commit_message:
User ids that begin with 0 cannot authenticate through ldap

Currently, in the ldap2py function, several fields are attempted
to be converted to python friendly types.

In doing so, an attempt to convert a field to int() is attempted,
but in some cases, a user id may begin with a 0. When the user
attempts to authenticate, they will be rejected since any additional
query will use the id without the 0 in front.

Closes-Bug: #1396763

Change-Id: I1e2436b845e534f6cdb0398b5cca17d8502b905f

commit_message:
Calculate rules_index after chain/rule processing

Currently rules_index may decremented if a duplicate rule or
chain is encountered that is not wrapped in the case of the
chain or in the case of a rule doesn't contain 'wrap_name'.
A duplicate rule/chain is a rule/chain that matches the above
criterea that iptables manager wants to add and that already
exists in the system's iptables ruleset.

Rather than deal with incrementing/decrementing the index when
a duplicate rule is encountered perhaps simpler alternative is
to not calculate the rule_index until the moment before the
new rules are inserted into the list of "new" rules.

The unit tests for this have been moved to the much better
written neutron.tests.unit.test_iptables_manager test.

Closes-Bug: 1311904
Change-Id: I9d88a4a8195f9f4a03bb8ba2accf2b9febeff42d

commit_message:
Incorrect work rally info find for SLA

If you type 'rally info find <query>' rally will suggest us docs that
 will be match by query. Even if you have one typo. otherwise it sugest
 you list of docs that you are possibly looking for. But if you type
'rally info find failure_rate' there output would be: "Failed to find
any docs for query: 'failure_rate'". Instead there must be information
about SLA(failure_rate): "Failure rate minimum and maximum in percents.".

Change-Id: Ie6c59e4091cddd8f5e81e2123cad1367b397a9b6
Closes-bug: 1399675

commit_message:
Extending delete_batch function and related test

in models.py (cue/db)
* added delete_batch methods in Cluster and Node class to
  override delete_batch in base class.

in test_models (cue/tests/db)
* removed test_delete_invalid_id since no changes take place
* updating status field in test dictionaries to use Status class
* updated batch_get test to include batch delete

Change-Id: Iae04a1cf6c5d71c08f37dc1aaca8b168364f5129

commit_message:
Add Functional Tests

* Added FunctionalTest base class to be used for testing API routes
* Added initial list clusters tests

Change-Id: Idd74be197003f398dc86d484aa943ddb2c1d39c2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cue refs/changes/20/139520/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # # Copyright 2012 New Dream Network, LLC (DreamHost) # # Author: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com> # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """Base classes for API tests. """ from oslo.config import cfg from oslo.config import fixture as fixture_config import pecan import pecan.testing from cue.tests import base OPT_GROUP_NAME = 'keystone_authtoken' cfg.CONF.import_group(OPT_GROUP_NAME, "keystonemiddleware.auth_token") cfg.CONF.import_opt("policy_file", "cue.openstack.common.policy") class FunctionalTest(base.TestCase): """Used for functional tests of Pecan controllers. Used in case when you need to test your literal application and its integration with the framework. """ PATH_PREFIX = '' def setUp(self): super(FunctionalTest, self).setUp() self.CONF = self.useFixture(fixture_config.Config()).conf self.CONF.set_override("auth_version", "v2.0", group=OPT_GROUP_NAME) # self.CONF.set_override("policy_file", # self.path_get('etc/cue/policy.json')) self.app = self._make_app() def _make_app(self, enable_acl=False): # Determine where we are so we can set up paths in the config root_dir = self.path_get() self.config = { 'app': { 'root': 'cue.api.controllers.root.RootController', 'modules': ['cue.api'], 'static_root': '%s/public' % root_dir, 'template_path': '%s/cue/api/templates' % root_dir, 'enable_acl': enable_acl, 'acl_public_routes': ['/', '/v1'], }, 'wsme': { 'debug': True, }, } return pecan.testing.load_test_app(self.config) def tearDown(self): super(FunctionalTest, self).tearDown() pecan.set_config({}, overwrite=True) def put_json(self, path, params, expect_errors=False, headers=None, extra_environ=None, status=None): """Sends simulated HTTP PUT request to Pecan test app. :param path: url path of target service :param params: content for wsgi.input of request :param expect_errors: boolean value whether an error is expected based on request :param headers: A dictionary of headers to send along with the request :param extra_environ: A dictionary of environ variables to send along with the request :param status: Expected status code of response """ return self.post_json(path=path, params=params, expect_errors=expect_errors, headers=headers, extra_environ=extra_environ, status=status, method="put") def post_json(self, path, params, expect_errors=False, headers=None, method="post", extra_environ=None, status=None): """Sends simulated HTTP POST request to Pecan test app. :param path: url path of target service :param params: content for wsgi.input of request :param expect_errors: boolean value whether an error is expected based on request :param headers: A dictionary of headers to send along with the request :param method: Request method type. Appropriate method function call should be used rather than passing attribute in. :param extra_environ: A dictionary of environ variables to send along with the request :param status: Expected status code of response """ full_path = self.PATH_PREFIX + path response = getattr(self.app, "%s_json" % method)( str(full_path), params=params, headers=headers, status=status, extra_environ=extra_environ, expect_errors=expect_errors ) return response def delete(self, path, expect_errors=False, headers=None, extra_environ=None, status=None): """Sends simulated HTTP DELETE request to Pecan test app. :param path: url path of target service :param expect_errors: boolean value whether an error is expected based on request :param headers: A dictionary of headers to send along with the request :param extra_environ: A dictionary of environ variables to send along with the request :param status: Expected status code of response """ full_path = self.PATH_PREFIX + path response = self.app.delete(str(full_path), headers=headers, status=status, extra_environ=extra_environ, expect_errors=expect_errors) return response def get_json(self, path, expect_errors=False, headers=None, extra_environ=None, q=None, groupby=None, status=None, override_params=None, **params): """Sends simulated HTTP GET request to Pecan test app. :param path: url path of target service :param expect_errors: boolean value whether an error is expected based on request :param headers: A dictionary of headers to send along with the request :param extra_environ: A dictionary of environ variables to send along with the request :param q: list of queries consisting of: field, value, op, and type keys :param groupby: list of fields to group by :param status: Expected status code of response :param override_params: literally encoded query param string :param params: content for wsgi.input of request """ q = q or [] groupby = groupby or [] full_path = self.PATH_PREFIX + path if override_params: all_params = override_params else: query_params = {'q.field': [], 'q.value': [], 'q.op': [], 'q.type': [], } for query in q: for name in ['field', 'op', 'value', 'type']: query_params['q.%s' % name].append(query.get(name, '')) all_params = {} all_params.update(params) if q: all_params.update(query_params) if groupby: all_params.update({'groupby': groupby}) response = self.app.get(full_path, params=all_params, headers=headers, extra_environ=extra_environ, expect_errors=expect_errors, status=status) if not expect_errors: response = response.json return response

commit_message:
Move last of tests to tests directory

The following commit: a016838546f695cbecdd69b2742d36d7c8dbadc6
moved all the tests here but the plexxi one slipped in before it
was merged and the policy/builtins/tests was left out by mistake.
This patch corrects this.

Change-Id: I36d7654396102b277ad900a158afafa216a022fb

commit_message:
initialize objects with context in pci manager

These changes aim to clean up the pattern of passing a context in
object member functions create/destroy/refresh/save and instead
initialize the object with the context when it's constructed.

Change-Id: Ic860411f389b12d27b4a11cd15dfca6c11e55471

commit_message:
Print version info at start

When debugging problems from logs, it would be useful to know what
version is running across program start and stop.  In one case I have
a suspicion that an upgrade was run inbetween but the logs don't help
identify that.

My first thought was to grab this from argparse just as --version
does, but that's not really currently possible [1].

The original starting message is probably irrelevant, but I realise
log messages tend to suffer from Hotel California syndrome; you can
check-in but you can never leave.

[1] http://bugs.python.org/issue9399

Change-Id: Ia1bfd2f3589b508e19fd8a94d59beaafd6d657d2

added_lines: @_retry.retry def _get_members(self, group_id): encoded_group = self._encode_group_id(group_id) group_members, cas = self.client.gets(encoded_group) actual_group_members = {} for m, v in six.iteritems(group_members): # Never kick self from the group, we know we're alive if (m == self._member_id or self.client.get(self._encode_member_id(m))): actual_group_members[m] = v if group_members != actual_group_members: # There are some dead members, update the group if not self.client.cas(encoded_group, actual_group_members, cas): # It changed, let's try again raise _retry.Retry return actual_group_members
deleted_lines: def _get_members(self, group_id): group_members = self.client.get(self._encode_group_id(group_id)) return dict((m, v) for m, v in six.iteritems(group_members) if self.client.get(self._encode_member_id(m)))

commit_message:
tests: remove check_port

It's not portable and currently the detection scheme use really easy to
break and report false positive. Try to rather launch services on
different ports.

Change-Id: I0739bea2f8fe42e1bba1c04e6ce5be14237dfbcb

commit_message:
Use condition variables using 'with'

Instead of doing [acquire, try, finally, release]
just use the condition variable as a context manager
to achieve the same effect with less code and with
less verbosity.

Change-Id: I0a3bb80a932a3dc6623ba2378afa0341e9e06e5a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/95/139895/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: with self._cond: with self._cond:
deleted_lines: self._cond.acquire() try: finally: self._cond.release() self._cond.acquire() try: finally: self._cond.release()

subject: Compute Add build_instance hook in compute manager
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-07-11 20:07:11.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/be3d45e9c4bd4e7fb61d21a2b6404c599fae85b3', 'message': 'Add build_instance hook in compute manager

The build_instance hook provides a hook close to the actual spawn
of an instance. It distinguishes itself from the create_instance
hook because, in the case of a successful build, the instance will
exist on the hypervisor when the build_instance post hook is
called, instead of simply just being scheduled as is the case with
the create_instance post hook. This is useful as some details may
not be availabe until after scheduling.

commit_message:
Compute Add build_instance hook in compute manager

The build_instance hook provides a hook close to the actual spawn
of an instance. It distinguishes itself from the create_instance
hook because, in the case of a successful build, the instance will
exist on the hypervisor when the build_instance post hook is
called, instead of simply just being scheduled as is the case with
the create_instance post hook. This is useful as some details may
not be available until after scheduling.

Co-Authored-By: Corey Wright <corey.wright@rackspace.com>
Change-Id: Ic12abf6315bbc6b010b8222ef296ec65cb4b4f95

commit_message:
Inherit RequestContext from oslo

In the long-term, OpenStack projects should use oslo.context as the base
class for their custom contexts. This enables the use of
application-agnostic tools, e.g. global logging configurations. See
http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/oslo-specs/specs/juno/app-agnostic-logging-parameters.html

This patch syncs the latest context module from oslo-incubator and use
it as the base class for Cinder RequestContext. The goal is to clean up
Cinder code, and to be ready for the first oslo.context release.

Change-Id: Iba9354b402de556ca6e55e7c17dd6f3f1624d72d
Related-bug: #1210261

deleted_lines: # Copyright 2011 OpenStack Foundation. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """ Simple class that stores security context information in the web request. Projects should subclass this class if they wish to enhance the request context or provide additional information in their specific WSGI pipeline. """ import itertools import uuid def generate_request_id(): return 'req-%s' % str(uuid.uuid4()) class RequestContext(object): """Helper class to represent useful information about a request context. Stores information about the security context under which the user accesses the system, as well as additional request information. """ user_idt_format = '{user} {tenant} {domain} {user_domain} {p_domain}' def __init__(self, auth_token=None, user=None, tenant=None, domain=None, user_domain=None, project_domain=None, is_admin=False, read_only=False, show_deleted=False, request_id=None, instance_uuid=None): self.auth_token = auth_token self.user = user self.tenant = tenant self.domain = domain self.user_domain = user_domain self.project_domain = project_domain self.is_admin = is_admin self.read_only = read_only self.show_deleted = show_deleted self.instance_uuid = instance_uuid if not request_id: request_id = generate_request_id() self.request_id = request_id def to_dict(self): user_idt = ( self.user_idt_format.format(user=self.user or '-', tenant=self.tenant or '-', domain=self.domain or '-', user_domain=self.user_domain or '-', p_domain=self.project_domain or '-')) return {'user': self.user, 'tenant': self.tenant, 'domain': self.domain, 'user_domain': self.user_domain, 'project_domain': self.project_domain, 'is_admin': self.is_admin, 'read_only': self.read_only, 'show_deleted': self.show_deleted, 'auth_token': self.auth_token, 'request_id': self.request_id, 'instance_uuid': self.instance_uuid, 'user_identity': user_idt} def get_admin_context(show_deleted=False): context = RequestContext(None, tenant=None, is_admin=True, show_deleted=show_deleted) return context def get_context_from_function_and_args(function, args, kwargs): """Find an arg of type RequestContext and return it. This is useful in a couple of decorators where we don't know much about the function we're wrapping. """ for arg in itertools.chain(kwargs.values(), args): if isinstance(arg, RequestContext): return arg return None def is_user_context(context): """Indicates if the request context is a normal user.""" if not context: return False if context.is_admin: return False if not context.user_id or not context.project_id: return False return True

commit_message:
Fix timeout in test_slave_user_removed int-test

The test_slave_user_removed int-test polls to check that the
slave user account is removed, but doesn't currently have a time
out set. This means that a failure in this test causes the entire
suite to spin, and ultimately time out. Fix this by adding a 3 min
timeout to this test.

Change-Id: I5f869c7d3cb0587409b5a12a89ed673e57552b82
Closes-bug: 1399583

commit_message:
Obsolete oslo-incubator modules - importutils

This change is part of a multi-part change set to handle obsolete and
graduated oslo modules. This change addresses import utils that is now
part of oslo.utils.

The file importutils is not being deleted because of dependencies
within oslo-incubator

commit_message:
Added versioning and migration mandates

Updated HACKING.rst to include mandates
around API versioning and seamless migrations.

Change-Id: Iafb33d7a698b22a84a7b6167792e4d37aed110de
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/octavia refs/changes/55/139755/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: heterogeneous parts, throughout the lifecycle of this project, different partsOctavia must also keep in mind Neutron LBaaS API versions. Octavia must have the ability to support multiple simultaneous Neutron LBaaS API versions in an effort to allow for Neutron LBaaS API deprecation of URIs. The rationale is that Neutron LBaaS API users should have the ability to transition from one version to the next easily. Upgrade and downgrade migrations will be supported -------------------------------------------------- Whenever large operators conduct upgrades it is important to have a backup plan in the form of downgrades. While upgrade migrations are commonplace, often, downgrade migrations are ignored. Octavia will support migrations that allow for seamless version to version upgrades/downgrades within the scope of a major version. For example, assume that an operator is currently hosting version 1.0 of Octavia and wants to upgrade to Octavia version 1.1. A database migration will consist of an upgrade migration and a downgrade migration that do not fail due to foreign key constraints or other typical migration issues.
deleted_lines: heterogenous parts, throughout the lifecycle of this project, different parts

commit_message:
Eliminate duplicated LoopingCall and LoopingCallDone code

Bug 1307560 cleaned up some parts of this particular use of deprecated
code. However there is still one instance left in
trove/common/utils.py which needs to be cleaned out. This change
removes LoopingCall and LoopingCallDone from utils.py and references
the openstack code from loopingcall.py.

Change-Id: Ice69626d4e6cbb1186aba8d84cfd6109569eba8f
Closes-Bug: #1314766
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/13/128713/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from trove.openstack.common import loopingcall raise loopingcall.LoopingCallDone(retvalue=obj) lc = loopingcall.LoopingCall(f=poll_and_check).start(sleep_time, True)
deleted_lines: import sysfrom eventlet import event from eventlet import greenthreadclass LoopingCallDone(Exception): """Exception to break out and stop a LoopingCall. The poll-function passed to LoopingCall can raise this exception to break out of the loop normally. This is somewhat analogous to StopIteration. An optional return-value can be included as the argument to the exception; this return-value will be returned by LoopingCall.wait() """ def __init__(self, retvalue=True): """:param retvalue: Value that LoopingCall.wait() should return.""" super(LoopingCallDone, self).__init__() self.retvalue = retvalue class LoopingCall(object): """Nabbed from nova.""" def __init__(self, f=None, *args, **kw): self.args = args self.kw = kw self.f = f self._running = False def start(self, interval, now=True): self._running = True done = event.Event() def _inner(): if not now: greenthread.sleep(interval) try: while self._running: self.f(*self.args, **self.kw) if not self._running: break greenthread.sleep(interval) except LoopingCallDone as e: self.stop() done.send(e.retvalue) except Exception: LOG.exception(_('In looping call.')) done.send_exception(*sys.exc_info()) return else: done.send(True) self.done = done greenthread.spawn(_inner) return self.done def stop(self): self._running = False def wait(self): return self.done.wait() raise LoopingCallDone(retvalue=obj) lc = LoopingCall(f=poll_and_check).start(sleep_time, True)

commit_message:
Clean up github references from docs

OpenStack hosts things in places that are not github. Also, it seems
that there is a big blob of unrelated readme in the README file.

Closes-Bug: 1399839
Change-Id: I70cc6772b50591c4b3badd6c92567a7a6541bacf
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/00/136400/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: ====== Docs ====== This repository contains the following OpenStack manual: * Database Services API Reference Prerequisites ------------- `Apache Maven <http://maven.apache.org/>`_ must be installed to build the documentation. To install Maven 3 for Ubuntu 12.04 and later, and Debian wheezy and later:: apt-get install maven On Fedora 15 and later:: yum install maven3 Building -------- The manuals are in the ``apidocs`` directory. To build a specific guide, look for a ``pom.xml`` file within a subdirectory, then run the ``mvn`` command in that directory. For example:: cd apidocs mvn clean generate-sources The generated PDF documentation file is:: apidocs/target/docbkx/webhelp/cdb-devguide/cdb-devguide-reviewer.pdf The root of the generated HTML documentation is:: apidocs/target/docbkx/webhelp/cdb-devguide/content/index.html Testing of changes and building of the manual ---------------------------------------------- Install the python tox package and run ``tox`` from the top-level directory to use the same tests that are done as part of our Jenkins gating jobs. If you like to run individual tests, run: * ``tox -e checkniceness`` - to run the niceness tests * ``tox -e checksyntax`` - to run syntax checks * ``tox -e checkdeletions`` - to check that no deleted files are referenced * ``tox -e checkbuild`` - to actually build the manual tox will use the `openstack-doc-tools package <https://github.com/openstack/openstack-doc-tools>`_ for execution of these tests. openstack-doc-tools has a requirement on maven for the build check. Contributing ============ Our community welcomes all people interested in open source cloud computing, and encourages you to join the `OpenStack Foundation <http://www.openstack.org/join>`_. The best way to get involved with the community is to talk with others online or at a meetup and offer contributions through our processes, the `OpenStack wiki <http://wiki.openstack.org>`_, blogs, or on IRC at ``#openstack`` on ``irc.freenode.net``. We welcome all types of contributions, from blueprint designs to documentation to testing to deployment scripts. If you would like to contribute to the documents, please see the `Documentation HowTo <https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Documentation/HowTo>`_. Bugs ==== Bugs should be filed on Launchpad, not GitHub: https://bugs.launchpad.net/openstack-api-site/ Installing ========== Refer to http://docs.openstack.org to see where these documents are published and to learn more about the OpenStack project.

commit_message:
Adds external attachment type validators to ML2

Adds external attachment type validator code for
binding ports with a HOST-ID field that represents
an L2 access point in a network (e.g. switch port + VLAN tag).

This will allow baremetal devices (e.g. Ironic servers) to be
attached to a given Neutron network via the standard ML2 port
binding mechanisms.

DocImpact

Partially Implements: blueprint neutron-external-attachment-points
Change-Id: I3a8472e3e7c990056f1f3846aadec40d70183661

subject: Add API intercept to feed requests to handlers
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-07-28 04:16:24.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/07e716ffe84ba717b25ae78a1d7024328bda0ce1', 'message': 'Add API intercept to feed requests to handlers

WIP: add an intercept layer to all requests for plugins via the neutron
manager. The interceptor passed back can then pass all requests through
intercept handlers that can modify the requets and results of all method calls
to core and service plugins.

commit_message:
Add API intercept to feed requests to handlers

Add an intercept layer to all requests for plugins via the neutron
manager. The interceptor passed back can then pass all requests through
intercept handlers. Each handler can modify the requets and results of
all method calls to core and service plugins.

Implements: blueprint api-intercept-plugin
Change-Id: Ia1dc1fdb2fdebd29e7a5546cf147323102f1bc28
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/01/109901/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.interceptor = Interceptor() self.interceptor.register_plugin(constants.CORE, self.plugin) self.service_plugins = { constants.CORE: self.interceptor.get_plugin_proxy(constants.CORE) } self.interceptor.register_plugin(service_type, self.plugin) pproxy = self.interceptor.get_plugin_proxy(constants.CORE) self.service_plugins[service_type] = pproxy stype = plugin_inst.get_plugin_type() self.interceptor.register_plugin(stype, plugin_inst) self.service_plugins[stype] = self.interceptor.get_plugin_proxy( stype) class Interceptor(object): def __init__(self): self.plugins = {} self.plugin_proxies = {} self.handlers = tuple() def register_handler(self, handler): self.handlers = tuple(list(self.handlers) + [handler]) def register_plugin(self, stype, plugin): self.plugin_proxies[stype] = PluginProxy(stype, self) self.plugins[stype] = plugin def getattr_on_type(self, stype, name): attr = getattr(self.plugins[stype], name) if not callable(attr): return attr return AttributeProxy(stype, name, self) def attribute_call(self, stype, attr_name, *args, **kwargs): for h in self.handlers: (attr_name, args, kwargs) = h.pre_attribute_call(stype, name, args, kwargs) result = getattr(self.plugins[stype], attr_name)(*args, **kwargs) for h in self.handlers: result = h.post_attribute_call(stype, attr_name, args, kwargs, result) return result def get_plugin_proxy(self, stype): return self.plugin_proxies[stype] class AttributeProxy(object): """Proxy for a callable plugin attribute to pass call back to interceptor. Keeps track of the service plugin type, the instantiating interceptor, and the name of the attribute being called. When called, it calls the attribute_call method of the interceptor that will then make the call to the real plugin method after passing through the intercept handlers. """ def __init__(self, stype, attr_name, interceptor): self.attr_name = attr_name self.stype = stype self.interceptor = interceptor def __call__(self, *args, **kwargs): return self.interceptor.attribute_call(self.stype, self.attr_name, *args, **kwargs) class PluginProxy(object): def __init__(self, stype, interceptor): self.stype = stype self.interceptor = interceptor def __getattr__(self, attr_name): return self.interceptor.getattr_on_type(self.stype, attr_name)
deleted_lines: self.service_plugins = {constants.CORE: self.plugin} self.service_plugins[service_type] = self.plugin self.service_plugins[plugin_inst.get_plugin_type()] = plugin_inst

commit_message:
Check the invalid suffix in RestAPI uri

Currently, RestAPI supports xml or json format type, invalid suffix
in uri should be forbidden.

Change-Id: I7e3c02e241d3993ca536876ace99187b2d2461e4
Closes-Bug: #1330095

commit_message:
Sync oslo-incubator

We hasn't synced with oslo-incubator in a while so this brings
us back up to date and updates neutron where needed.

Based from commit: 669f0383e933f5446427ed13341144e447fa5140

Change-Id: If8d7b8fb09882e7bda26a833c98eac0a0d299103
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/13/120313/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def __init__(self, domain, localedir=None): t = gettext.translation(domain, localedir=self.localedir, fallback=True) # Use the appropriate method of the translation object based # on the python version. m = t.gettext if six.PY3 else t.ugettext def f(msg): """oslo.i18n.gettextutils translation function.""" if USE_LAZY: return Message(msg, domain=domain) return m(msg) return f global USE_LAZYdef install(domain): Note that to enable lazy translation, enable_lazy must be called. from six import moves tf = TranslatorFactory(domain) moves.builtins.__dict__['_'] = tf.primary
deleted_lines: import functools def __init__(self, domain, lazy=False, localedir=None): self.lazy = lazy if self.lazy: return functools.partial(Message, domain=domain) t = gettext.translation( domain, localedir=self.localedir, fallback=True, ) if six.PY3: return t.gettext return t.ugettext # FIXME(dhellmann): This function will be removed in oslo.i18n, # because the TranslatorFactory makes it superfluous. global _, _LI, _LW, _LE, _LC, USE_LAZY tf = TranslatorFactory('neutron', lazy=True) _ = tf.primary _LI = tf.log_info _LW = tf.log_warning _LE = tf.log_error _LC = tf.log_criticaldef install(domain, lazy=False): :param lazy: indicates whether or not to install the lazy _() function. The lazy _() introduces a way to do deferred translation of messages by installing a _ that builds Message objects, instead of strings, which can then be lazily translated into any available locale. if lazy: from six import moves tf = TranslatorFactory(domain, lazy=True) moves.builtins.__dict__['_'] = tf.primary else: localedir = '%s_LOCALEDIR' % domain.upper() if six.PY3: gettext.install(domain, localedir=os.environ.get(localedir)) else: gettext.install(domain, localedir=os.environ.get(localedir), unicode=True)

commit_message:
Implements: Brocade LBaaS Plugin Driver and Device Driver

Implementation of the blueprint neutron-brocade-lbaas-driver.
This patch set also supports simple file based device inventory.

call the device driver api self.device_driver.create_vip(device, vip) self.db.update_status(context, loadbalancer_db.Vip, vip["id"], constants.ACTIVE) except Exception as e: LOG.debug(_("Exception in create_vip in device driver : %s"), e) self.db.update_status(context, loadbalancer_db.Vip, vip["id"], constants.ERROR) @log def update_vip(self, context, old_vip, new_vip): try: device = self._fetch_device(context, new_vip['pool_id']) # call the device driver api self.device_driver.update_vip(device, new_vip, old_vip) self.db.update_status(context, loadbalancer_db.Vip, new_vip["id"], constants.ACTIVE) except Exception as e: LOG.debug(_("Exception in update_vip in device driver : %s"), e) self.db.update_status(context, loadbalancer_db.Vip, new_vip["id"], constants.ERROR) @log def delete_vip(self, context, vip): try: device = self._fetch_device(context, vip['pool_id']) # call the device driver api self.device_driver.delete_vip(device, vip) self.db.delete_vip(context, vip["id"]) except Exception as e: LOG.debug(_("Exception in delete_vip in device driver : %s"), e) self.db.update_status(context, loadbalancer_db.Vip, vip["id"], constants.ERROR) @log def create_pool(self, context, pool): try: device = self._fetch_device(context, pool['id']) # call the device driver api self.device_driver.create_pool(device, pool) self.db.update_status(context, loadbalancer_db.Pool, pool["id"], constants.ACTIVE) except Exception as e: LOG.debug(_("Exception in create_pool in device driver : %s"), e) self.db.update_status(context, loadbalancer_db.Pool, pool["id"], constants.ERROR) @log def update_pool(self, context, old_pool, new_pool): try: device = self._fetch_device(context, new_pool['id']) # call the device driver api self.device_driver.update_pool(device, new_pool, old_pool) self.db.update_status(context, loadbalancer_db.Pool, new_pool["id"], constants.ACTIVE) except Exception as e: LOG.debug(_("Exception in update in device driver : %s"), e) self.db.update_status(context, loadbalancer_db.Pool, new_pool["id"], constants.ERROR) @log def delete_pool(self, context, pool): try: device = self._fetch_device(context, pool['id']) # call the device driver api self.device_driver.delete_pool(device, pool) LOG.debug(_("Pool successfully deleted by the Device Driver ....")) self.db.delete_pool(context, pool["id"]) except Exception as e: LOG.debug(_("Exception in delete_pool in device driver : %s"), e) self.db.delete_pool(context, pool["id"]) @log def stats(self, context, pool_id): return {"bytes_in": 0, "bytes_out": 0, "active_connections": 0, "total_connections": 0} @log def create_member(self, context, member): try: device = self._fetch_device(context, member['pool_id']) # call the device driver api self.device_driver.create_member(device, member) self.db.update_status(context, loadbalancer_db.Member, member["id"], constants.ACTIVE) except Exception as e: LOG.debug(_("Exception in create_member in device driver : %s"), e) self.db.update_status(context, loadbalancer_db.Member, member["id"], constants.ERROR) @log def update_member(self, context, old_member, new_member): try: device = self._fetch_device(context, new_member['pool_id']) # call the device driver api self.device_driver.update_member(device, new_member, old_member) self.db.update_status(context, loadbalancer_db.Member, new_member["id"], constants.ACTIVE) except Exception as e: LOG.debug(_("Exception in update_member in device driver : %s"), e) self.db.update_status(context, loadbalancer_db.Member, new_member["id"], constants.ERROR) @log def delete_member(self, context, member): try: device = self._fetch_device(context, member['pool_id']) # call the device driver api self.device_driver.delete_member(device, member) LOG.debug(_("Member successfully deleted " "by the Device Driver ....")) except Exception as e: LOG.debug(_("Exception in delete_member in device driver : %s"), e) self.db.update_status(context, loadbalancer_db.Member, member["id"], constants.ERROR) self.db.delete_member(context, member["id"]) @log def create_health_monitor(self, context, health_monitor): pass @log def update_health_monitor(self, context, old_health_monitor, health_monitor, pool_association): pass @log def delete_health_monitor(self, context, health_monitor): self.plugin._delete_db_health_monitor(context, health_monitor["id"]) @log def create_pool_health_monitor(self, context, health_monitor, pool_id): try: device = self._fetch_device(context, pool_id) # call the device driver api self.device_driver.create_health_monitor(device, health_monitor, pool_id) LOG.debug(_("Health Monitor successfully created " "by the Device Driver ....")) self.db.update_pool_health_monitor(context, health_monitor['id'], pool_id, constants.ACTIVE) except Exception as e: LOG.debug(_("Exception in create_health_monitor " "in device driver : %s"), e) self.db.delete_pool_health_monitor(context, health_monitor["id"], pool_id) @log def delete_pool_health_monitor(self, context, health_monitor, pool_id): try: device = self._fetch_device(context, pool_id) # call the device driver api self.device_driver.delete_health_monitor(device, health_monitor, pool_id) LOG.debug(_("Health Monitor successfully deleted " "by the Device Driver ....")) except Exception as e: LOG.debug(_("Exception in delete_health_monitor " "in device driver : %s"), e) self.db.delete_pool_health_monitor(context, health_monitor["id"], pool_id)

commit_message:
Cisco N1KV: Enable HTTPs communication with VSM

Right now Cisco N1KV communicates with VSM using http.
This commit will make HTTPs the default communication of the plugin
and will also enable to configure that the plugin does SSL
verification of the VSM certificate.

The verification is optional since it needs an out of band
way to put the VSM certicate in the controller.

Change-Id: I863eb48c85c82126b7c9bb1e05f2bb4775ecb9d5
Closes-Bug: 1365600

subject: Block external access directly to qg devices in logical routers.
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-09-04 13:27:34.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/agent/l3_agent.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/b536ee44340acd94e3c2e9936c347fd6a9dcc925', 'message': "Block external access directly to qg devices in logical routers.

The qg device in a logical router which has a gateway set
is accessible on that gateway's IP address. This is especially
problematic when the metadata-proxy is running as it becomes accessible.
This patch adds a drop rule after the dst: 127.0.0.1 port: 9697
rule for all traffic destined for the qg device which is not
RELATED,ESTABLISHED. Floating IP functionality happens prior to this
so that will continue working, and we really don't want anyone establishing
new connections into our logical routers directly.

Change-Id: Ica9b23490832c0b6037ebf84573a200d6c53d4ec
Closes-Bug: 1350975
"}]
commit_message:
Block external access directly to qg devices in logical routers.

The qg device in a logical router which has a gateway set
is accessible on that gateway's IP address. This is especially
problematic when the metadata-proxy is running as it becomes accessible.
This patch adds a drop rule after the dst: 127.0.0.1 port: 9697
rule for all traffic destined for the qg device which is not
RELATED,ESTABLISHED. Floating IP functionality happens prior to this
so that will continue working, and we really don't want anyone establishing
new connections into our logical routers directly.

Change-Id: Ica9b23490832c0b6037ebf84573a200d6c53d4ec
Closes-Bug: 1350975

commit_message:
Set default unit test timeout to 10 seconds

Set the default unit test timeout to 10 seconds instead
of having them run unbound. 10 seconds is more than long
enough to cover normal unit tests and will prevent changes
like Idd770a85a9eabff112d9613e75d8bb524020234a from merging,
which caused 2 seconds of tests to balloon up to 5 minutes.

Related-Bug: #1372076
Change-Id: I33a7334477172b98e9cf76e51cb958026221ba0f

commit_message:
Cisco DFA ML2 Mechanism Driver - Part 4

This commit contains changes that implement config profile for DFA as a
service plugin.

Change-Id: Ibd11dcbcfc6a41c495a41075f80e03d35ba6dfd0
Partially Implements: blueprint ml2-mechanism-driver-for-cisco-dfa

added_lines: # Copyright 2014 Cisco Systems, Inc. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. # # @author: Nader Lahouti, Cisco Systems, Inc. import eventlet from sqlalchemy.orm import exc from neutron.api import extensions import neutron.db.api as db from neutron.db import common_db_mixin as base_db from neutron.openstack.common import log as logging from neutron.openstack.common import uuidutils as uuidutils from neutron.plugins.ml2.drivers.cisco import dfa from neutron.plugins.ml2.drivers.cisco.dfa import cisco_dfa_rest from neutron.plugins.ml2.drivers.cisco.dfa import config_profile as cfg_prof from neutron.plugins.ml2.drivers.cisco.dfa import constants as dfac from neutron.plugins.ml2.drivers.cisco.dfa import dfa_exceptions as dexc from neutron.plugins.ml2.drivers.cisco.dfa import dfa_models_v2 LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) class ConfigProfile_db_mixin(cfg_prof.ConfigProfilePluginBase, base_db.CommonDbMixin): """Config Profile Mixin.""" def _fields(self, res, fields): if fields: return dict(((key, item) for key, item in res.items() if key in fields)) return res def _make_config_profile_dict(self, config_profile, fields=None): res = {'id': config_profile['id'], 'name': config_profile['name']} return self._fields(res, fields) def _config_profile_exists(self, cfgid=None, cfgname=None): """Check if profile exist.""" if cfgid == dfac.DEFAULT_CFG_PROFILE_ID: return True db_session = db.get_session() if cfgid: ent = (db_session.query(dfa_models_v2.ConfigProfile). filter_by(id=cfgid).first()) if ent is None: return False elif ent.id == cfgid: return True else: return False if cfgname: ent = (db_session.query(dfa_models_v2.ConfigProfile). filter_by(name=cfgname).first()) if ent is None: return False elif ent.name == cfgname: return True else: return False def _delete_config_profile(self, cfg_profile_id): """Delete config profile.""" db_session = db.get_session() with db_session.begin(subtransactions=True): (db_session.query(dfa_models_v2.ConfigProfile). filter_by(id=cfg_profile_id).delete()) def _get_config_profile_binding(self, db_session, cfgp_id): """Retrieve config profile binding.""" try: return (db_session.query(dfa_models_v2.ConfigProfileBinding). filter_by(cfg_profile_id=cfgp_id). one()) except (exc.NoResultFound, exc.MultipleResultsFound): return None def get_config_profile(self, context, cfgid, fields=None): """Return configuration profile for a given id.""" cfgp = self.get_cfg_profile(context.session, cfgid) return self._make_config_profile_dict(cfgp, fields) def get_config_profiles(self, context, filters=None, fields=None): """Return DFA configuration profiles.""" res = self._get_collection(context, dfa_models_v2.ConfigProfile, self._make_config_profile_dict, filters=filters, fields=fields) return res def _add_config_profile(self, cfg_profile_name, cfg_profile_id, fwd_mode): """Add config profile to the database.""" cfg_profile = {'id': cfg_profile_id, 'name': cfg_profile_name, 'forwarding_mode': fwd_mode} if not self._config_profile_exists(cfgname=cfg_profile_name): self._create_config_profile(cfg_profile) def _invalidate_config_profile(self): """Invalidate the onfig profile database.""" db_session = db.get_session() entries = db_session.query(dfa_models_v2.ConfigProfile).all() for ent in entries: if not self._get_config_profile_binding(db_session, ent.id): # The config profile is not bind to any network. # Delete it from database. self._delete_config_profile(ent.id) def _create_config_profile(self, cp): """Create Config Profile.""" db_session = db.get_session() with db_session.begin(subtransactions=True): cfgp = dfa_models_v2.ConfigProfile(id=cp['id'], name=cp['name'], forwarding_mode= cp['forwarding_mode']) db_session.add(cfgp) return cfgp def get_cfg_profile(self, db_session, id): """Get Config Profile.""" try: return db_session.query( dfa_models_v2.ConfigProfile).filter_by(id=id).one() except (exc.NoResultFound, exc.MultipleResultsFound): raise dexc.ConfigProfileIdNotFound(profile_id=id) class ConfigProfilePlugin(ConfigProfile_db_mixin): """Implementation of the Cisco DFA Config Profile Service Plugin.""" supported_extension_aliases = ["config_profile"] def __init__(self): super(ConfigProfilePlugin, self).__init__() extensions.append_api_extensions_path(dfa.__path__) # Initialize DCNM client. self._dcnm_client = cisco_dfa_rest.DFARESTClient() # Populate config profile table. # And update the table periodically by spawning a task. self._ctask_sleep_interval = 60 eventlet.spawn(self._config_profile_task) def _populate_cfg_profiles(self): """Populates the configuration porfile database. Get the profile list from DCNM and save it in the database after assigning a unique uuid to each of them. """ try: cfg_profiles = self._dcnm_client.config_profile_list() if len(cfg_profiles): for prof in cfg_profiles: cfgp_id = uuidutils.generate_uuid() cfgp_name = prof fwd_mode = (self._dcnm_client. config_profile_fwding_mode_get(prof)) self._add_config_profile(cfgp_name, cfgp_id, fwd_mode) LOG.debug('cfgp_name = %(cn)s, cfgp_id = %(id)s, ' ' fwd_mod = %(fm)s' % {'cn': cfgp_name, 'id': cfgp_id, 'fm': fwd_mode}) except dexc.DFAClientRequestFailed as ex: # The DCNM in not responsive. It is needed to invalidate the # database to reflect that. self._invalidate_config_profile() emsg = _('Failed to get config profiles:err = %s') LOG.error(emsg % ex) def _config_profile_task(self): """Periodic task that polls DCNM to get configuration profile.""" while True: self._populate_cfg_profiles() eventlet.sleep(self._ctask_sleep_interval) def get_config_profiles(self, context, filters=None, fields=None): """Return DFA configuration profiles.""" res = super(ConfigProfilePlugin, self).get_config_profiles(context, filters, fields) return res

commit_message:
Cisco DFA ML2 Mechanism Driver - part 2

This is part 2 of changes to support Cisco DFA ML2 mechanism driver.
The changes in this commit are in ovs_neutron_agent and they setup RPC for
Mechanism Driver.
In DFA topology where openstack compute nodes are connected to the external
switches or fabrics, VDP protocol is used to assign VLAN for communication
between VM on compute nodes and the switches. VDP is running on all compute
nodes and as part of the DFA requirements the VDP is required to send Cisco
organization-specific OUI to the switches. For that reason, the mechanism
driver prepares the data and send it to the agent on compute nodes using RPC.
The changes in this commit define parameters in the config file that both
mechanism driver and agent can use to setup RPC.
It is worth to note here that, RPC can be avoided if get_device_details could
ask a mechanism driver to add more information to the return dictionary if
they need to. For now this is not supported so RPC is used to exchange the
information.

Partially Implements: blueprint ml2-mechanism-driver-for-cisco-dfa

Change-Id: I56847b67f7be117b42896ddb41af95088acc245d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/65/110065/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import itertools # This list keeps list of topic's name for agent and mechanism drivers. self._mech_driver_rpc_topics = [] # Populate the _mech_driver_rpc_topics list. md_rpc = cfg.CONF.mech_driver_agent.mech_driver_rpc if md_rpc: self._create_mech_driver_topics_list(md_rpc) self._setup_mech_driver_consumers(consumers) def _create_mech_driver_topics_list(self, mech_drvr): """ Create list of topics for each mechanism driver and agent. name: name of mechanism driver, plugin_topic: topic name on the mechanism driver side, agent_topic: topic name on the agent side. """ key_list = ['name', 'plugin_topic', 'agent_topic'] for val in mech_drvr: if len(val) > 0: tmplist = val.split(':') while len(tmplist) < len(key_list): tmplist.append(None) d = dict(itertools.izip(key_list, tmplist)) self._mech_driver_rpc_topics.append(d) LOG.debug(('List of mechanism drivers RPC topics=%s') % (self._mech_driver_rpc_topics)) def _setup_mech_driver_consumers(self, consumers): """Add agent's topic to the listening consumers list, for every mechanism driver in the _mech_driver_rpc_topics list. """ for md in self._mech_driver_rpc_topics: a_topic = md['agent_topic'] if a_topic: consumers.append([a_topic, topics.UPDATE]) def send_vm_info(self, context, **kwargs): # NOTE: The oui data prepared by this method will be used by another # blueprint that implements support for VDP in neutron agent: # https://review.openstack.org/#/c/89728/ # https://review.openstack.org/#/c/105563/ LOG.debug("vm_info received") vminfo = kwargs.get('vm_info') if not vminfo: return

commit_message:
Implement ebtables manager

A manager for the ebtables utility. An ebtables manager
is needed for an additional patch, which will close an
ARP cache poisoning loophole.

While there are similarities between iptables-manager and
ebtables-manager, these have not been factored out, since
the iptables-manager code is sensitive and it's not
desirable to modify it at this time.

The implementation of the ebtables manager comes in large
part from an abandoned patch provided by douard Thuleau, which
he presented for review here:

        https://review.openstack.org/#/c/70067/

Credit for the workin of the ebtables manager should go to
douard, I merely ported it to today's code.

Related-bug: 1274034
Co-authored-by: Thuleau douard <edouard.thuleau@cloudwatt.com>

Change-Id: Ic3c92aed35bd7875c0bab25c95a9ca2e6b8ae243

Refactor OpenDaylight ML2 driver

This commit refactors the OpenDaylight mechanism driver so that the
REST Client can be re-used by other neutron service plugins

commit_message:
Adds FWaaS service plugin for Cisco CSR1kv

Support for Cisco CSR1kv Firewall:
Add API extensions and associated db for insertion of FW service
on Cisco CSR1kv router. There are no changes to the reference implemention
model for FWaaS rules and policies.

Change-Id: I81c462211d9d42956783f432bfb5f9aef9021420
Implements: blueprint fwaas-cisco

added_lines: # Copyright 2014 Cisco Systems, Inc. All rights reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. # from oslo.config import cfg from neutron.common import constants as l3_const from neutron.common import rpc as n_rpc from neutron.common import topics from neutron import context as neutron_context from neutron import manager from neutron.openstack.common import log as logging import neutron.plugins from neutron.plugins.cisco.db import cisco_fwaas_db as csrfw_db from neutron.plugins.cisco.extensions import csrfirewall as csr_ext from neutron.plugins.common import constants as const from neutron.services.firewall import fwaas_plugin as ref_fw_plugin LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) class FirewallCallbacks(n_rpc.RpcCallback): RPC_API_VERSION = '1.0' def __init__(self, plugin): super(FirewallCallbacks, self).__init__() self.plugin = plugin # todo: sridar this class needs to be refactored, leaving this # in for ability to do some sanity testing with L3Agent. def set_firewall_status(self, context, firewall_id, status, **kwargs): """Agent uses this to set a firewall's status.""" LOG.debug(_("set_firewall_status() called")) with context.session.begin(subtransactions=True): fw_db = self.plugin._get_firewall(context, firewall_id) # ignore changing status if firewall expects to be deleted # That case means that while some pending operation has been # performed on the backend, neutron server received delete request # and changed firewall status to const.PENDING_DELETE if fw_db.status == const.PENDING_DELETE: LOG.debug(_("Firewall %(fw_id)s in PENDING_DELETE state, " "not changing to %(status)s"), {'fw_id': firewall_id, 'status': status}) return False #TODO(xuhanp): Remove INACTIVE status and use DOWN to # be consistent with other network resources if status in (const.ACTIVE, const.INACTIVE, const.DOWN): fw_db.status = status return True else: fw_db.status = const.ERROR return False def firewall_deleted(self, context, firewall_id, **kwargs): """Agent uses this to indicate firewall is deleted.""" LOG.debug(_("firewall_deleted() called")) with context.session.begin(subtransactions=True): fw_db = self.plugin._get_firewall(context, firewall_id) # allow to delete firewalls in ERROR state if fw_db.status in (const.PENDING_DELETE, const.ERROR): self.plugin.delete_db_firewall_object(context, firewall_id) return True else: LOG.warn(_('Firewall %(fw)s unexpectedly deleted by agent, ' 'status was %(status)s'), {'fw': firewall_id, 'status': fw_db.status}) fw_db.status = const.ERROR return False def get_firewalls_for_tenant(self, context, **kwargs): """Agent uses this to get all firewalls and rules for a tenant.""" LOG.debug(_("get_firewalls_for_tenant() called")) fw_list = [ self.plugin._make_firewall_dict_with_rules(context, fw['id']) for fw in self.plugin.get_firewalls(context) ] return fw_list def get_firewalls_for_tenant_without_rules(self, context, **kwargs): """Agent uses this to get all firewalls for a tenant.""" LOG.debug(_("get_firewalls_for_tenant_without_rules() called")) fw_list = [fw for fw in self.plugin.get_firewalls(context)] return fw_list def get_tenants_with_firewalls(self, context, **kwargs): """Agent uses this to get all tenants that have firewalls.""" LOG.debug(_("get_tenants_with_firewalls() called")) ctx = neutron_context.get_admin_context() fw_list = self.plugin.get_firewalls(ctx) fw_tenant_list = list(set(fw['tenant_id'] for fw in fw_list)) return fw_tenant_list class FirewallAgentApi(n_rpc.RpcProxy): """Plugin side of plugin to agent RPC API.""" API_VERSION = '1.0' def __init__(self, topic, host): super(FirewallAgentApi, self).__init__(topic, self.API_VERSION) self.host = host # todo: sridar this class needs to be refactored, leaving this # in for ability to do some sanity testing with L3Agent. def create_firewall(self, context, firewall): return self.fanout_cast( context, self.make_msg('create_firewall', firewall=firewall, host=self.host) ) def update_firewall(self, context, firewall): return self.fanout_cast( context, self.make_msg('update_firewall', firewall=firewall, host=self.host) ) def delete_firewall(self, context, firewall): return self.fanout_cast( context, self.make_msg('delete_firewall', firewall=firewall, host=self.host) ) class CSRFirewallPlugin(ref_fw_plugin.FirewallPlugin, csrfw_db.CiscoFirewall_db_mixin): """Implementation of the Neutron Firewall Service Plugin. This class implements the Cisco CSR FWaaS Service Plugin, inherits from the fwaas ref plugin as no changes are made to handling fwaas policy and rules. The CRUD methods are overridden to provide for the specific implementation. The basic fwaas db is managed thru the firewall_db.Firewall_db_mixin. The backend specific associations are captured in the new table, csrfw_db.CiscoFirewall_db_mixin. """ supported_extension_aliases = ["fwaas", "csrfirewall"] def __init__(self): """Do the initialization for the firewall service plugin here.""" basepath = neutron.plugins.__path__[0] ext_paths = [basepath + '/cisco/extensions'] cp = cfg.CONF.api_extensions_path to_add = "" for ext_path in ext_paths: if cp.find(ext_path) == -1: to_add += ':' + ext_path if to_add != "": cfg.CONF.set_override('api_extensions_path', cp + to_add) self.endpoints = [FirewallCallbacks(self)] self.conn = n_rpc.create_connection(new=True) self.conn.create_consumer( topics.FIREWALL_PLUGIN, self.endpoints, fanout=False) self.conn.consume_in_threads() self.agent_rpc = FirewallAgentApi( topics.L3_AGENT, cfg.CONF.host ) def _rpc_update_firewall(self, context, firewall_id): status_update = {"firewall": {"status": const.PENDING_UPDATE}} fw = super(ref_fw_plugin.FirewallPlugin, self).update_firewall( context, firewall_id, status_update) if fw: fw_with_rules = ( self._make_firewall_dict_with_rules(context, firewall_id)) self.agent_rpc.update_firewall(context, fw_with_rules) def create_firewall(self, context, firewall): LOG.debug(_("create_firewall() called")) tenant_id = self._get_tenant_id_for_create(context, firewall['firewall']) # port validation with router plugin l3_plugin = manager.NeutronManager.get_service_plugins().get( const.L3_ROUTER_NAT) routers = l3_plugin.get_routers(context) router_ids = [ router['id'] for router in routers if router['tenant_id'] == tenant_id] port_id = firewall['firewall']['port_id'] port_db = self._core_plugin._get_port(context, port_id) if not (port_db['device_id'] in router_ids and port_db['device_owner'] == l3_const.DEVICE_OWNER_ROUTER_INTF): raise csr_ext.InvalidInterfaceForCSRFW(port_id = port_id) firewall['firewall']['status'] = const.PENDING_CREATE fw = super(ref_fw_plugin.FirewallPlugin, self).create_firewall( context, firewall) fw_with_rules = ( self._make_firewall_dict_with_rules(context, fw['id'])) # Add entry into firewall associations table _fw = {'firewall': {'id': fw['id'], 'port_id': port_id, 'direction': 'both'}} self.add_firewall_csr_association(context, _fw) #todo: sridar update for cfgagent dict with info from router plugin self.agent_rpc.create_firewall(context, fw_with_rules) return fw def update_firewall(self, context, id, firewall): LOG.debug(_("update_firewall() called")) self._ensure_update_firewall(context, id) #todo: sridar add csr db checks firewall['firewall']['status'] = const.PENDING_UPDATE fw = super(ref_fw_plugin.FirewallPlugin, self).update_firewall( context, id, firewall) fw_with_rules = ( self._make_firewall_dict_with_rules(context, fw['id'])) self.agent_rpc.update_firewall(context, fw_with_rules) return fw def delete_firewall(self, context, id): LOG.debug(_("delete_firewall() called")) status_update = {"firewall": {"status": const.PENDING_DELETE}} fw = super(ref_fw_plugin.FirewallPlugin, self).update_firewall( context, id, status_update) fw_with_rules = ( self._make_firewall_dict_with_rules(context, fw['id'])) self.agent_rpc.delete_firewall(context, fw_with_rules)

commit_message:
Introduce driver capabilities

This spec suggests introducing inspectable capabilities for Ironic drivers.

Change-Id: I5d50bde43a26523a199d41e73ddcf3aa4a07e329
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/27/128927/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Introduce Driver Capabilities ========================================== This spec suggests introducing inspectable capabilities for Ironic drivers. Problem description =================== Capabilities are required for at least these use cases: * Adding new variant of deployment. With time we start implementing variants of deployment that are not supported by all drivers. Examples include: * Whole-disk vs partition deployment [1]. * Using configdrive for deployment [2]. * Using ephemeral partitions. Failure to verify that the driver in use actually supports the requested variant will lead to error on the late stage of deployment or even (as with whole-disk) to the wrong deployment. Using capabilities Nova Ironic driver could check that deploy is possible and fail early if it is not, benefitting both performance and user experience. * New vendor passthru methods. As we are introducing more vendor-specific calls, we need some way to find out, if some call is supported by given driver. Driver capabilities would enable 3rd-party tools (like [3]) to inspect support of particular feature by particular driver. Proposed change =============== * Introduce get_capabilities() call to all interfaces, return value being set of strings. * Introduce get_capabilities() call to driver interface, defaulting to union of capabilities of all interfaces. * Publish capabilities as ``/v1/drivers/{name}/capabilities`` REST endpoint. * Inspect existing drivers to get list of capabilities we can already use. References ========== * [1] https://review.openstack.org/97150 * [2] https://review.openstack.org/99235 * [3] https://pypi.python.org/pypi/ironic-discoverd

commit_message:
LBaaS reference implementation driver to support TLS

Including plugin modifications for barbican container retrieval
Including template updates to support TLS and SNI
Including jinja_config updates to support storing of the container details
Including driver updates for data directory locations

Implement blueprint lbaas-ref-impl-tls-support

Change-Id: I47c34e7b8a0558373f3e3262a7c40ff43a367465
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/48/115548/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _store_listener_crt(state_path, loadbalancer_id, container): cert_path = _retrieve_crt_path(state_path, loadbalancer_id, container.id) # build a string that represents the pem file to be saved pem = '{0}{1}{2}'.format( container.certificate, container.private_key, '' if not container.intermediates else container.intermediates) utils.replace_file(cert_path, pem) return cert_path def _retrieve_crt_path(state_path, loadbalancer_id, cont_id): if state_path and loadbalancer_id: conf_dir = _retrieve_data_dir(state_path, loadbalancer_id) if not os.path.isdir(conf_dir): os.makedirs(conf_dir, 0o755) return os.path.join( conf_dir, '{0}.pem'.format(cont_id)) def _retrieve_data_dir(state_path, loadbalancer_id): confs_dir = os.path.abspath(os.path.normpath(state_path)) # since the conig is generated each time a create or update happens # clear the directory of old pem files to ensure no stale # data is left behind. The plugin will handle reg/de-reg of the # the containers. confs_path = os.path.join(confs_dir, loadbalancer_id) for f in os.listdir(confs_path): if f.endswith('.pem'): os.remove(f) return confs_path def render_loadbalancer_obj(loadbalancer, user_group, socket_path, state_path=None): loadbalancer = _transform_loadbalancer(loadbalancer, state_path=state_path)def _transform_loadbalancer(loadbalancer, state_path=None): listeners = [_transform_listener( x, loadbalancer.id, state_path) for x in loadbalancer.listeners]def _transform_listener(listener, loadbalancer_id=None, state_path=None): if listener.default_tls_container_id: ret_value['default_tls_path'] = _store_listener_crt( state_path, loadbalancer_id, listener.default_tls_container) if listener.sni_containers: for c in listener.sni_containers: _store_listener_crt(state_path, loadbalancer_id, c.tls_container) ret_value['crt_dir'] = _retrieve_data_dir(state_path, loadbalancer_id)
deleted_lines: def render_loadbalancer_obj(loadbalancer, user_group, socket_path): loadbalancer = _transform_loadbalancer(loadbalancer)def _transform_loadbalancer(loadbalancer): listeners = [_transform_listener(x) for x in loadbalancer.listeners]def _transform_listener(listener):

subject: l3_db: refactor L3_NAT_dbonly_mixin add/remove_router_interface

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-08-26 06:41:31.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/5c5367e80711adb382dce5b34a418b88102c4134', 'message': 'l3_db: refactor L3_NAT_dbonly_mixin add/remove_router_interface

This patch refactors add/remove_router_interface to allow
override actual port operation.

This patch simplifies vyatta vrouter patch.

commit_message:
l3_db: refactor L3_NAT_dbonly_mixin add/remove_router_interface

This patch refactors add/remove_router_interface to allow
override actual port operation.
l3 plugin for routervm will twist port operation when
add/remove router interface as port creation/deletion will be
done with VM creation/deletion.
This patch simplifies vyatta vrouter patch.

Related to blueprint l3-plugin-brocade-vyatta-vrouter

Change-Id: Iaa69d835436c8f3c0fb70798ebf9c81f7727b0b2

is the target plugin with the port binding modulatirity
necessary to bind these ports.

Using this extension, administrators can define external
attachment strings to keep track of specific physical
ports in networks. These can then be assigned to tenants
who can then assign them to their own networks. An
assignment results in a port creation with the external
attachment identifier populated in the HOST ID field so
the plugin can bind the port to the network segment.

commit_message:
External Attachment Point Extension

This introduces the external attachment point
extension API definition, DB classes, and mixin
class. It also loads the class in ML2 since this
is the target plugin with the port binding modulatirity
necessary to bind these ports.

Using this extension, administrators can define external
attachment strings to keep track of specific physical
ports in networks. These can then be assigned to tenants
who can then assign them to their own networks. An
assignment results in a port creation with the external
attachment identifier populated in the HOST ID field so
the plugin can bind the port to the network segment.

DocImpact

Implements: blueprint neutron-external-attachment-points
Change-Id: I51cc1c852f45d5f443ee0c0d1d1c6304a6d55992

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. # @author: Kanzhe Jiang, Big Switch Networks # @author: Kevin Benton, Big Switch Networks import abc import six from neutron.api import extensions from neutron.api.v2 import attributes as attr from neutron.api.v2 import base from neutron.common import exceptions from neutron import manager from neutron.openstack.common import log as logging LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) class ExternalAttachmentPointNotFound(exceptions.NotFound): message = _("External attachment point %(id)s does not exist") class DuplicateExternalAttachmentPoint(exceptions.InUse): message = _("External attachment point with the same identifier already " "exists, %(id)s") class ExternalAttachmentPointAssigned(exceptions.InUse): message = _("External attachment point %(id)s is currently assigned to " "network %(net_id)s") class ExternalAttachmentPointInUse(exceptions.InUse): message = _("External attachment point %(id)s currently has the following " "ports assigned to it: %(port_ids)s") class InvalidAttachmentFormat(exceptions.BadRequest): message = _("The attachment identifier is invalid for attachment type " "%(type)s: %(reason)s") class InvalidAttachmentType(exceptions.BadRequest): message = _("The attachment type '%(type)s' is not supported") class ExternalPortNotFound(exceptions.NotFound): message = _("External port %(id)s does not exist") RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTE_MAP = { 'external_attachment_points': { 'id': {'allow_post': False, 'allow_put': False, 'enforce_policy': True, 'validate': {'type:uuid': None}, 'is_visible': True, 'primary_key': True}, 'tenant_id': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'required_by_policy': True, 'is_visible': True}, 'name': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'enforce_policy': True, 'validate': {'type:string': None}, 'is_visible': True, 'default': ''}, 'description': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'enforce_policy': True, 'validate': {'type:string': None}, 'is_visible': True, 'default': ''}, 'attachment_id': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': False, 'enforce_policy': True, 'default': False, 'validate': {'type:dict': None}, 'is_visible': True, 'required_by_policy': True}, 'attachment_type': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': False, 'enforce_policy': True, 'default': False, 'validate': {'type:string': None}, 'is_visible': True, 'required_by_policy': True}, 'network_id': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'required_by_policy': True, 'is_visible': True}, 'status': {'allow_post': False, 'allow_put': False, 'required_by_policy': False, 'is_visible': True}, 'status_description': {'allow_post': False, 'allow_put': False, 'required_by_policy': False, 'is_visible': True}, }, 'external_ports': { 'id': {'allow_post': False, 'allow_put': False, 'enforce_policy': True, 'validate': {'type:uuid': None}, 'is_visible': True, 'primary_key': True}, 'external_attachment_id': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'required_by_policy': True, 'is_visible': True}, 'port_id': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'enforce_policy': True, 'validate': {'type:uuid_or_none': None}, 'is_visible': True, 'default': None}, 'name': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'enforce_policy': True, 'validate': {'type:string': None}, 'is_visible': True, 'default': ''}, 'description': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'enforce_policy': True, 'validate': {'type:string': None}, 'is_visible': True, 'default': ''}, 'mac_address': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'enforce_policy': True, 'validate': {'type:mac_address': None}, 'required_by_policy': True, 'is_visible': True}, } } EXTENDED_ATTRIBUTES_2_0 = { 'ports': { 'external_attachment_id': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'is_visible': True, 'default': None, 'validate': {'type:uuid': None}}, } } class ExternalAttachmentPoint(extensions.ExtensionDescriptor): @classmethod def get_name(cls): return "Neutron External Attachment Point" @classmethod def get_alias(cls): return "external-attachment-points" @classmethod def get_description(cls): return ("Provides an object to reference points in a network that " "need to be added to a Neutron network") @classmethod def get_namespace(cls): return ("http://wiki.openstack.org/neutron/" "externalattachmentpoints/API_1.0") @classmethod def get_updated(cls): return "2014-05-25:00:00-00:00" @classmethod def get_resources(cls): my_plurals = [(key, key[:-1]) for key in RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTE_MAP.keys()] attr.PLURALS.update(dict(my_plurals)) exts = [] plugin = manager.NeutronManager.get_plugin() for resource_name in ['external_attachment_point', 'external_port']: collection_name = resource_name.replace('_', '-') + "s" params = RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTE_MAP.get(resource_name + "s", dict()) controller = base.create_resource( collection_name, resource_name, plugin, params, allow_bulk=True, allow_pagination=True, allow_sorting=True) ex = extensions.ResourceExtension(collection_name, controller, attr_map=params) exts.append(ex) return exts def get_extended_resources(self, version): if version == "2.0": attr.PLURALS.update({'external_attachment_points': 'external-attachment-point'}) return dict(EXTENDED_ATTRIBUTES_2_0.items() + RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTE_MAP.items()) else: return {} @six.add_metaclass(abc.ABCMeta) class ExternalAttachmentBase(object): @abc.abstractmethod def create_external_attachment_point(self, context, attachment_point): pass @abs.abstractmethod def update_external_attachment_point(self, context, id, attachment_point): pass @abs.abstractmethod def delete_external_attachment_point(self, context, id): pass @abs.abstractmethod def get_external_attachment_point(self, context, id, fields=None): pass @abs.abstractmethod def get_external_attachment_points(self, context, filters=None, fields=None, sorts=None, limit=None, marker=None, page_reverse=False): pass @abs.abstractmethod def create_external_port(self, context, external_port): pass @abs.abstractmethod def update_external_port(self, context, id, external_port): pass @abs.abstractmethod def delete_external_port(self, context, id): pass @abs.abstractmethod def get_external_port(self, context, id, fields=None): pass @abs.abstractmethod def get_external_ports(self, context, filters=None, fields=None, sorts=None, limit=None, marker=None, page_reverse=False): pass

commit_message:
BSN Plugin: external attachment support

Adds a Big Switch external attachment driver and support for
the external attachment point mixin to the Big Switch Plugin.
This allows arbitrary ports in the Big Switch fabric to be
connected to a Neutron network.

Implements: blueprint bsn-external-attachment
Change-Id: I2332f1af4af183dcd2cde4730385a8eece7c156b

commit_message:
Fix the incorrect logic of _modify_rules()

Do not need to do 'rules_index -= 1', if one rule entry is removed
from new_filter. Need to do 'rules_index -= 1', if one chain entry
is removed from new_filter, because chain is above the rule.
Add one unit test for _modify_rules(), so that we will not make it
wrong in the future.

Change-Id: I00a1987d8ec6c1018bbc0e70e60dafbb13a0bd73
Closes-Bug: 1359072

deleted_lines: new_filter = [s for s in new_filter if chain_str not in s.strip()] # backup one index so we write the array correctly if not old: rules_index -= 1
