added_lines: # Copyright 2012 Big Switch Networks, Inc. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. # # @author: mayu, Huawei tech, Inc. """ A client for Huawei sdn controller. """ import base64 import httplib import json import socket from oslo.config import cfg from neutron.common import exceptions from neutron.common import utils from neutron.openstack.common import log as logging LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) restproxy_opts = [ cfg.StrOpt('servers', default='localhost:8800', help=_("A comma separated server and port number ")), cfg.StrOpt('server_auth', default='username:password', secret=True, help=_("The username and password for authenticating " "against the Huawei sdn controller.")), cfg.BoolOpt('server_ssl', default=False, help=_("If True, Use SSL when connecting to the " "Huawei sdn controller ")), cfg.BoolOpt('sync_data', default=False, help=_("Sync data on connection")), cfg.IntOpt('server_timeout', default=10, help=_("Maximum number of seconds to wait for" " proxy request to connect and complete.")), ] cfg.CONF.register_opts(restproxy_opts, "RESTCLIENT") # The following are used to invoke the API on the external controller NET_RESOURCE_PATH = "/tenants/%s/networks" PORT_RESOURCE_PATH = "/tenants/%s/networks/%s/ports" ROUTER_RESOURCE_PATH = "/tenants/%s/routers" ROUTER_INTF_OP_PATH = "/tenants/%s/routers/%s/interfaces" NETWORKS_PATH = "/tenants/%s/networks/%s" PORTS_PATH = "/tenants/%s/networks/%s/ports/%s" ATTACHMENT_PATH = "/tenants/%s/networks/%s/ports/%s/attachment" ROUTERS_PATH = "/tenants/%s/routers/%s" ROUTER_INTF_PATH = "/tenants/%s/routers/%s/interfaces/%s" SUCCESS_CODES = range(200, 207) FAILURE_CODES = [0, 301, 302, 303, 400, 401, 403, 404, 500, 501, 502, 503, 504, 505] SYNTAX_ERROR_MESSAGE = _('Syntax error in server config file, aborting plugin') BASE_URI = '/networkService/v1.1' ORCHESTRATION_SERVICE_ID = 'Neutron v2.0' METADATA_SERVER_IP = '169.254.169.254' class RemoteRestError(exceptions.NeutronException): def __init__(self, message): if message is None: message = "None" self.message = _("Error in REST call to remote network " "controller") + ": " + message super(RemoteRestError, self).__init__() class ServerProxy(object): """REST server proxy to a network controller.""" def __init__(self, server, port, ssl, auth, neutron_id, timeout, base_uri, name): self.server = server self.port = port self.ssl = ssl self.base_uri = base_uri self.timeout = timeout self.name = name self.success_codes = SUCCESS_CODES self.auth = None self.neutron_id = neutron_id self.failed = False if auth: self.auth = 'Basic ' + base64.encodestring(auth).strip() def rest_call(self, action, resource, data, headers): uri = self.base_uri + resource body = json.dumps(data) if not headers: headers = {} headers['Content-type'] = 'application/json' headers['Accept'] = 'application/json' headers['NeutronProxy-Agent'] = self.name headers['Instance-ID'] = self.neutron_id headers['Orchestration-Service-ID'] = ORCHESTRATION_SERVICE_ID if self.auth: headers['Authorization'] = self.auth LOG.debug(_("ServerProxy: server=%(server)s, port=%(port)d, " "ssl=%(ssl)r, action=%(action)s"), {'server': self.server, 'port': self.port, 'ssl': self.ssl, 'action': action}) LOG.debug(_("ServerProxy: resource=%(resource)s, data=%(data)r, " "headers=%(headers)r"), {'resource': resource, 'data': data, 'headers': headers}) conn = None if self.ssl: conn = httplib.HTTPSConnection( self.server, self.port, timeout=self.timeout) if conn is None: LOG.error(_('ServerProxy: Could not establish HTTPS ' 'connection')) return 0, None, None, None else: conn = httplib.HTTPConnection( self.server, self.port, timeout=self.timeout) if conn is None: LOG.error(_('ServerProxy: Could not establish HTTP ' 'connection')) return 0, None, None, None try: conn.request(action, uri, body, headers) response = conn.getresponse() respstr = response.read() respdata = respstr if response.status in self.success_codes: try: respdata = json.loads(respstr) except ValueError: # response was not JSON, ignore the exception pass ret = (response.status, response.reason, respstr, respdata) except (socket.timeout, socket.error) as e: LOG.error(_('ServerProxy: %(action)s failure, %(e)r'), {'action': action, 'e': e}) ret = 0, None, None, None conn.close() LOG.debug(_("ServerProxy: status=%(status)d, reason=%(reason)r, " "ret=%(ret)s, data=%(data)r"), {'status': ret[0], 'reason': ret[1], 'ret': ret[2], 'data': ret[3]}) return ret class SdnClient(object): def __init__(self, server, port, ssl=None, auth=None, neutron_id=None, timeout=10, base_uri=BASE_URI, name='NeutronRestProxy'): self.base_uri = base_uri self.timeout = timeout self.name = name self.auth = auth self.ssl = ssl self.neutron_id = neutron_id self.servers = [] self.servers.append(self.server_proxy_for(server, port)) def server_proxy_for(self, server, port): return ServerProxy(server, port, self.ssl, self.auth, self.neutron_id, self.timeout, self.base_uri, self.name) def server_failure(self, resp, ignore_codes=[]): """Define failure codes as required. Note: We assume 301-303 is a failure, and try the next server in the server pool. """ return (resp[0] in FAILURE_CODES and resp[0] not in ignore_codes) def action_success(self, resp): """Defining success codes as required. Note: We assume any valid 2xx as being successful response. """ return resp[0] in SUCCESS_CODES @utils.synchronized('bsn-rest-call', external=True) def rest_call(self, action, resource, data, headers, ignore_codes): good_first = sorted(self.servers, key=lambda x: x.failed) for active_server in good_first: ret = active_server.rest_call(action, resource, data, headers) if not self.server_failure(ret, ignore_codes): active_server.failed = False return ret else: LOG.error(_('ServerProxy: %(action)s failure for servers: ' '%(server)r Response: %(response)s'), {'action': action, 'server': (active_server.server, active_server.port), 'response': ret[3]}) LOG.error(_("ServerProxy: Error details: status=%(status)d, " "reason=%(reason)r, ret=%(ret)s, data=%(data)r"), {'status': ret[0], 'reason': ret[1], 'ret': ret[2], 'data': ret[3]}) active_server.failed = True # All servers failed, reset server list and try again next time LOG.error(_('ServerProxy: %(action)s failure for all servers: ' '%(server)r'), {'action': action, 'server': tuple((s.server, s.port) for s in self.servers)}) return (0, None, None, None) def rest_action(self, action, resource, data='', errstr='%s', ignore_codes=[], headers=None): """ Wrapper for rest_call that verifies success and raises a RemoteRestError on failure with a provided error string By default, 404 errors on DELETE calls are ignored because they already do not exist on the backend. """ if not ignore_codes and action == 'DELETE': ignore_codes = [404] resp = self.rest_call(action, resource, data, headers, ignore_codes) if self.server_failure(resp, ignore_codes): LOG.error(_("NeutronRestProxyV2: ") + errstr, resp[2]) raise RemoteRestError(resp[2]) if resp[0] in ignore_codes: LOG.warning(_("NeutronRestProxyV2: Received and ignored error " "code %(code)s on %(action)s action to resource " "%(resource)s"), {'code': resp[2], 'action': action, 'resource': resource}) return resp def rest_create_network(self, tenant_id, network): resource = NET_RESOURCE_PATH % tenant_id data = {"network": network} errstr = _("Unable to create remote network: %s") self.rest_action('POST', resource, data, errstr) def rest_update_network(self, tenant_id, net_id, network): resource = NETWORKS_PATH % (tenant_id, net_id) data = {"network": network} errstr = _("Unable to update remote network: %s") self.rest_action('PUT', resource, data, errstr) def rest_delete_network(self, tenant_id, net_id): resource = NETWORKS_PATH % (tenant_id, net_id) errstr = _("Unable to update remote network: %s") self.rest_action('DELETE', resource, errstr) def rest_create_port(self, net, port): resource = PORT_RESOURCE_PATH % (net["tenant_id"], net["id"]) data = {"port": port} errstr = _("Unable to create remote port: %s") self.rest_action('POST', resource, data, errstr) def rest_update_port(self, tenant_id, network_id, port, port_id): resource = PORTS_PATH % (tenant_id, network_id, port_id) data = {"port": port} errstr = _("Unable to update remote port: %s") self.rest_action('PUT', resource, data, errstr) def rest_delete_port(self, tenant_id, network_id, port_id): resource = PORTS_PATH % (tenant_id, network_id, port_id) errstr = _("Unable to delete remote port: %s") self.rest_action('DELETE', resource, errstr) def rest_plug_interface(self, tenant_id, net_id, port, remote_interface_id): if port["mac_address"] is not None: resource = ATTACHMENT_PATH % (tenant_id, net_id, port["id"]) data = {"attachment": { "id": remote_interface_id, "mac": port["mac_address"] } } errstr = _("Unable to plug in interface: %s") self.rest_action('PUT', resource, data, errstr) def rest_unplug_interface(self, tenant_id, net_id, port_id): resource = ATTACHMENT_PATH % (tenant_id, net_id, port_id) errstr = _("Unable to unplug interface: %s") self.rest_action('DELETE', resource, errstr)

_kill may be called by `_handle_process_error` or `stop` from outside,

commit_message:
Fix ovs agent fails to kill ovsdb monitor properly

_kill may be called by `_handle_process_error` or `stop` from outside,
if it is called more than once, following exception will occur:

AssertionError: Trying to re-send() an already-triggered event.

kill_event can't be re-used even if it is respawning, the patch
introduce a respawning state to indicate the process is respawning.

Change-Id: Id584b4444f5b65f0d532ccb930f70a08e5419c06
Closes-bug: #1350903
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/54/114154/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if not self._kill_event.ready(): self._kill_event.send()
deleted_lines: self._kill_event.send()

subject: Fixes port deletion failure if port missing in NVP
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-08-25 15:05:22.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/dddef90fba02a532808a145244b7914280522734', 'message': 'Fixes port deletion failure if port missing in NVP

The issue here is that port deletion fails if the
port being deleted does not existing in the NSX
database. This does not necessarily mean that the
port does not exist entirely. Therefore, this fix
wraps the NSX port deletion around a try block that
ignores any failure. The port deletion fails only
if the port does not exist in the neutron database
as well.

Change-Id: Iaf3ff43b63bc321e29c86e6ce4704a5b2780ff16
Closes-Bug: 1293723

commit_message:
Fixes port deletion failure if port missing in NVP

The issue here is that port deletion fails if the
port being deleted does not existing in the NSX
database. This does not necessarily mean that the
port does not exist entirely. Therefore, this fix
wraps the NSX port deletion around a try block that
ignores any failure. The port deletion fails only
if the port does not exist in the neutron database
as well.

Change-Id: Iaf3ff43b63bc321e29c86e6ce4704a5b2780ff16
Closes-Bug: 1293723
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/40/116640/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: try: port_delete_func(context, neutron_db_port) except Exception as e: # This implies that the port does not exist in the NSX database. # we can now proceed to try deleting it from Neutron's database. LOG.debug(("Port %s does not exist on the NSX config." %(id)))
deleted_lines: port_delete_func(context, neutron_db_port)

When load balancer/proxy return 504, client raises ValueError.
This happen when response is not a JSON object.
ValueError Exception is needed to be handled.

Change-Id: Iaa8d577f99137327f6e7ad9c7c6abc350f4cc938
Closes-Bug: #1358889
'}]
commit_message:
Handling exception on 504 Error

When load balancer/proxy return 504, client raises ValueError.
This happen when response is not a JSON object.
ValueError Exception is needed to be handled.

Change-Id: Iaa8d577f99137327f6e7ad9c7c6abc350f4cc938
Closes-Bug: #1358889
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-zaqarclient refs/changes/16/136816/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: try: if not self._deserialized and self.content: self._deserialized = json.loads(self.content) return self._deserialized except ValueError as ex: print("Response is not a JSON object.", ex) return None
deleted_lines: if not self._deserialized and self.content: self._deserialized = json.loads(self.content) return self._deserialized

subject: Add service group as a firewall customized service
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-07-11 05:41:28.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/ab2e2ac4e334aeb0cd8826113bd402706fb540bc', 'message': "Implements: blueprint fwaas-customized-service for customized service

-In FWaaS, administrator can use port range and protocol inside firewall rules
to define traffic type. But we don't have a flexible way to allow user to specify more
than one type of traffic in the same rule.To support different traffic type, with the
same source, destination address and action, different rules need to be created.
This makes the process of defining firewall rules un-scalable.
two resources are added to the db one is called service group(class ServiceGroup)
and one is called service object(class ServiceObject)
class ServiceGroupDbMixin is mixin class to add service group to db plugin base,
service group id is added to class firewall rule and the corresponding dict
reference implementation support is not yet complete and will be fully done in next patch.
the agent queries the service group content from plugin	and expend the firewal rule
based on thecontent of the service group into the iptable rules.
Administrator can use service object to define a special type of traffic. The service
objects is grouped into service group that can be referenced from other openstack
modules (eg. firewall rule). Firewall rule has a foreign key to service group.
Each service object can be defined with a timeout value that can be used to overwrite
default session idle timeout value.

Change-Id: If699bfd90f2a8d80ac93c51220707c856e94f8db

"}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2014-07-24 01:42:46.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/b08090839705ab3e6ad540fef12adbd3f236963e', 'message': 'Add service group as a firewall customized service

This patch introduces the model and extension framework
for implementing service group as a firewall customized service.

Two resources service_group and service_object are added,
multiple service group and service objects can be configured to
allow flexibility and grouping of traffic, service group consists of
multiple service objects, admin can create multiple service groups to
provide more flexibility to tenants for using them without
disturbing other tenants.
due to many to many relationship between service groups and
service objects, to associate them an association table is introduced,
currently only service object config is the way to associate to service
group
The service objects are grouped into service group that can be referenced
from other openstack modules (eg. firewall rule, securitygroup etc).
currently firewall rule has multiple service groups to allow the
user flexibilty to define their own groups and use them without impacting
the other users. due to many to many relationship between service groups and
firewall rules exists an association table is introduced,
Each service object can be defined with a timeout value that can be used
to overwrite default session idle timeout value.

Implements: blueprint fwaas-customized-service for customized service

Change-Id: If699bfd90f2a8d80ac93c51220707c856e94f8db
Authored-by: badveli vishnuvardhan <badveli_vishnuus@yahoo.com>

from other openstack modules (eg. firewall rule, securitygroup etc).
currently firewall rule has multiple service groups to allow the
user flexibilty to define their own groups and use them without impacting
the other users. due to many to many relationship between service groups and
firewall rules exists an association table is introduced,
Each service object can be defined with a timeout value that can be used
to overwrite default session idle timeout value.

Implements: blueprint fwaas-customized-service for customized service

Change-Id: If699bfd90f2a8d80ac93c51220707c856e94f8db
Authored-by: badveli vishnuvardhan <badveli_vishnuus@yahoo.com>

commit_message:
Add service group as a firewall customized service

This patch introduces the model and extension framework
for implementing service group as a firewall customized service.
Two resources service_group and service_object are added,
currently firewall rule can refer multiple service groups to allow the
user flexibilty to define their own groups and use them without impacting
the other users.
Each service object can be defined with a timeout value that can be used
to overwrite default session idle timeout value.
More info can be found at service group wiki
https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Neutron/FWaaS/FWaaS-ServiceGroup
Implements: blueprint fwaas-customized-service for customized service
Change-Id: If699bfd90f2a8d80ac93c51220707c856e94f8db
Authored-by: badveli vishnuvardhan <badveli_vishnuus@yahoo.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/74/106274/20 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: SERVICE_GROUP_ID = None 'service_group_id': SERVICE_GROUP_ID, service_group_id, 'service_group_id': service_group_id, shared=SHARED, protocol=PROTOCOL, service_group_id = None, ip_version=IP_VERSION, service_group_id,
deleted_lines: shared=SHARED, protocol=PROTOCOL, ip_version=IP_VERSION,

commit_message:
Cleanup Big Switch code

Re-organize the Big Switch code and refactor some shared
methods between the ML2 driver and the core plugin.

Implements: blueprint bsn-module-cleanup
Change-Id: I53de4924fa2e3b9883af9403e4b551399074896d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/90/116190/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

revisions:

   This driver provides the ability to provivion vxlan network for
   openstack networking through Huawei SDN controller. The driver
   proxy neutron request to Huawei SDN controller, then a response
   will be sent back to ml2 plugin after dedicated process. Both function
   code and unit code are included.

commit_message:
Implement bp/huawei-ml2-mechanism-driver

This driver proxy neutron request to huawei sdn controller
which can provide vxlan network provision. Huawei controller
can communicate with ovs based on openflow protocal, flow
table route info which can conduct vm traffic will be posted.

Implements: blueprint huawei-ml2-mechanism-driver
Change-Id: I6a4b59ab3bf5cc5a73cbb407f0cc4604407bc8f3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/48/68148/15 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2012 Big Switch Networks, Inc. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. # # @author: mayu, Huawei tech, Inc. """ A client for Huawei sdn controller. """ import base64 import httplib import json import socket from oslo.config import cfg from neutron.common import exceptions, utils from neutron.openstack.common import log as logging LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) restproxy_opts = [ cfg.StrOpt('servers', default='localhost:8800', help=_("A comma separated server and port number ")), cfg.StrOpt('server_auth', default='username:password', secret=True, help=_("The username and password for authenticating " "against the Huawei sdn controller.")), cfg.BoolOpt('server_ssl', default=False, help=_("If True, Use SSL when connecting to the " "Huawei sdn controller ")), cfg.BoolOpt('sync_data', default=False, help=_("Sync data on connection")), cfg.IntOpt('server_timeout', default=10, help=_("Maximum number of seconds to wait for" " proxy request to connect and complete.")), ] cfg.CONF.register_opts(restproxy_opts, "RESTCLIENT") # The following are used to invoke the API on the external controller NET_RESOURCE_PATH = "/tenants/%s/networks" PORT_RESOURCE_PATH = "/tenants/%s/networks/%s/ports" ROUTER_RESOURCE_PATH = "/tenants/%s/routers" ROUTER_INTF_OP_PATH = "/tenants/%s/routers/%s/interfaces" NETWORKS_PATH = "/tenants/%s/networks/%s" PORTS_PATH = "/tenants/%s/networks/%s/ports/%s" ATTACHMENT_PATH = "/tenants/%s/networks/%s/ports/%s/attachment" ROUTERS_PATH = "/tenants/%s/routers/%s" ROUTER_INTF_PATH = "/tenants/%s/routers/%s/interfaces/%s" SUCCESS_CODES = range(200, 207) FAILURE_CODES = [0, 301, 302, 303, 400, 401, 403, 404, 500, 501, 502, 503, 504, 505] SYNTAX_ERROR_MESSAGE = _('Syntax error in server config file, aborting plugin') BASE_URI = '/networkService/v1.1' ORCHESTRATION_SERVICE_ID = 'Neutron v2.0' METADATA_SERVER_IP = '169.254.169.254' class RemoteRestError(exceptions.NeutronException): def __init__(self, message): if message is None: message = "None" self.message = _("Error in REST call to remote network " "controller") + ": " + message super(RemoteRestError, self).__init__() class ServerProxy(object): """REST server proxy to a network controller.""" def __init__(self, server, port, ssl, auth, neutron_id, timeout, base_uri, name): self.server = server self.port = port self.ssl = ssl self.base_uri = base_uri self.timeout = timeout self.name = name self.success_codes = SUCCESS_CODES self.auth = None self.neutron_id = neutron_id self.failed = False if auth: self.auth = 'Basic ' + base64.encodestring(auth).strip() def rest_call(self, action, resource, data, headers): uri = self.base_uri + resource body = json.dumps(data) if not headers: headers = {} headers['Content-type'] = 'application/json' headers['Accept'] = 'application/json' headers['NeutronProxy-Agent'] = self.name headers['Instance-ID'] = self.neutron_id headers['Orchestration-Service-ID'] = ORCHESTRATION_SERVICE_ID if self.auth: headers['Authorization'] = self.auth LOG.debug(_("ServerProxy: server=%(server)s, port=%(port)d, " "ssl=%(ssl)r, action=%(action)s"), {'server': self.server, 'port': self.port, 'ssl': self.ssl, 'action': action}) LOG.debug(_("ServerProxy: resource=%(resource)s, data=%(data)r, " "headers=%(headers)r"), {'resource': resource, 'data': data, 'headers': headers}) conn = None if self.ssl: conn = httplib.HTTPSConnection( self.server, self.port, timeout=self.timeout) if conn is None: LOG.error(_('ServerProxy: Could not establish HTTPS ' 'connection')) return 0, None, None, None else: conn = httplib.HTTPConnection( self.server, self.port, timeout=self.timeout) if conn is None: LOG.error(_('ServerProxy: Could not establish HTTP ' 'connection')) return 0, None, None, None try: conn.request(action, uri, body, headers) response = conn.getresponse() respstr = response.read() respdata = respstr if response.status in self.success_codes: try: respdata = json.loads(respstr) except ValueError: # response was not JSON, ignore the exception pass ret = (response.status, response.reason, respstr, respdata) except (socket.timeout, socket.error) as e: LOG.error(_('ServerProxy: %(action)s failure, %(e)r'), {'action': action, 'e': e}) ret = 0, None, None, None conn.close() LOG.debug(_("ServerProxy: status=%(status)d, reason=%(reason)r, " "ret=%(ret)s, data=%(data)r"), {'status': ret[0], 'reason': ret[1], 'ret': ret[2], 'data': ret[3]}) return ret class SdnClient(object): def __init__(self, server, port, ssl=None, auth=None, neutron_id=None, timeout=10, base_uri='/networkService/v1.1', name='NeutronRestProxy'): self.base_uri = base_uri self.timeout = timeout self.name = name self.auth = auth self.ssl = ssl self.neutron_id = neutron_id self.servers = [] self.servers.append(self.server_proxy_for(server, port)) def server_proxy_for(self, server, port): return ServerProxy(server, port, self.ssl, self.auth, self.neutron_id, self.timeout, self.base_uri, self.name) def server_failure(self, resp, ignore_codes=[]): """Define failure codes as required. Note: We assume 301-303 is a failure, and try the next server in the server pool. """ return (resp[0] in FAILURE_CODES and resp[0] not in ignore_codes) def action_success(self, resp): """Defining success codes as required. Note: We assume any valid 2xx as being successful response. """ return resp[0] in SUCCESS_CODES @utils.synchronized('bsn-rest-call', external=True) def rest_call(self, action, resource, data, headers, ignore_codes): good_first = sorted(self.servers, key=lambda x: x.failed) for active_server in good_first: ret = active_server.rest_call(action, resource, data, headers) if not self.server_failure(ret, ignore_codes): active_server.failed = False return ret else: LOG.error(_('ServerProxy: %(action)s failure for servers: ' '%(server)r Response: %(response)s'), {'action': action, 'server': (active_server.server, active_server.port), 'response': ret[3]}) LOG.error(_("ServerProxy: Error details: status=%(status)d, " "reason=%(reason)r, ret=%(ret)s, data=%(data)r"), {'status': ret[0], 'reason': ret[1], 'ret': ret[2], 'data': ret[3]}) active_server.failed = True # All servers failed, reset server list and try again next time LOG.error(_('ServerProxy: %(action)s failure for all servers: ' '%(server)r'), {'action': action, 'server': tuple((s.server, s.port) for s in self.servers)}) return (0, None, None, None) def rest_action(self, action, resource, data='', errstr='%s', ignore_codes=[], headers=None): """ Wrapper for rest_call that verifies success and raises a RemoteRestError on failure with a provided error string By default, 404 errors on DELETE calls are ignored because they already do not exist on the backend. """ if not ignore_codes and action == 'DELETE': ignore_codes = [404] resp = self.rest_call(action, resource, data, headers, ignore_codes) if self.server_failure(resp, ignore_codes): LOG.error(_("NeutronRestProxyV2: ") + errstr, resp[2]) raise RemoteRestError(resp[2]) if resp[0] in ignore_codes: LOG.warning(_("NeutronRestProxyV2: Received and ignored error " "code %(code)s on %(action)s action to resource " "%(resource)s"), {'code': resp[2], 'action': action, 'resource': resource}) return resp def rest_create_network(self, tenant_id, network): resource = NET_RESOURCE_PATH % tenant_id data = {"network": network} errstr = _("Unable to create remote network: %s") self.rest_action('POST', resource, data, errstr) def rest_update_network(self, tenant_id, net_id, network): resource = NETWORKS_PATH % (tenant_id, net_id) data = {"network": network} errstr = _("Unable to update remote network: %s") self.rest_action('PUT', resource, data, errstr) def rest_delete_network(self, tenant_id, net_id): resource = NETWORKS_PATH % (tenant_id, net_id) errstr = _("Unable to update remote network: %s") self.rest_action('DELETE', resource, errstr) def rest_create_port(self, net, port): resource = PORT_RESOURCE_PATH % (net["tenant_id"], net["id"]) data = {"port": port} errstr = _("Unable to create remote port: %s") self.rest_action('POST', resource, data, errstr) def rest_update_port(self, tenant_id, network_id, port, port_id): resource = PORTS_PATH % (tenant_id, network_id, port_id) data = {"port": port} errstr = _("Unable to update remote port: %s") self.rest_action('PUT', resource, data, errstr) def rest_delete_port(self, tenant_id, network_id, port_id): resource = PORTS_PATH % (tenant_id, network_id, port_id) errstr = _("Unable to delete remote port: %s") self.rest_action('DELETE', resource, errstr) def rest_plug_interface(self, tenant_id, net_id, port, remote_interface_id): if port["mac_address"] is not None: resource = ATTACHMENT_PATH % (tenant_id, net_id, port["id"]) data = {"attachment": { "id": remote_interface_id, "mac": port["mac_address"] } } errstr = _("Unable to plug in interface: %s") self.rest_action('PUT', resource, data, errstr) def rest_unplug_interface(self, tenant_id, net_id, port_id): resource = ATTACHMENT_PATH % (tenant_id, net_id, port_id) errstr = _("Unable to unplug interface: %s") self.rest_action('DELETE', resource, errstr)

commit_message:
Implement Midonet Juno Port Api calls

This patch is part of a series of patches converting the current midonet plugin
code to the new model described in blueprint midonet-plugin-juno. This patch
focuses specifically on the "port" handlers.

Partially-Implements: blueprint midonet-plugin-juno
Signed-off-by: Joe Mills <joe@midokura.com>

Change-Id: I3e5a87385d9e3f77d9f420a60338db224ce72964

commit_message:
Give floating IPs their own veth device

This way, floating IPs have their own MAC address, and additional
services or safeties can be applied to them. (think tcpdump) To
enable this feature, set floatingip_dedicated_device to True in
l3_agent.ini.

THIS IS A WORK IN PROGRESS

blueprint floatingip-dedicated-veth

Change-Id: I1914d9afdebfe71653cf958459fbfcd43c57bf8a

added_lines: FLOATINGIP_DEV_PREFIX = 'fi-' FLOATINGIP_TAP_DEV_PREFIX = 'ft-' cfg.StrOpt('floatingip_dedicated_device', default=False, help=_('Use a dedicated device for floating IPs, instead ' 'of the router\'s gateway interface')), stale_devs = current_internal_devs - (current_port_devs) ip_wrapper = ip_lib.IPWrapper(self.root_helper, namespace=ri.ns_name) # Clean up dedicated devices that no longer belong in the namespace floating_ips = ri.router.get(l3_constants.FLOATINGIP_KEY, []) dedicated_devices = set(self.get_floatingip_device_name(fip['id']) for fip in floating_ips) floating_ip_devices = set(d.name for d in ip_wrapper.get_devices() if d.name.startswith(FLOATINGIP_DEV_PREFIX)) for stale_dev in floating_ip_devices - commit_message:
Adds FWaaS driver for Cisco CSR1kv

Support for Cisco CSR1kv Firewall:
Add Cisco config agent service helper for firewall.
Add Cisco CSR1kv REST client.
Add Cisco CSR1kv firewall driver.

Change-Id: I6c8e2ac0ee48be69ab483ebe024313776204504f
Implements: blueprint fwaas-cisco

You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. # # @author: Hareesh Puthalath, Cisco Systems, Inc. import abc import Queue import six import threading from neutron.common import rpc as n_rpc from neutron.openstack.common import log as logging LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) @six.add_metaclass(abc.ABCMeta) class ServiceHelperBase(object): def __init__(self): self._observers = [] def register(self, observer): LOG.debug(_("Attaching observer: %(ob)s to subject: %(sub)s"), {'ob': observer.__class__.__name__, 'sub': self.__class__.__name__}) if observer not in self._observers: self._observers.append(observer) else: raise ValueError(_("Observer: %(ob)s is already registered to " "subject: %(sub)s"), {'ob': observer.__class__.__name__, 'sub': self.__class__.__name__}) def unregister(self, observer): LOG.debug(_("Dettaching observer: %(ob)s to subject: %(sub)s"), {'ob': observer.__class__.__name__, 'sub': self.__class__.__name__}) if observer in self._observers: self._observers.remove(observer) else: raise ValueError(_("Observer: %(ob)s is not attached to " "subject: %(sub)s"), {'ob': observer.__class__.__name__, 'sub': self.__class__.__name__}) def notify(self, resource, **kwargs): """Calls all observers attached to th given subject.""" LOG.debug(_("Notifying all observers of this subject")) for observer in self._observers: LOG.debug(_("Notifying observer: %s"), observer.__class__.__name__) observer.update(resource, **kwargs) def update(self, resource, **kwargs): LOG.debug(_("Update received")) def create_rpc_dispatcher(self): """Get the rpc dispatcher for this service.""" return n_rpc.PluginRpcDispatcher([self]) @abc.abstractmethod def process_service(self, *args, **kwargs): raise NotImplementedError class QueueMixin(object): def __init__(self): super(QueueMixin, self).__init__() self._queues = {} self._lock = threading.RLock() def enqueue(self, qname, data): if qname not in self._queues: self._queues[qname] = Queue.Queue() with self._lock: queue = self._queues[qname] queue.put(data) def dequeue(self, qname): if qname not in self._queues: raise ValueError(_("queue %s is not defined"), qname) with self._lock: try: return self._queues[qname].get(block=False) except Queue.Empty: return None def qsize(self, qname): """Return the approximate size of the queue.""" if qname in self._queues: return self._queues[qname].qsize()

commit_message:
Fix ARP cache poisoning vulnerability

ARP cache poisoning is not actually prevented by the firewall
driver 'iptables_firewall'. We are using the ebtables manager
in order to create Ethernet frame filtering rules, which prevent
the sending of ARP cache poisoning frames.

Note:

    This commit is based entirely on douard Thuleau's patch, which
    he presented for review here:

        https://review.openstack.org/#/c/70067/

    His patch was abandoned. I have merely copied his code into the
    latest code base and made a few minor adjustments for this purpose.

    All credit for the patch should go to douard.

Change-Id: Iad9508862cdbd5a663027fa98d815b075e8ff833
Closes-Bug: 1274034

commit_message:
Avoid changing constants module when adding new service plugin

Loading a new service plugin requires changes to the:
neutron/plugins/common/constants.py

This patch adds an option to load this information as configuration. The
patch attempts to work within the current framework of extension and
service plugin configuration, and limit the scope of changes to those
minimally required to achieve this.

Change-Id: Ida49366e0047afeb7d96ebf7fceb9fb967d4c8a1
Closes-Bug: 1361813

You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import os from oslo.config import cfg import neutron.common.test_lib as test_lib from neutron.plugins.common import constants import neutron.tests.unit.test_db_plugin as test_plugin class ParseServiceExtensionsMappingTestCase( test_plugin.NeutronDbPluginV2TestCase): def setUp(self): etc_path = os.path.join(os.path.dirname(__file__), 'etc') test_lib.test_config['config_files'] = [os.path.join(etc_path, 'neutron.conf.test')] self.addCleanup(cfg.CONF.reset) super(ParseServiceExtensionsMappingTestCase, self).setUp() def test_parse_single_service_provider_opt(self): from neutron.services import service_extension_configuration # noqa self.assertIn('NEW_SERVICE1', constants.ALLOWED_SERVICES) self.assertIn('NEW_SERVICE2', constants.ALLOWED_SERVICES) self.assertIn('NEW_SERVICE1', constants.COMMON_PREFIXES) self.assertEqual(constants.COMMON_PREFIXES[ 'NEW_SERVICE1'], '/new_svc_extension1') self.assertIn('NEW_SERVICE2', constants.COMMON_PREFIXES) self.assertEqual(constants.COMMON_PREFIXES[ 'NEW_SERVICE2'], '/new_svc_extension2') self.assertIn('new_svc_extension1', constants.EXT_TO_SERVICE_MAPPING) self.assertEqual(constants.EXT_TO_SERVICE_MAPPING[ 'new_svc_extension1'], 'NEW_SERVICE1') self.assertIn('new_svc_extension2', constants.EXT_TO_SERVICE_MAPPING) self.assertEqual(constants.EXT_TO_SERVICE_MAPPING[ 'new_svc_extension2'], 'NEW_SERVICE2')

commit_message:
ServiceInstanceInfo DB table

The table is part of the service insertion implementation.
The table is populated by each service plugin when a new instance
is created. When a new service_interface is created on a service
instance, the table is looked up to find the type of the service
for the instance.

Implements: blueprint service-base-class-and-insertion
Change-Id: Ie8015e16434445830b4df12a777f19e9fced391f

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-07-30 23:11:03.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/agent/linux/ovs_lib.py', 'neutron/plugins/ml2/rpc.py', 'neutron/plugins/openvswitch/agent/ovs_neutron_agent.py', 'neutron/plugins/ml2/plugin.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/e27862bc423a6a66c6ab669f378752ac6b9bfd16', 'message': "Delete the port name from ovsdb when neutron port-delete is called

Until now, when a user deleted a port from the neutron client using
the port-delete command we didn't remove it from ovs-db port lists.
As a result of which the openvswitch agent didnt deleted the security
group rules for that port. This allowed us to ping to the affected VM

Closes-Bug: #1333365
"}]
commit_message:
Delete the port name from ovsdb when neutron port-delete is called

Until now, when a user deleted a port from the neutron client using
the port-delete command we didn't remove it from ovs-db port lists.
As a result of which the openvswitch agent didnt deleted the security
group rules for that port. This allowed us to ping to the affected VM
even when the port got delete resulting in a security threat.

Change-Id: Ifaeba4ab253288a341739497204c28c04ffc0847
Closes-Bug: #1333365

commit_message:
add routerport instead of overloading device_id

implements blueprint l3-router-port-relationship

Previously the l3_agent relied on overloading the device_id attribute to
link a port to a router. Overloading this attribute prevents using the
L3 extension in situations where the router might be a service VM (Nova
will not use a port that already has a device_id).

Change-Id: I23a3a45665db8f61ce94f624f52a019b89e51570

commit_message:
Snabb NFV mechanism driver for ML2

Snabb NFV is an open source implementation of Network Functions
Virtualization. http://snabb.co/nfv.html

Change-Id: I2352eca1511e7a7c19ad3261554544ba320d48f0
Implements: blueprint snabb-nfv-mech-driver

commit_message:
Implements update_device_up in brocade plugin
Closes-Bug: #1223751

Change-Id: I856161a7ee6de83c36ff308e9dbbfe981e06e603
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/39/94139/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def update_device_up(self, rpc_context, **kwargs): """Device is up on agent.""" device = kwargs.get('device') port = self.get_port_from_device(device) if port: entry = {'device': device, 'exists': True} # Set port status to UP port_id = port['port_id'] brocade_db.update_port_state(rpc_context, port_id, True) else: entry = {'device': device, 'exists': False} LOG.debug(_("%s can not be found in database"), device) return entry

commit_message:
Support loading of service plugins via entrypoints

service_plugins are documented to use plain names that
are mapped via entrypoints to class names. However
neutron-db-manage was not handling this case.

Closes-Bug: #1286052
Change-Id: I3ce8e60d8b6ff4b471daf74dd05425edfc657fc0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/47/75447/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from stevedore import driverfor plugin in active_plugins: try: # Try to resolve plugin by name driver.DriverManager('neutron.service_plugins', plugin) except RuntimeError: # fallback to class name importutils.import_class(plugin)
deleted_lines: for class_path in active_plugins: importutils.import_class(class_path)

commit_message:
FWaaS integration with service type framewrok

The patch integrate FWaaS to service type framework. 'provider'
attribute can be specified when the firewall is created

Implements: blueprint fwaas-service-types-integration
Change-Id: Ida4acc619dc3a5ac0c872817caf1b44b0a479033

subject: Implement service vm framework: drivers for load balander (WIP)
revisions:
[{'number': 5, 'created': '2014-04-28 20:01:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/b71984a6ac5314425c519a714f0bea21e3c6e911', 'message': "Implement service vm framework: drivers for load balander (WIP)

This is work-in-progress yet. Only for early review/discussion.
This is just for showing its progress as early as possible and triggering
discussion based on the concrete code base.

A framework for for creating, managing and deploying Neutron advanced
services implemented as virtual machines.
The goal is to enable advanced network services (e.g. Load
Balancing, Security, Monitoring) that may be supplied by third party
vendors, are deployed as virtual machines, and are launched and
inserted into the tenant network on demand.

This is 1st phase:
two-leg VM for LBaaS service. VM effectively does nothing. Concept proofing.
As agreed at the design summit.

TODO:
done:- determine db model
done:- implement rest API
done:- python-neutron client
       https://github.com/yamahata/python-neutronclient.git adv-svc-vm
done:- talking nova with python-novaclient to spin up/down VM
done:- simple LBaaS driver (or apply this framework to existing LBaaS
  driver)
  done:- lbaas nova driver which requires trivial scheduler
done:- split patch into API/data model and lbaas part
done:- unit test for API/data model
done:- settle down management/data network/interface
WIP:- mgmt driver to communicate with hosting device and logical service
      instance
WIP:- mgmt driver for notifier api
WIP:- agent with notifier api
NEW:- unit test for simple lbaas driver
- devstack
  https://github.com/yamahata/devstack.git adv-svc-vm
- test
  - tempest?

- option: reference implementation of MGMT driver. SSH?
- option: use HEAT for spining up/down VM
- option: utlize l3-agent consolidation framework
- option: horizon GUI

commit_message:
Implement service vm framework: drivers for load balander (WIP)

This is work-in-progress yet. Only for early review/discussion.
This is just for showing its progress as early as possible and triggering
discussion based on the concrete code base.

A framework for for creating, managing and deploying Neutron advanced
services implemented as virtual machines.
The goal is to enable advanced network services (e.g. Load
Balancing, Security, Monitoring) that may be supplied by third party
vendors, are deployed as virtual machines, and are launched and
inserted into the tenant network on demand.

This is 1st phase:
two-leg VM for LBaaS service. VM effectively does nothing. Concept proofing.
As agreed at the design summit.

TODO:
done:- determine db model
done:- implement rest API
done:- python-neutron client
       https://github.com/yamahata/python-neutronclient.git adv-svc-vm
done:- talking nova with python-novaclient to spin up/down VM
done:- simple LBaaS driver (or apply this framework to existing LBaaS
  driver)
  done:- lbaas nova driver which requires trivial scheduler
done:- split patch into API/data model and lbaas part
done:- unit test for API/data model
done:- settle down management/data network/interface
WIP:- mgmt driver to communicate with hosting device and logical service
      instance
WIP:- mgmt driver for notifier api
WIP:- agent with notifier api
NEW:- unit test for simple lbaas driver
- devstack
  https://github.com/yamahata/devstack.git adv-svc-vm
- test
  - tempest?

- option: reference implementation of MGMT driver. SSH?
- option: use HEAT for spining up/down VM
- option: utlize l3-agent consolidation framework
- option: horizon GUI

etherpad
https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/NeutronServiceVM

current status
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1ZWDDTjwhIUedyipkDztM0_nBYgfCEP9Q77hhn1ZduCA/edit#heading=h.tajialn1fpoe

design overview
https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1Ir8MZC7fJb8SOhiZOEQovP_EvdFz_cF_-GEWsidAu7k/edit?usp=sharing

Implement: blueprint adv-services-in-vms
---
Changes v12 -> 13:
- finished rest API/db model with unit test and split it out.

Change v11 -> v12:
- use six
- unit tests

Change v10 -> v11:
- simple driver for lbaas worked

Changes v9 -> v10:
- started mgmt driver
- started unit tests

Changes v8 -> v9:
- introduced driver for lbaas and simple scheduler (mostly done)
- started mgmt-if and networks.
  WIP. needs to be finished.

Changes v7 -> v8:
- use python-novaclient
- started lbaas driver

Changes v6 -> v7:
- nova driver tested
- reflected review(not all)

Changes v5 -> v6:
- added nova driver (not tested yet)
- use stevedore

Changes v4 -> v5:
- Rest API prototype
- python-neutron client

Changes v3 -> v4:
- fixed db table
- implemented basic db operations
- started REST API

Changes v2.1 -> v3
- more update on db tables.
- introduce vm/drivers dir

Changes v2 -> v2.1
- pep8
Changes v1 -> v2:
- reflected Bob's comment

Change-Id: Iede23f4199b4e027c7b28d7519fcccd69c37237d

commit_message:
Implement Midonet Juno Router Api calls

This patch is part of a series of patches converting the current midonet plugin
code to the new model described in blueprint midonet-plugin-juno. This patch
focuses specifically on the "router" handlers.

Partially-Implements: blueprint midonet-plugin-juno
Signed-off-by: Joe Mills <joe@midokura.com>

Change-Id: I6457d2db09cc328196c587b7d1a8c29f6e86319e

commit_message:
Remove @author tags from copyright statements

We have git to track the authorship of files. It is not necessary to use
the @author tags in the copyright statements.

Change-Id: Ifc8a32e1131a2d9d7ef900cdef420da81119fb5a

subject: Redact X-Auth-Token from http requests
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-09-10 15:33:45.000000000', 'files': ['neutronclient/common/utils.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-neutronclient/commit/f6243f5bee861e383e8d1738b8fec22833d9f38f', 'message': 'Redact X-Auth-Token from http requests

X-Auth-Token is logged for every request which causes a lot
noise in nova logs and significantly increases its size -
instead of it log TOKEN_REDACTED like keystone client.
Closes-Bug: #1367339

Change-Id: I0a6884a49cc134d42747adbb20a28141dfd0aabc
'}]
commit_message:
Redact X-Auth-Token from http requests

X-Auth-Token is logged for every request which causes a lot
noise in nova logs and significantly increases its size -
instead of it log TOKEN_REDACTED like keystone client.
Closes-Bug: #1367339

Change-Id: I0a6884a49cc134d42747adbb20a28141dfd0aabc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-neutronclient refs/changes/49/120449/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import six for (key, value) in six.iteritems(kwargs['headers']): if key == 'X-Auth-Token': value = 'TOKEN_REDACTED' header = ' -H "%s: %s"' % (key, value)
deleted_lines: for element in kwargs['headers']: header = ' -H "%s: %s"' % (element, kwargs['headers'][element])

commit_message:
firewall-rule-show is not showing protocol "any"

If user creates a firewall rule with protocol = any, firewall-rule-show of
that rule is not showing anything. It should display "any"

Change-Id: Ibe6b4c66e811ed153b07f99e6c2ff3113f4e2472
Closes-bug: 1336800

commit_message:
Make neutronclient authenticate using keystoneclient

1. Delete user_id in command arguments.
2. Using keystoneclient to authenticate instead of using
   REST API request directly.
3. Using keystoneclient to authenticate will also let
   keystoneclient to log credentials. Hashing credentials
   in keystoneclient log will be fixed in Bug: 1004114.

DocImpact

Change-Id: Ib6151335cf0db7b4bd5546e81f56b6a20ef68bfd
Closes-Bug: 1327019
Co-authored-by: Xu Han Peng <xuhanp@cn.ibm.com>

commit_message:
peer_id attribute can be IPv4/IPv6 address

as per design.
but help shows it can be IPv4/IPv6 address,
e-mail address, key id, or FQDN.

Change-Id: I8d0ebaf32fe9017b829b3690bcb5d032c9667ec6
Closes-Bug: 1364221

commit_message:
Add API in python-neutronclient for Cisco DFA

When creating a network in Cisco DFA topology, a new API is needed to return
list of supported configuration profiles.
This patch defines list_config_profiles API, which returns list of
available profiles stored in neutron database.

Change-Id: I7a0b8428248b5bda8bedcd59cc2633be3e868041
Implements: blueprint python-neutronclient-for-cisco-dfa

commit_message:
Use immutable arg rather mutable arg

Passing mutable objects as default args is a known Python pitfall.
We'd better avoid this. This commit changes mutable default args with
None.

Change-Id: I9237705e5300ef695b30c469460feee48473dd11

subject: Add service group as a firewall customized service
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-07-09 20:53:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-neutronclient/commit/1484bd702381c2383b10dfe4dc7ed5308f0fdf61', 'message': "Implements: blueprint fwaas-customized-service using service group

-In FWaaS, administrator can use port range and protocol inside firewall rules
to define traffic type. But we don't have a flexible way to allow user to specify more
than one type of traffic in the same rule.To support different traffic type, with the
same source, destination address and action, different rules need to be created.
This makes the process of defining firewall rules un-scalable.
two resources are added to enhance the FWaaS using the following cli
one is called service group and one is called service object
Administrator can use service object to define a special type of traffic. The service
objects is grouped into service group that can be referenced from other openstack
modules (eg. firewall rule).
Each service object can be defined with a timeout value that can be used to overwrite
default session idle timeout value.
New CLIs:
service-group-create
service-group-delete
service-group-list
service-group-show
service-group-update
service-object-create
service-object-delete
service-object-list
service-object-show

Change-Id: Ic1c05f94eb9b7cdab9472c43a2162acecf8c2d27

commit_message:
Add service group as a firewall customized service

This patch introduces flexible way to allow user to specify more
than one type of traffic in the same rule.
two resources are added to enhance the FWaaS using the following cli
one is called service group and one is called service object
Administrator can use service object to define a special type of traffic.
The service objects is grouped into service group that can be referenced
from other openstack modules (eg. firewall rule).
New CLIs:
service-group-create
service-group-delete
service-group-list
service-group-show
service-group-update
service-object-create
service-object-delete
service-object-list
service-object-show
Implements: blueprint fwaas-customized-service for customized service
Change-Id: Ic1c05f94eb9b7cdab9472c43a2162acecf8c2d27
Authored-by: badveli vishnuvardhan <badveli_vishnuus@yahoo.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-neutronclient refs/changes/73/105873/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from neutronclient.neutron.v2_0 import servicegroup 'service-group-create': servicegroup.CreateServiceGroup, 'service-group-show': servicegroup.ShowServiceGroup, 'service-group-list': servicegroup.ListServiceGroup, 'service-group-delete': servicegroup.DeleteServiceGroup, 'service-group-update': servicegroup.UpdateServiceGroup, 'service-object-create': servicegroup.CreateServiceObject, 'service-object-list': servicegroup.ListServiceObject, 'service-object-show': servicegroup.ShowServiceObject, 'service-object-delete': servicegroup.DeleteServiceObject, self.log.debug(_('Got an error: %s'), unicode(err))
deleted_lines: self.log.debug('Got an error: %s', unicode(err))

commit_message:
CLI support for Traffic Steering

This commit adds CLI support for the Traffic Steering Abstraction
proposed in blueprint traffic-steering-abstraction.

Implements: blueprint traffic-steering-abstraction
Change-Id: Ie6dd2e42e99de13ba8bdd7313a31d0607ecef5fd

commit_message:
Per project user quotas support in client

The purpose of this is to implement the per user quota supprt.

Chages:
- API and parser updated to handle user_id when showing, updating and
deleting quota.

Depends on change I0d63eb00babcaf3252ea226c1e23b5016c1c8697

Change-Id: If3bd1f208f315968a2380778cbe0759e6f57456b
Implements: blueprint per-project-user-quotas

commit_message:
Expose retries and retry_interval

The python-neutronclient contains a connection retry logic, but it isn't
in use. "Maximum attempts reached" exception is raised after 1 attempt.

Solution:

    New constructor parameters: retries, retry_interval
    The retriable request will be retried 3 times
    The error message will contain the number of retries

Change-Id: I658b91c3275e8109ff9f504e969a0c8a61e9b091
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-neutronclient refs/changes/64/71464/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: :param integer retries: Number of connection attempts. Default: 3 :param float retry_interval: Number of seconds beetween connection attempts. Default: 1 def __init__(self, retries=3, retry_interval=1, **kwargs): self.retries = retries self.retry_interval = retry_interval raise exceptions.ConnectionFailed(reason=(_("Maximum attempts " "reached (%d)")) % max_attempts)
deleted_lines: def __init__(self, **kwargs): self.retries = 0 self.retry_interval = 1 raise exceptions.ConnectionFailed(reason=_("Maximum attempts reached"))

commit_message:
Use timeutils.set_time_override instead of stubbing

Some old unit tests would stub timeutils.utcnow{,_ts} instead of
using the override functionality that timeutils has. This patch
makes all unit tests use the timeutils override in favor or stubbing
the functions out.

Change-Id: Ieca64e6e811970b252536049c51d53f528a27999
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/68/139868/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: FAKE_TIMESTAMP = datetime.datetime(2012, 10, 29, 13, 42, 11) timeutils.set_time_override(FAKE_TIMESTAMP) self.addCleanup(timeutils.clear_time_override) timeutils.set_time_override(FAKE_TIMESTAMP) self.addCleanup(timeutils.clear_time_override)
deleted_lines: import calendardef fake_utcnow(): return datetime.datetime(2012, 10, 29, 13, 42, 11) fake_utcnow.override_time = None def fake_utcnow_ts(): d = fake_utcnow() return calendar.timegm(d.utctimetuple()) self.stubs.Set(timeutils, "utcnow", fake_utcnow) self.stubs.Set(timeutils, "utcnow_ts", fake_utcnow_ts) self.stubs.Set(timeutils, "utcnow", fake_utcnow) self.stubs.Set(timeutils, "utcnow_ts", fake_utcnow_ts)

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-08-13 19:49:29.000000000', 'files': ['neutronclient/shell.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-neutronclient/commit/74cb38ca001af6de4a3649143c77c116f35534b1', 'message': "Don't look beyond subcommand for args to main

Don't pass arguments after the subcommand to the argument
parser for the main command. This will prevent collisions
between arguments that could share the same name with an

Change-Id: I6c7d165f4428f38c03134ab77ae2b1a0b80fb00c
"}]
commit_message:
Don't look beyond subcommand for args to main

Don't pass arguments after the subcommand to the argument
parser for the main command. This will prevent collisions
between arguments that could share the same name with an
argument to the parent command (e.g. --timeout).

Closes-Bug: #1353536
Change-Id: I6c7d165f4428f38c03134ab77ae2b1a0b80fb00c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-neutronclient refs/changes/05/114005/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if command_pos != -1: parse_range = argv[0:command_pos] additional = argv[command_pos:] else: parse_range = argv additional = [] self.options, remainder = self.parser.parse_known_args(parse_range) remainder += additional
deleted_lines: self.options, remainder = self.parser.parse_known_args(argv)

added_lines: # # Copyright 2013 Intel # Copyright 2013 Isaku Yamahata <isaku.yamahata at intel com> # <isaku.yamahata at gmail com> # All Rights Reserved. # # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. # # @author: Isaku Yamahata, Intel from neutronclient.neutron import v2_0 as neutronV20 _DEVICE_TEMPLATE = "device_template" class ListDeviceTemplate(neutronV20.ListCommand): """List device template that belong to a given tenant.""" resource = _DEVICE_TEMPLATE class ShowDeviceTemplate(neutronV20.ShowCommand): """show information of a given DeviceTemplate.""" resource = _DEVICE_TEMPLATE class CreateDeviceTemplate(neutronV20.CreateCommand): """create a DeviceTemplate.""" resource = _DEVICE_TEMPLATE def add_known_arguments(self, parser): parser.add_argument( '--name', help='Set a name for the devicetemplate') parser.add_argument( '--description', help='Set a description for the devicetemplate') parser.add_argument( '--service-type', action='append', help='Add a servicetype for the devicetemplate') parser.add_argument( '--device-driver', help='Set a device driver name for the devicetemplate') parser.add_argument( '--mgmt-driver', help='Set a manegement driver name for the devicetemplate') parser.add_argument( '--attribute', nargs=2, action='append', help='Set a servicetypes for the devicetemplate') def args2body(self, parsed_args): body = { self.resource: { 'service_types': [ {'service_type': service_type} for service_type in parsed_args.service_type], 'device_driver': parsed_args.device_driver, 'mgmt_driver': parsed_args.mgmt_driver, } } if parsed_args.attribute: body[self.resource]['attributes'] = dict(parsed_args.attribute) neutronV20.update_dict(parsed_args, body[self.resource], ['tenant_id', 'name', 'description']) return body class UpdateDeviceTemplate(neutronV20.UpdateCommand): """Update a given DeviceTemplate.""" resource = _DEVICE_TEMPLATE allow_names = False class DeleteDeviceTemplate(neutronV20.DeleteCommand): """Delete a given DeviceTemplate.""" resource = _DEVICE_TEMPLATE

commit_message:
fw-rule-update shud throw error for dup options

firewall-rule-update is not throwing an error
when user gives --protocol option multiple
times.

Closes-bug: 1327071

Change-Id: Ica9c39fb72ef6055dafa2a5e2f73b51dd9e91094

Partially-implements: blueprint ovs-firewall-driver

python-neutronclient users can already specify --port-range-min and
--port-range-max with security-group-rule-create to create a security
group rule with destination ports. This change allows users to
optionally specify --source-port-range-min and --source-port-range-max
with security-group-rule-create to create a security group rule that
will match on source ports.

Change-Id: Idcbd93912aed3d58573cc54b7ae598583b6bd8bd

commit_message:
Added --source-port-range-min, --source-port-range-max

Partially-implements: blueprint ovs-firewall-driver

python-neutronclient users can already specify --port-range-min and
--port-range-max with security-group-rule-create to create a security
group rule with destination ports. This change allows users to
optionally specify --source-port-range-min and --source-port-range-max
with security-group-rule-create to create a security group rule that
will match on source ports.

Change-Id: Idcbd93912aed3d58573cc54b7ae598583b6bd8bd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-neutronclient refs/changes/30/62130/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Client support for group-based-policy-abstraction

Implement the CLI support for group-based-policy-abstraction. group-policy
adds resources such as endpoint, endpoint-group, contracts and policy-rules
to enable the specification of application requirements for both an app
provider and an app consumer.

Change-Id: I1f815c3db317e14642abe03b6da843168d0ac6bf
Implements: blueprint group-based-policy-abstraction

commit_message:
Added unittest for utils.py

Now a basic unittest for utils.py
is available under tests/test_utils.py.
While writing unittest two bugs were encountered
and fixed also on this commit.

tox.ini also has been modified to be able to use
runtests.py

commit_message:
Infoblox Plugin for Neutron

This proposal relies on the recently introduced blueprints for pluggable IPAM subsystem and generic DNS service and essentially offers a third-party implementation for these generic functions.

See also https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/infoblox-plugin-neutron

Change-Id: Ic06f962acdb2ad9eb5549e684aa14300af384797
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/86/97986/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Infoblox Plugin for Neutron ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/infoblox-plugin-neutron This blueprint describes enhancing OpenStack with richer and powerful networking capabilities provided by Infoblox. This proposal relies on the recently introduced blueprints for pluggable IPAM subsystem and generic DNS service and essentially offers a third-party implementation for these generic functions. See related blueprints in the Dependencies section. The blueprint also provides ideas about building a generic Infoblox-enabled OpenStack cluster. A typical network topology and component interaction are described in the technical specifications. Problem Description =================== Following are the use cases: * An OpenStack cloud admin wants to have a single IPAM source of truth for physical and virtual networks, updated in real time. * An OpenStack cloud admin wants to have an OpenStack cluster with networking backed by the Infoblox solution. * An OpenStack cloud admin wants to delegate IP Address Management to the Infoblox solution. * An OpenStack cloud admin wants to delegate DHCP functionality to the Infoblox solution. * An OpenStack cloud admin wants to delegate DNS functionality to the Infoblox solution. * An OpenStack cloud user wants to utilize the Infoblox intelligent assignment of IP addresses based on OpenStack related metadata or metadata provided by the user. * An OpenStack cloud user wants to utilize per tenant DNS zone lifecycle management policy specific to Infoblox. Proposed Changes =============== 1. Infoblox-enabled Neutron architecture overview < images/infoblox_neutron.png> 2. IPAM driver for neutron service Infoblox IPAM driver uses Neutron DB to track most of the state. In addition, some of the operations are synchronized with the Infoblox Grid using REST API. The following requests are tracked by the Neutron DB and synchronized with the Infoblox Grid: * create_network * delete_network * create_subnet * delete_subnet IP allocation is completely delegated to the Infoblox Grid. The Neutron DB does not track used and available IP addresses, though it still tracks the subnet IP ranges. The following actions are managed by the Infoblox Grid only (this is not reflected in the Neutron DB): * allocate_ip * deallocate_ip 3. DHCP/DNS proxy driver for dhcp agent < images/proxy_driver.png > DHCP traffic flow: * DHCP requests come from Tenant A (192.168.0.0/24) * The DHCP relay (on the controller) accepts this broadcast request and relays it using its own routing table to the Infoblox DHCP server. * The Infoblox DHCP server responds to the request and send a response to the DHCP relay. * The DHCP relay receives a response and sends it back to the client in Tenant A. The same applies to the receiving acknowledgement process and for DNS. This scheme works for regular tenants behind NAT and l3-router as for provider networks in which tenant networks is a part of the customer infrastructure and routable. 4. Infoblox-enabled OpenStack cluster Following is an example of a network connectivity diagram for an Infoblox-enabled OpenStack cluster (based on Mirantis Reference Architecture 4.0 [1]): < images/infoblox_cluster.png > [1] http://docs.mirantis.com/fuel/fuel-4.0/reference-architecture.html#network-architecture Alternatives ------------ None. Data Model Impact ----------------- New models will be added to support DNS and DHCP relay functionality. The existing models are not affected. REST API Impact --------------- None. Security Impact --------------- The implementation will utilize OpenStack best practices for secure REST API connectivity similar to existing plugins. Notification Impact -------------------- None. Other End User Impact --------------------- The Infoblox Grid provides a GUI (Grid Manager) to manage networking. Users can use Grid Manager it to configure network properties. Online Help is provided through the GUI. Performance Impact ------------------ The plugin uses REST communication to external Infoblox Grid that could affect performance. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- None. Developer Impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Soheil Eizadi (seizadi) Other contributors: <TBD> Work Items ---------- 1. Implement IPAM plugin for neutron-service. 2. Implement DNS proxy driver for neutron-dhcp-agent. 3. Implement DHCP proxy driver for neutron-dhcp-agent. Dependencies ============ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/neutron-ipam https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/dns-subsystem Testing ======= The plugin and Infoblox solution/integration will be tested using Tempest according to the current OpenStack policy*. * https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Neutron_Plugins_and_Drivers Documentation Impact ==================== None. References ========== None.

Add l3-agent-consolidation spec

Change-Id: I0b2ac0a74c5f352c65428ea46ba38c0f45c86bd2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/32/91532/11 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ====================== l3 agent consolidation ====================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/l3-agent-consolidation The implementation of l3-agent needs to be modular in order to handle vendor specific l3 extensions and l3-agent based advanced services nicely. Problem description =================== The l3-agent doesn't have hook points nor extension loading capability. Due to lack of them, the l3-agent has the following shortcomings: * Agents for router-based advanced services, such as VPN and FW, needs to inherit the l3-agent code. With this scheme, there's no way to run more than one of such agents. Also, it isn't possible to arbitrarily select and enable some of such advanced services, as they are hard-coded. * It is not possible to implement vendor-specific l3-agent extensions without changing the l3-agent code. Proposed change =============== The l3-agent will have a set of hook points and driver loading mechanism for advanced services. The agent codes for FWaaS and VPNaaS will be rewritten as advanced service drivers. Alternatives ------------ None. Data model impact ----------------- None. REST API impact --------------- None. Security impact --------------- None. Notifications impact -------------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ None other than a little more agent start up time due to driver loading. Other deployer impact --------------------- * l3_agent.ini will have a new advanced_service_drivers option. * neutron-vpn-agent will be deprecated. * How to handle vendor specific hooks needs to be worked out. Developer impact ---------------- It will affect developers working on the l3-agent and its derived agents. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Who is leading the writing of the code? Or is this a blueprint where you're throwing it out there to see who picks it up? If more than one person is working on the implementation, please designate the primary author and contact. Primary assignee: <launchpad-id or None> Other contributors: <launchpad-id or None> Work Items ---------- TBD. Dependencies ============ Will be added depending on others' development plans. Testing ======= Tests will be covered by unit tests. Documentation Impact ==================== The developer doc might need a section of l3-agent hooks and APIs for l3-agent based agents. References ========== * https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1e85n2IE38XoYwlsqNvqhKFLox6O01SbguZXq7SnSSGo/edit?pli=1#slide=id.gc2c671fc_00 * Juno design summit session: L3 vendor plugins https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/L3-vendor-plugins

commit_message:
This blueprint spec provides information about the updating
from old quantum project to neutron project.

It addresses the naming problems in code variables and created
security group bridges.

Change-Id: Id25b8e600a6c00300fc8c4f4dffecbb13bb274e7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/06/96106/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ====================================================================== Legacy Quantum Naming Update - Update the legacy quantum naming usage ====================================================================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/legacy-quantum-naming-update There are lots of code using quantum naming due to the previous project name. Since we have already changed the name from quantum to neutron, we should also update these names, and also recommend further coding to utilize the new naming. Problem description =================== Today the Neutron project is actually the one performing network functions in OpenStack. However, lots of new writing code still utlize the name quantum due to the existing libraries. * One problem is the naming of variables in the code. E.g., q_const should be updated to n_const, which means from quantum to neutron. * The other problem is the naming of bridges that are created by Neutron. The existing security rule bridge is named as qbrxxx, which should also be updated to nbrxxx. Proposed change =============== The proposal is to change all the old naming from quantum to neutron, in this case, many Neutron code especially the plugins with the quantum naming will be updated, e.g., neutron/common/util.py, neutron/db/securitygroups_rpc_base.py, and neutron/plugins. Alternatives ------------ None. Data model impact ----------------- The possible data model is the security rules bridge, which is named as 'qbrxxx' currently. We will update it into 'nbrxxx' accordingly. REST API impact --------------- None. Security impact --------------- None. Notifications impact -------------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ None. Other deployer impact --------------------- There is no necessary changes in the configuration files. However, to enable the new code, the neutron services should be restarted after deploying the updated component. Developer impact ---------------- Developers will be suggested to utilize the new neutron naming, instead of the old one in the working code. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: <yangbaohua> Other contributors: <None> Work Items ---------- 1. Update the variable naming in plugins 2. Update the variable naming in the common library 3. Update the naming of the security group bridge Dependencies ============ None. Testing ======= Yes, since the variable names are changed, we suggest the existing unit tests to run throughly to make sure the functions are not affected. Single node infrastructure to test the feature may still be possible, but we need to validate. Continuous integration testing to test the dvr at the gate will be considered. Documentation Impact ==================== Yes. There will be documentation impact and so documentation will utilize the new names. References ========== * https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/legacy-quantum-naming-update

Exclude compute related tests for now.

Compute tests are not working yet, so to get reliable passes with
keystone, glance and cinder; compute related tests are disabled. This
will be reverted once compute tests are passing.

commit_message:
Generic DNS Subsystem

This blueprint describes a generic DNS subsystem, which provides a basic DNS resolving service and the ability to communicate within a tenant or outside the cloud using fully qualified domain names. In addition, it provides an ability to add a pluggable DNS service provider.

See also: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/dns-subsystem

Change-Id: I5c6ab0fe9fa6909ee23605f2dec4861c8bf8ab24
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/70/97970/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Generic DNS Subsystem ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/dns-subsystem This blueprint describes a generic DNS subsystem, which provides a basic DNS resolving service and the ability to communicate within a tenant or outside the cloud using fully qualified domain names. In addition, it provides an ability to add a pluggable DNS service provider. Problem Description =================== Currently, Neutron does not have a DNS subsystem. We see the following use cases for future implementation: * A cloud user wants a basic DNS resolving service for the VMs out of the box. * A cloud user wants to use fully qualified domain names for VM-to-VM communication within a tenant. * A cloud user wants to use fully qualified domain names to access VMs from outside the cloud. * A cloud operator wants to select a backend to provide DNS services appropriate for a particular OpenStack environment. Proposed Changes =============== 1. Requirements * The VMs must be automatically configured to use the internal DNS servers. * Users should not be required to specify external DNS servers when creating a new network, but be able to specify external DNS servers in addition to that provided by the cloud. * DNS services must be provided in a highly available manner, including configuration of both a primary and a secondary DNS. * Each new VM in a tenant must automatically get a set of corresponding DNS records in a per-tenant DNS zone (optionally in a shared one). * VMs must get automatically configured with a proper DNS suffix. * The policy for DNS zone access restriction must be configurable by a cloud operator. * The format of address records must be defined by means of a template/pattern specified by a cloud operator. * IPv6 address records should be supported. * For each floating IP address assigned to a VM, a set of appropriate DNS records must be created in the corresponding DNS zone (per-tenant-network / per-floating-pool / shared zone). * A default dnsmasq-based implementation should be available. 2. DNS subsystem architecture overview High-level DNS subsystem architecture is shown in the following image (dns-arch): < image/dns_subsystem.png > The Neutron DHCP agent manages the DNS driver together with the existing DHCP driver. Each DNS driver maintains a DNS server connected to a tenant network. Its responsible for resolving VM names within a tenant. All the DNS records created automatically during the port create process in Neutron. The following diagram shows the process of automatic DNS records creation triggered by the nova-boot command: .. seqdiag:: seqdiag { user -> nova [label = nova-boot]; nova -> neutron-service [label = "allocate IP"]; neutron-service -> dns-db [label = create DNS record]; nova <-- neutron [label = IP]; nova -> nova [label = ...]; user <-- nova [label = VM info]; } 3. Pluggable backend design A DNS driver has an interface that is very similar to the DHCP driver. DnsBase: * enable * disable * restart * active * reload_records * existing_dns_records (optional, if neutron DB change is approved) * check_version The DNS driver is managed by dhcp_agent. Each notification event triggers changes on both the DHCP and DNS drivers. The following example shows the flow for the port.update.end notification: .. seqdiag:: seqdiag { neutron-service -> neutron-dhcp [label = port.update.end]; neutron-dhcp -> neutron-dhcp [label = "call_driver(dhcp, 'reload_allocations', )"]; neutron-dhcp -> neutron-dhcp [label = "call_driver(dns, 'reload_records, )"]; } 4. Default dnsmasq-based DNS driver TBD The description of the default driver can be found in the dedicated blueprint: <bp-ref>. 5. HA (high availability) support The blueprint does not introduce the new components thus this blueprint wont affect the existing HA schemes. Data Model Impact ----------------- * Add enable_dns property to the Subnet, similar to enable_dhcp. If this approach is not suitable, we can enable DNS through the config file. In such case, no changes are required for the Neutron DB. * Default dnsmasq-based implementation requires its own DB, which is described in dedicated BP. REST API Impact --------------- None. Security impact --------------- None. Notification Impact -------------------- None. Other End User Impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ The additional driver inside dhcp-agent will increase time to handle notifications, and will probably increase DB workload. We expect the increase will not be significant, and will not affect other OpenStack components. A corresponding benchmark analysis will be performed once the code becomes stable. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- New configuration options: * dns_driver - The driver used to manage the DNS server. Developer Impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Soheil Eizadi (seizadi) Other contributors: <TBD> Work Items ---------- 1. Introduce the DNS subsystem to the neutron-service which will create records in the DNS driver DB. 2. Create DnsBase and make all necessary changes on the dhcp-agent. 3. Create the default dnsmasq-based driver (covered by separate bp). 4. Create tempest tests. Dependencies ============ None. Testing ======= Neutron unit and integration tests + Tempest test required. Documentation Impact ==================== Documentation needs to be updated to cover the new DNS subsystem. References ========== None.
