added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Dynamic multicast management solution ========================================== The idea of this proposal is to support multicast snooping to avoid load on the production virtual machines (VMs). This proposal provides dynamic management of multicast group by provisioning the virtual switches which are hosted on the KVM or ESX hypervisor. Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: None Problem description =================== In existing Open stack solution, Tenant VMs hosted will receive unnecessary multicast traffic upto the Layer of the IP Stack even though they have not subscribed to the multicast group. ( i.e multicast packets reaches the L2 layer of the VMs will be dropped at the Layer 2 since no multicast entry exist). With this proposal, the vSwitch will be provisioned to handle IGMP control packets to manage multicast data packets of the unreserved multicast data group. The reserved multicast group traffic will be always allowed which is required for proper functioning of the network. Proposed change =============== To address the above challenge, the proposed solution require changes in the L2 agent module. Flows will be added at the integration bridge to manage the multicast traffic or an additional bridge will be hosted in the openvswitch to manage the multicast groups. The tenant VMs interested in the multicast traffic will registered the multicast group. The kernel will send out the IGMP JOIN/LEAVE Reports for the registered multicast groups, which reaches the OVS Switch hosted on the CN. The OVS Switch on the CN will be provisioned with FLOWS to allow multicast traffic for only those VMs which are interested in the multicast traffic. Following are Use-cases for supporting multicast in Openstack. Tenant VM is the Multicast Group Receiver. The OVS Switch will be provisioned to BLOCK/ALLOW traffic from/to VMs. Tenant VM is the Multicast Group Source. The OVS Switch will be provisioned to Forward the traffic to the NN because some Receivers might be on other side of the network(cloud) registered for this multicast traffic. Tenant VMs not being there in the multicast group but later joining the same. Tenant VMs being there in the multicast group but later leaving the same. Support (S,G) entries. Source Specific multicast. The OVS Switch will be provisioned to support source specific entries. NN  Querier can be deployed on it NN will be provisioned for allowing the traffic or blocking the traffic from the outside world. Physical Switch- Querier can be deployed on it NN will be provisioned for allowing the traffic or blocking the traffic from the Physical Switch. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Singh, Gangadhar Other contributors: P,Rashmi Shenoy, Raghuveer Gupta, Romil Work Items ---------- OVS L2 agent implementation ML2 Plugin L3 agent Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unit tests will be added. Existing tempest will be added. Documentation Impact ==================== Documentation will be updated. References ========== None

commit_message:
Link Aggregation for Ironic

Allow Ironic to configure link aggregation

Provide the ability to boot a bare metal node
using a resilient network pair of interfaces in
an arbitrarily degraded state.  Also, provide a
way to represent the link aggregate.

blueprint neutron-link-aggregation

Change-Id: Ib1ffe1dbfd2de3562e93d0fc830434fec312ad46
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/65/103765/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Neutron for Ironic - Link Aggregation ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/neutron-link-aggregation Today, if a user deploying workloads via Ironic wants to use link aggregation for better resilience and/or higher bandwidth, the configuration must be done outside the OpenStack framework. This is because Neutron lacks several capabilities. * it cannot provide the required information about the underlying physical network topology * it cannot represent multiple interfaces connecting a Nova instance to a single network in a way that Nova can accept * for resilient boot, it requires a separate IP address for each NIC We propose to enable the automation of the link aggregation configuration by enhancing Neutron to provide the required topology knowledge and by resolving the tension between Nova and Neutron regarding an instance having multiple connections to a network. Problem description =================== Ironic represents compute hardware as Nova instances. So, each instance's interface (NIC) to a network is represented by a Neutron port with a single mac address. Nova currently limits an instance's connection to a specific network to 1 port. Together, these facts conspire to prevent representing a link aggregation configuration using Nova and Neutron ports. In the following subsections are some use cases and problems specific to each. Primary Use Cases ----------------- This section contains use cases needed in first feature release. 1. **Boot of a bare metal node**. Ironic needs to be able to boot a bare metal node from a network using any one of multiple network interfaces. Once the node is booted, the interfaces will be aggregated such that there may be 1 IP address for the aggregate, but at boot time, each interface has a distinct mac address. DHCP (dnsmasq) cannot share 1 IP address across a set of mac addresses, so booting from interface B requires a different IP address than booting from interface A. Requiring multiple IP addresses for the aggregate is undesirable. Deferred Use Cases ------------------ This section discusses use cases to be delivered after first feature release, provided here for context. 2. **Automated discovery of link aggregate**. While switches are configured outside of OpenStack, network topology and link aggregate definitions in the switches are discovered by Neutron, enabling deployers to automatically configure aggregation in the bare metal instances. 3. **Automated configuration of link aggregate**. Fully automatic link aggregate configuration (switch and host side). Proposed change =============== While the DHCP issue can be worked around in Linux, doing so is complex (e.g. memoising DHCP results and applying them after boot if DHCP is not available) and such hacks are not available for the boot process itself. Thus we offer a design to support boot time DHCP. This specification is focused on enabling booting a resilient network pair in an arbitrary degraded state without manual intervention, and simplifying the in-instance configuration where this is enabled by the low level support. * Get resilient boot time DHCP working. Options: - modify dnsmasq to allow multiple macs per IP - use a client id instead of mac address? - require multiple IPs (undesirable) - others? * Provide a way to represent a link aggregate. Options: - modify port resource to allow multiple mac addresses - provide a way to associate ports which are part of the same aggregate - use proposed 'network port' resource from https://review.openstack.org/#/c/91275 Alternatives ------------ TBD Data model impact ----------------- TBD REST API impact --------------- TBD Security impact --------------- TBD Notifications impact -------------------- TBD Other end user impact --------------------- TBD Performance Impact ------------------ TBD Other deployer impact --------------------- TBD Developer impact ---------------- TBD Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: ccarlino Other contributors: Work Items ---------- TBD Dependencies ============ TBD, but may depend on the Physical Network Topology spec [Reference 1]. Testing ======= TBD Documentation Impact ==================== TBD References ========== #. Physical Network Topology: https://review.openstack.org/91275 #. TripleO Network Configuration: https://review.openstack.org/97859

commit_message:
Option to disable dns on some subnets

Change-Id: I343747f02755249f318ef0467f01b31a99a2999b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/42/100242/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ===================================== Option to disable dns on some subnets ===================================== Problem description =================== Multiple NIC/subnet may attach to a VM instance, if both subnets provide dns servers, depending on the dhcp order, only the last one will be used (overrides the previous one). So the VM is choosing the dns server randomly among all dns of its subnets. For security reason some subnets can be totally local and isolate, there is no l3-router, even the dnsmasq won't be able to talk to any other dns servers, if any VM choose it as its dns server, the VM lost its dns function. So I want to disable dns on such subnets. So we may want to disable dns of the subnet. Proposed change =============== Add an option to disable dns server on some subnet, so the dnsmasq won't push dns server to VM, the VM will use dns of other available subnets. Alternatives ------------ None. Data model impact ----------------- * subnet - add enable_dns column REST API impact --------------- For each API resource to be implemented using Neutron's attribute map facility (see the neutron.api.v2.attributes), describe the resource collection and specify the name, type, and other essential details of each new or modified attribute. A table similar to the following may be used: +----------+-------+---------+---------+------------+----------------------+ |Attribute |Type |Access |Default |Validation/ |Description | |Name | | |Value |Conversion | | +==========+=======+=========+=========+============+======================+ |enable_dns|boolean|RW |True | |Whether to enable dns | | | | | | |on the subnet | +----------+-------+---------+---------+------------+----------------------+ Security impact --------------- None. Notifications impact -------------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- * neutronclient - Add --enable-dns/--disable-dns to subnet resource Performance Impact ------------------ None. Other deployer impact --------------------- None. Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: zangmingjie Work Items ---------- * neutron single patch * neutronclient single patch Dependencies ============ None. Testing ======= * Unit tests * Tempest API tests Documentation Impact ==================== * subnet API change References ========== * WIP: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/89745

added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================================= FWaaS Integration with Service Type Framework ============================================= Launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/fwaas-service-types-integration Integrate FWaaS with service type framework. Problem description =================== Service Type Framework is a framework that enables multi-vendor deployment of advanced services. The patch for FWaaS integration has been submitted in IceHouse release cycle. We will refactor the pacth to be the backend of Flavor Framework in Juno release. Proposed change =============== The implementation dispatches service API calls to vendor drivers based on provider attribute of the firewall instance. The provider attribute is hidden to tenant users but only visiable to the admin user. The admin user selects the provider with matching flavor that is requested by the tenant user. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Gary Duan Primary assignee: <gduan> Work Items ---------- Work items or tasks -- break the feature up into the things that need to be done to implement it. Those parts might end up being done by different people, but we're mostly trying to understand the timeline for implementation. Dependencies ============ This blueprint is under the umbrella of blueprint neutron-services-insertion-chaining-steering. Testing ======= Unit tests will be implemented. Tempest test cases should only be against service flavors. Documentation Impact ==================== Documentation should cover how administrator can map flavors to backend providers. This effect will be done as part of Flavor Framework blueprint. References ========== None

commit_message:
Chaining of basic Networking Services with OVS

Specification for Chaining basic Neutron services with OVS

Change-Id: Ib07ab797723cb71ba9952e85890cb81f937bc938
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/08/108308/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =============================================== Chaining of basic Networking services with OVS =============================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/ovs-chaining In the present OpenStack implementation basic network orchestration services like L2 Population, MacLearning are using OpenvSwitch (OVS). But going forward more and more services are looking to leverage OVS, like Security Groups, DVR etc. This significantly adds to number of flows that get added in an OVS instance which adversely impacts performance, scalability and troubleshooting. This blueprint proposes a solution to address the above mentioned problem. Problem description =================== Currently, various OpenStack Neutron services use Integration Bridge and/or Tunnel Bridge/Physical Bridge which are two OVS instances running on the Host OS. This creates following key problem points: 1. As more and more services add flows to same instance likelihood for conflict between flows also increases. Flow conflicts become trickier to troubleshoot as size and complexity of flows increases. 2. If something goes wrong it is difficult to isolate the service that added the flow that led to failure. Large no. of flows from very different services lead to a troubleshooting nightmare. 3. In current model anyone working on a feature/service that uses any of the existing bridges has to be aware of other features that use the same. It limits the flexibility and freedom when designing new solutions. Proposed change =============== Were proposing isolating each core service that uses an OpenvSwitch instance to its own OVS Bridge. Chaining of basic networking services requires a separate OVS bridge for each of services that use OVS and chains them together. The order of services will be same as it is in current model. Today the order is maintained by order of Tables in an OVS bridge where each service adds its flows. Each service will specify the ports [patch-ports] that its OVS bridge expects/provides. Any new service will fall into one of the two categories * Services that traditionally would go in Integration bridge. These will require one port per VIF on tenant side. * Services that traditionally would go in Phy/Tunnel Bridge. These will require one patch port to service bridge before them. With each service having its own OVS bridge, each services flows are isolated from others there will not be any more conflicts across services. If something goes wrong one can easily identify point of failure by tracing data path through different service instances. The OVS bridge at which failure occurred or wrong flow is found will be the smoking gun that will help identify the guilty service. Following diagram explains the service chaining model using security_bridge, maclearn_bridge and tunnel_bridge as hypothetical examples. asciiflow:: +-----+ +-----+ +-----+ +-----+ |vif1 | |vif2 | |vif3 | |vif1 | +--+--+ +--+--+ +--+--+ +--+--+ | | | | +--------+--------+--------+--------+--------------+ | | | | | | | +-+-+ +-+-+ +-+-+ +-+-+ | | +-+p1 +----+p2 +----+p3 +----+p4 +------+ | | | +---+ +---+ +---+ +---+ | | | | security_bridge | | | | +---+ +---+ +---+ +---+ | | | +-+p5 +----+p6 +----+p7 +----+p8 +------+ | | +-+-+ +-+-+ +-+-+ +-+-+ | | | | | | | | +-+-+ +-+-+ +-+-+ +-+-+ | | +-+p1 +----+p2 +----+p3 +----+p4 +------+ | | | +---+ +---+ +---+ +---+ | | | | maclearn_bridge | | | | +---+ +---+ +---+ +---+ | | | +-+p5 +----+p6 +----+p7 +----+p8 +------+ | | +-+-+ +-+-+ +-+-+ +-+-+ | | | | | | | | +-+-+ +-+-+ +-+-+ +-+-+ | | +-+p1 +----+p2 +----+p3 +----+p4 +------+ | | | +---+ +---+ +---+ +---+ | | | | ..N bridges.. | | | | +---+ | | | +---------------+p5 +-------------------+ | | +-+-+ | | | | | +-+-+ | | +---------------+p1 +-------------------+ | | | +---+ | | | | ..N bridges.. | | | | +---+ | | | +---------------+p2 +-------------------+ | | +-+-+ | | | | | | | | +-+-+ | | +---------------+p1 +-------------------+ | | | +---+ | | | | Tunnel Bridge | | | | +---+ | | | +---------------+p2 +-------------------+ | | +-+-+ | | | Compute Host | +----------------------+---------------------------+ | +------+-------+ | physical | | interface | +--------------+ Alternatives ------------ 1. Bridge-per-VIF One alternative is to use multiple bridges, one per VIF and use it to host multiple services. Each bridge will host multiple services applied on that VIF. This design basically replaces Linux bridges with OVS bridges. This model can still be considered but doesn't provide service isolation. All it does is move services from Integration Bridge to a *Policy Bridge*. The issue of multiple services using same bridge will still exist. This was not considered because it doesn't address the root problem and because OVS currently allows 256 bridges, which limits the no. of VIFs that can be present on a host. One solution that can be used here is to use bridge-per-vif only for first service that interfaces directly to bridges (e.g. security_bridge in above diagram). 2. Bridge per tenant network/subnet This combines the two approaches by using a single bridge for all VIFs that belong to same tenant network. This provides tenant data isolation and doesn't use as many bridges as bridge-per-vif. Data model impact ----------------- None. REST API impact --------------- None. Security impact --------------- None. Notifications impact -------------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ Adding multiple bridges or patch ports to an OpenVswitch DP instance doesn't have any performance impact on data packets. There might be a slight increase in setup time when ports are added/deleted/updated as those changes will be made to multiple bridges. Other deployer impact --------------------- This will require some changes to way OVS bridges are configured. Exact changes are not finalized yet and will be decided based on community feedback. One solution could be to use bridge_mappings. Developer impact ---------------- Developer impact will be limited to Neutron developers working on features that use OVS bridges. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: vthapar Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- This doesn't add any new feature, more about doing existing things differently. Implementation is mostly in ovs_neutron_agent.py Key high level tasks include: * Refactor code to dynamically configure OVS bridges based on configuration and create patch-ports. * Refactor code that uses existing OVS bridges to support new service bridges. Additionally, a prototype implementation of OVS Firewall using a Security bridge that also eliminates use of Linux bridges is planned. Dependencies ============ None. Testing ======= Appropriate unit and tempest test cases will be added and modified. Documentation Impact ==================== Configuration changes will be captured in documentation. References ========== * Juno Design Summit session - https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/juno-neutron-modular-l2-agent

commit_message:
Add log translation hints for neutron

Current oslo libraries support translating log messages using different
translation domains and oslo would like to see hints in all of our code
by the end of juno. So neutron should handle the changes out over the
release.Relate info about log translation hints as follows:
    https://blueprints.launchpad.net/oslo/+spec/log-messages-translation-domain-rollout
    https://review.openstack.org/#/c/70455

blueprint support-log-translation-hints

Change-Id: I7a44c0c525d700d4e6ad089e17fb1801fdf6f6d9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/51/105951/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ===================================== Add log translation hints for neutron ===================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/support-log-translation-hints To update neutron log messages to take advantage of oslo's new feature of supporting translating log messages using different translation domains. Problem description =================== Current oslo libraries support translating log messages using different translation domains and oslo would like to see hints in all of our code by the end of juno. So neutron should handle the changes out over the release. Proposed change =============== Since there are too many files need to change, so divide this bp into 20 patches according to neutron directories:: neutron  agent  api  cmd  common  db  debug  extensions  hacking  notifiers  openstack  plugins  scheduler  server  services  tests For each directory's files, we change all the log messages as follows. 1. Change "LOG.exception(_(" to "LOG.exception(_LE". 2. Change "LOG.warn(_(" to "LOG.warn(_LW(". 3. Change "LOG.info(_(" to "LOG.info(_LI(". 4. Change "LOG.critical(_(" to "LOG.info(_LC(". Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Pipeline impact --------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance/Scalability Impacts ------------------------------- None Other deployer impact --------------------- Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: ling-yun<zengyunling@huawei.com> Work Items ---------- For each directory's files, we change all the log messages as follows. 1. Change "LOG.exception(_(" to "LOG.exception(_LE". 2. Change "LOG.warn(_(" to "LOG.warn(_LW(". 3. Change "LOG.info(_(" to "LOG.info(_LI(". 4. Change "LOG.critical(_(" to "LOG.info(_LC(". We handle these changes in the following order:: neutron neutron/agent neutron/api neutron/cmd neutron/common neutron/db neutron/debug neutron/extensions neutron/hacking neutron/notifiers neutron/openstack neutron/plugins neutron/scheduler neutron/server neutron/services neutron/tests Add a HACKING check rule to ensure that log messages to relative domain. Using regular expression to check whether log messages with relative _L* function. :: log_translation_domain_error = re.compile( r"(.)*LOG\.error\(\s*_LE\(('|\")") log_translation_domain_info = re.compile( r"(.)*LOG\.info\(\s*_LI\(('|\")") log_translation_domain_warn = re.compile( r"(.)*LOG\.(warn|warning)\(\s*_LW\(('|\")") log_translation_domain_critical = re.compile( r"(.)*LOG\.critical\(\s*_LC\(('|\")") Future lifecycle ================ None Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= None Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== [1]https://blueprints.launchpad.net/oslo/+spec/log-messages-translation-domain-rollout [2]https://review.openstack.org/#/c/70455 [3]https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/LoggingStandards

commit_message:
Action support for security group rule

Security Group is an widely used extension in the OpenStack.
The model is widely used and get familiar with many users.
Basically, the security group will only support ALLOW action
and it's limited.
In this blueprint, we are going to support more ACTIONS including DENY,
ALLOW_CONNECTION and APPLY_SERVICE. We will also
add new attributes for rule such as *priority*
in rule in order to support these attributes.

Change-Id: I01eac77d07972ec1c941d2fb8691beee0dab9c9a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/12/93112/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Action support for security group ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/security-group-action Problem description =================== Security Group is a core functionalies in the openstack. The model is widly used and get famillier with many users. Basically, the security group will only supports ALLOW action and it's limited. In this bp, we are going to support more ACTIONS including DENY, ALLOW_CONNECTION, QoS and APPLY_SERVICE. We will Also add new attributes for rule such as *priority* in rule in order to support these attributes. Here is a usecase description. This is a typical web 3tire application. An application Developer want to apply some filtering rule, IDS and QoS for web applications. .. blockdiag:: blockdiag usecase1 { orientation = portrait internet -> allow_port_80 -> apply_ids -> apply_qos -> web_application; group{ allow_port_80 -> apply_ids -> apply_qos } apply_qos -> web_application; web_application -> allow_mysql_port -> database; group{ allow_mysql_port } allow_port_80 [shape='roundedbox'] apply_ids [shape='roundedbox'] apply_qos [shape='roundedbox'] allow_mysql_port [shape='roundedbox'] } If we realize this usecase in the today's neutron. Network looks like this form. .. blockdiag:: blockdiag usecase_in_neutron { orientation = portrait internet -> router1 -> dmz_network -> security_group_ids -> ids_vm; dmz_network -> router2 -> frontend_network -> security_group_web ->ACTION web_application_vm; frontend_network -> router3 -> backend_network; backend_network -> security_group_db -> db_vm; } (NOTE: there is no qos support yet today) The goal of this bp is simplify this model. .. blockdiag:: blockdiag security_group_action { orientation = portrait security_group_internet -> security_group_web -> security_group_db; security_group_internet <- internet_network; security_group_web <- web_network <- web_vm; security_group_db <- db_network <- db_vm; } Proposed change =============== Alternatives ------------ If user is using security group, and he want to apply additional action for the existing one. There is no altertives. Data model impact ----------------- This extension add two mapping database tables. This table will be added in migration. Please see Rest API impact for the useage of this data models. :: class SecurityGroupRuleActionBinding(model_base.BASEV2): security_group_rule_id = sa.Column(sa.String(36), sa.ForeignKey("securitygrouprules.id", ondelete="CASCADE"), nullable=False) action = sa.Column(sa.Enum('ALLOW', 'DENY', 'ALLOW_CONNECTION', 'APPLY_SERVICE' name='securitygrouprules_action')) action_value = sa.Column(sa.PickleType()) priority = sa.Column(sa.Integer()) security_group_rule = orm.relationship( SecurityGroupRule, backref=orm.backref('action', cascade='all,delete'), primaryjoin="SecurityGroupRule.id==SecurityGroupRuleActionBinding.security_group_rule_id") :: class SecurityGroupNetworkBinding(model_base.BASEV2): network_id = sa.Column(sa.String(36), sa.ForeignKey("networks.id", ondelete='CASCADE'), primary_key=True) security_group_id = sa.Column(sa.String(36), sa.ForeignKey("securitygroups.id"), primary_key=True) # Add a relationship to the Port model in order to instruct SQLAlchemy to # eagerly load security group bindings networks = orm.relationship( models_v2.Network, backref=orm.backref("security_groups", lazy='joined', cascade='delete')) REST API impact --------------- In this bp, we will add following new attributes for secuirty_group_rule model. :: 'security_group_rules': { 'action': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'is_visible': True, 'default': 'ALLOW', 'convert_to': convert_action}, 'action_value': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'is_visible': True, 'default': None}, 'priority': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'convert_to': convert_to_int, 'default': None, 'is_visible': True} } } *action* and *action_value* will take following values ALLOW This action do same beheivior with existing security group rule. This is also default beheivior. ALLOW_CONNECTION This is similer with ALLOW action. Main difference is this action ensure routing with the remote_group_id. DENY This rule will exclude action QOS This rule apply QoS. You can specify additional qos attributes in action_value property. This is an example for action_value for QOS. :: {'type': 'ratelimit', 'kbps': "10240"} or you can specifiy id described in qos extension :: {'id': 'uuid_of_qos_resource'} APPLY_SERVICE This will apply services. reference to the service will be specified in action_value. This is an action_value example for apply_service. :: {'service_id': 'uuid_of_service', 'type': 'fwaas'} priority attributes is a int value for sort rules. Exsisting security group has only allow rules, so there is no need to sort rules. However, we are adding DENY or APPLY_SERVICE rules. so we need to sort rules. Now, Security Group Rule will be sorted this order. - priority - action DENY ALLOW QOS APPLY_SERVICE - direction - id This extension will also add new attributes for network for better support for ALLOW_CONNECTION attribute. :: 'network_id': { 'security_groups': { 'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'is_visible': True, 'default': attr.ATTR_NOT_SPECIFIED, 'convert_to': convert_to_uuid_list_or_none} } } This beheives like security_groups in network will be appended to there security_groups attributes in the port. Security impact --------------- This extension ensure full compatibility with exisiting security group implemenation, so there are no additional security impact using this extension. Notifications impact -------------------- No impact Other end user impact --------------------- This extension let neutron client allow to specify action and priorites. Also we can specify security_group for network. Performance Impact ------------------ This extension will add addional mapping tables for existing databases. However, join will be done in RDBMS, so we assume there are limited performance impact. Other deployer impact --------------------- Developer impact ---------------- - We are going to add support for ML2 plugin - Contrail support Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Nachi Ueno <nati-ueno> Work Items ---------- - extension patch - ml2 support - contrail support - qos support (added later) - service support (added later) Dependencies ============ - No dependencies Testing ======= - Unit test add security group rule with action for every action patterns update security group rule with action for evey action patterns delete security group rule with action show security group rule with action list security group rule with action add securtiy group for network remote security group from network - Tempest test rule apply actions for network check connectibility for apply_action Documentation Impact ==================== - REST API change will be documented References ========== * security groups http://docs.openstack.org/admin-guide-cloud/content/securitygroup_workflow.html

subject: Auto-associate floating IP
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-07-11 20:38:51.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs/commit/9a844d791e3971b9bc772d92dbc2443b662bcadd', 'message': 'Auto-associate floating IP

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/87/106487/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Auto-associate floating IP ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/auto-associate-floating-ip A proposal to allow the users of Neutron network service the ability to mark a network that later when ports are created, floating ips will be auto created and associated with them. This is nova parity feature item. Problem description =================== The Tenant Administrator wants to specify for a specific network that floating ips will be auto created and associated with the new ports created on this network (during new VM boot for example) In Nova this is a sistem wide flag. In Neutron this flag should be specified on network level and floating IPs should be associated during port creation. For floating IPs creation a router with set getway is needed too. Also public network for the floating ips should be specified. Proposed change =============== Add new auto_assoc_float_ip boolean flag in subnet. Add auto_assoc_public_net_id to subnet. When a new router interface is added a new api flag auto_assoc_floating_ip can be provided together with auto_assoc_public_net_id to provide public network for the new floating ips. If the router does not have gateway the operation should fail with 400 Delete of external network that has auto associate subnets should fail During port creationion on marked subnets, a new floating ip should be created and associated with the port. Creating floatingip should be the first step and if it fails we should fail the port creation too. During port delete on marked subnet, the associated floating ip should be deleted too. Alternatives ------------ Another alternative to manage auto associate floating IPs is to be done on the orchestration side during vm creatinons. Data model impact ----------------- New autoassociate_fip attribute on susbnet. New autoassociate_fip_external_net_id attribute on subnet REST API impact --------------- Security impact --------------- Describe any potential security impact on the system. Some of the items to consider include: * Does this change touch sensitive data such as tokens, keys, or user data? no * Does this change alter the API in a way that may impact security, such as a new way to access sensitive information or a new way to login? no * Does this change involve cryptography or hashing? no * Does this change require the use of sudo or any elevated privileges? no * Does this change involve using or parsing user-provided data? This could be directly at the API level or indirectly such as changes to a cache layer. no * Can this change enable a resource exhaustion attack, such as allowing a single API interaction to consume significant server resources? Some examples of this include launching subprocesses for each connection, or entity expansion attacks in XML. no Notifications impact -------------------- Other end user impact --------------------- Aside from the API, are there other ways a user will interact with this feature? * Does this change have an impact on python-neutronclient? What does the user interface there look like? These API calls need to be added to neutron client too Performance Impact ------------------ Other deployer impact --------------------- Developer impact ---------------- Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Simeon Monov <sdmonov> Other contributors: Work Items ---------- Dependencies ============ Testing ======= Documentation Impact ==================== References ==========

commit_message:
Support for netconf based FWaaS Appliance

Documentation for the Blueprint
Neutron-host-plug-in-for-Virtual-Edge-Firewall-appliance
with-NETCONF-interface-for-configuring-policies.

This blueprint implements a Virtual Firewall appliance
with NETCONF standard.

Implements: blueprint tcs-fwaas-netconf-host-plugin
Change-Id: I6932342997bd6c7127dae453b505d7b0b45f43a4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/04/98104/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ======================================================================================================== Neutron host plug-in for Virtual Edge Firewall appliance with NETCONF interface for configuring policies ======================================================================================================== Launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/tcs-fwaas-netconf-host-plugin This blueprint aims to provide a host-plugin for supporting orchestration and configuration of a virtual edge firewall appliance in an Openstack cloud. Neutron service plug-in with integrated NETCONF client will be built. The solution aims to provide a YANG standard based NETCONF interface for configuring virtual applicances over SSH using NETCONF. The needed YANG model can be generated and same can be used by both client and server. Problem description =================== Current FWaaS supports Linux ip tables based Firewall rules. There should be a mechanism to launch commercial FW appliances on Virtual machines and configure them using NETCONF Proposed change =============== The diagram below provides a high level overview of how the FW-appliance-aS will integrate into neutron. The FWaaS plugin has been modified to launch a VM with the specified parameters in the neutron.conf file. A complete new NETCONF agent that runs on every host has been added. This driver that has a NETCONF client runs on the agent. Also, Nova api plugin has been introduced to access nova api call in neutron. ++ | | | | | | | Neutron Server with | | FW-appliance-aS enabled | | | +++ | | FWaaS plugin | | | (modified) | | Neutron DB | ++ ++ | | | Nova plugin | | | ++++++++ | | | | | | | | | ++ | | | | +++ | | | | | Nova Server | | | | | +++ | | | | | +++++ | | | | NETCONF server ++ | | | ++ | | | | Firewall Instance | | | | | | | | | ++ | | | | | | | HOST 1 ++ | | | | NETCONF Client ++ | | ++ | | | | | | | NETCONF Agent & Driver ++ | | | +++ The FW-appliance-aS has the modified FWaaS plugin that launches the firewall VM from the neutron, when a firewall is created. At the same time, the firewall logical instance in neutron is updated to the database with the firewall VM ID. The major change from the FWaaS has been proposed with the NETCONF Agent and Driver. The Agent is invoked when a firewall instance is created and generates the following workflow: * The agent initialises the driver object that connects to the Firewall VM launched. * Once, the Firewall VM is in active state and the startup scripts are ready on the VM, the agent invokes the driver to execute the firewall commands that configure the logical firewall specified on this VM. * The driver object runs the specified commands on the NETCONF server on the VM, via an instance of NETCONF client(yangcli) which communicates with server through ssh. Alternatives ------------ The firewall can be also realised with the fwaas plugin which uses ip tables to configure the ingress/egress packet flows on the host. However, service chaining cannot be incorporated with this implementation. Further, the user could make a selection of a firewall of his choice, with the FW-appliance-aS. Also, FW-appliance-aS supports the NETCONF protocol for configuring the firewall which is widely used. Data model impact ----------------- No existing models are changed. However, for the firewall model the way the firewall ID is set has been changed. The server ID of the launched firewall VM is assigned as the ID for the firewall, else a uuid generator is invoked to generate a random uuid for the firewall. REST API impact --------------- None. Security impact --------------- None. Notifications impact -------------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ The performance of fwaas driver is not impacted by incorporation of new NETCONF agent and driver. However, the time for the firewall to become 'ACTIVE' could be increased and solely depends on the Host machine. Other deployer impact --------------------- The deployer must run the binary FW-appliance-aS and change the neutron.conf, fwaas_driver.ini to allow launch of firewall VM and enable to the run the service: * Name, Image ID, Internal Network IDs, External Network IDs, flavor for launching the firewall appliance. * Username and password to login into the firewall instance and execute yangcli commands in fwaas_driver.ini file under group "FW_appliance_creds". * NETCONF driver path and enable service paramaters in fwaas_driver.ini with the group "fw_app". * nova parameters to connect to the nova api from neutron, which include nova api class and nova credentials in neutron.conf. The following configuration parameters group in neutron.conf file. :: [fw_appliance] Name = <firewall-vm-name> Image = <Image-ID> Flavor = <Flavor-ID> Net = <External Network ID> Gateway_Net = <Internal Network IDs> Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Hemanth Nakkina Anirudh Vedantam Work Items ---------- The work is split up into two parts: 1. FWaaS plugin modification, NETCONF agent, NETCONF Driver and FW-appliance-aS binary. * The modifications on the neutron plugin would enable the firewall VM to be launched from Neutron FWaaS plugin. * A complete new Agent for the communication between the Plugin and the Driver has been provided. The Driver the invokes the yangcli binary(NETCONF client) is also provided 2. NETCONF Driver, and YANG model on NETCONF Server. * The Driver the invokes the yangcli binary(NETCONF client) is provided. The YANG model is the logical firewall specification, to be implemented on the Firewall appliance is provided on NETCONF server Dependencies ============ The following are the new library requirements to be installed: * libxml2-dev * libssh2.1.dev * libncurses5.dev * libz-dev * debhelper Testing ======= The code will be covered with unit tests. For tempest test coverage, third party testing is provided. Documentation Impact ==================== Configuration details will be updated. References ========== None.

commit_message:
Neutron Extension for BGPVPN

The Blueprint defines a set of APIs required to interconnect a
OpenStack virtual-network with an l3-VPN network as defined by RFC4364
(BGP/MPLS Virtual Private Networks).
L3VPN network is widely used in industry especially for enterprise.
This extension will support eVPN based L2VPN which is also widely used.

Change-Id: I73900d0aa083daddc6bef940b1cb6c0945b8884a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/29/93329/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Neutron Extension for L3VPN ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/neutron-l3-vpn Problem description =================== The Blueprint defines a set of APIs required to interconnect a OpenStack virtual-network with an L3VPN network as defined by RFC4364 (BGP/MPLS Virtual Private Networks). L3VPN network is widely used in industry especially for enterprise. This is a usecase 1. In this usecase, there are yellow tenant and green tenant. Both tenants has a external sites, and they are going to connect a neutron network for their site using L3VPN. .. blockdiag:: blockdiag usecase1 { NeutronNetwork1 <-> L3VPNConnection1 <-> L3VPNNetwork; NeutronNetwork2 <-> L3VPNConnection2 <-> L3VPNNetwork; L3VPNNetwork <-> L3VPN_PE1 <-> Site1; L3VPNNetwork <-> L3VPN_PE2 <-> Site2; L3VPNNetwork [shape=cloud]; NeutronNetwork1 [color=yellow]; L3VPNConnection1 [color=yellow]; L3VPN_PE1 [color=yellow]; Site1 [color=yellow]; NeutronNetwork2 [color=green]; L3VPNConnection2 [color=green]; L3VPN_PE2 [color=green]; Site2 [color=green]; } Proposed change =============== Alternatives ------------ IPsec VPN and SSL-VPNs are vpn alternatives. However, they can't fix large scale enterprise networking who need dynamic routing in multiple data centers. Data model impact ----------------- We are going to add new L3VPNConnection resources. L3VPNConnection will have reference to Network. In L3VPN, we identify a vpn using route target identifier. L3VPNConnection is a relationship with Neutron and route target. .. blockdiag:: blockdiag l3vpnconnection { Network <- L3VPNConnection; } Deletion for associated network should be prohibited by a proper exception. Here is a conceptual model relationship with L3VPN terminology. VRFs (Virtual Routing and Forwarding) in PE can import/export route target. If a VRF imports route target, associated route will be imported. If a VRF exports route target, route in the VRF will be associated and exported with route target. Same thing will happen for the Neutron network. .. blockdiag:: blockdiag { Network1 -> L3VPNConnection1 -> RouteTargetYellow <- VRF1 <-> Site1; Network2 -> L3VPNConnection2 -> RouteTargetGreen <- VRF2 <-> Site2; } REST API impact --------------- This is a description of l3vpn connection. One of route_target, import_target or export_target options must be defined. The common use case is for l3vpn connectivity to use a single bi-directional route-target. However it is possible to have the auto-aggregate flag controls whether or not routes should be automatically aggregated at the OpenStack cluster boundary, when advertised to an external network. .. csv-table:: L3VPNConnection :header: Attribute Name,Type,Access,Default Value,Validation/Constraint,Description id,uuid-str,R,Generated,UUID_PATTERN,id of L3VPNConnection resource network_id,uuid-str,RW,None,N/A,network id associated with route target route_target,list(str),RW admin only,N/A,List of valid route-target strings.<as#>:32bit-number,route target will be import/export import_target,list(str),RW admin only,N/A,List of valid route-target strings.<as#>:32bit-number,route targets will be imported export_target,list(str),RW admin only,N/A,List of valid route-target strings.<as#>:32bit-number,route targets will be exported auto_aggregate,bool,RW admin only,TRUE,{ True | False },enable aggreation or not We will have a database table for L3VPNConnection and a proper migration scripts. Security impact --------------- L3VPNConnection impacts external connectivity. In addition, network operators don't won't expose actual route target value for the users. so, workflow for L3VPNConnection will be followings. * Network operator creates L3VPNConnection for a tenant based on contract. Network id can be None in this stage. * A tenant will associate L3VPNConnection with a network. Notifications impact -------------------- A Service plug-in should send CRUD event notification of the L3VPNConnection. Other end user impact --------------------- We are also going to add support for this in python-neutornclient. Here is a list of command we will have :: neutron l3vpn-connection-create --network-id <uuid> --route-target list=true 64512:1,64512:2 neutron l3vpn-connection-update <l3vpn id> neutron l3vpn-connection-list neutron l3vpn-connection-delete <l3vpn id> Performance Impact ------------------ L3VPNConnection table will have a table relationship for Network. Especially speaking, we need additional check when we try to delete network. Other deployer impact --------------------- Reference implementation will use opencontrail. Developer impact ---------------- * Reference implementation will use opencontrail, so contrail plug-in need to be merged and suppering this extension. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Nachi Ueno <nati-ueno> Other contributors: Pedro Marques Work Items ---------- - L3VPNConnection API Extension - contrail plug-in support Dependencies ============ * opencontrail plug-in `:doc:opencontrail-plugin.rst` should be merged Testing ======= UT * CRUD for L3VPNConnection Tempest * Connection between two sites Documentation Impact ==================== The use of L3VPNConnection should be documented References ========== * RFC4364 BGP/MPLS IP Virtual Private Networks (VPNs) http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4364 * opencontrail plug-in `:doc:opencontrail-plugin.rst`

commit_message:
Traffic Steering blueprint

Blueprint traffic-steering-abstraction

Change-Id: Ia7ff3146a83dfbbf520ac049384f9bcd53ce11cd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/77/92477/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Traffic Steering Abstraction for Neutron ========================================== Launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/traffic-steering-abstraction A lower level imperative abstraction which allows specifying that traffic be steered between an ordered list of Neutron ports. The traffic can be further subject to L2/L3 classification criteria. This abstraction can be leveraged to realize service chaining, and is particularly helpful in chaining services that are not known to Neutron and only manifest as Neutron ports (e.g. a user managed service VM). Problem description =================== OpenStack Neutron provides users the ability to instantiate and manage network services in an easy and convenient way through well-defined REST APIs. Resources are pooled and allocated to tenants with no human interaction besides users themselves requesting the service. As of now, OpenStack delivers four network service types: L3 routing, firewall as a service (FWaaS), load balancer as a service (LBaaS) and VPN as a Service (VPNaaS). Each of these types can be provided by multiple drivers available (e.g., iptables and vArmour for FWaaS; HAProxy, Netscaler and Radware for LBaaS). Even though the OpenStack Neutron community has been doing a tremendous effort on keeping up with users demand on introducing new Neutron network service types and Neutron network service providers, it is nevertheless unfeasible in the long run to continue attending demands at this pace in a timely manner. There are several network service types OpenStack could contemplate in the future as Neutron network services (e.g. deep packet inspection (DPI), intrusion detection and prevention systems (IDS/IPS)), but several others that it will probably never contemplate (e.g. Evolved Packet Core (EPC), IP Multimedia Subsystem (IMS)). Either way, OpenStack should provide a strong foundation for the deployment of network services, whether natively or not. In other words, OpenStack can in fact have embedded network services (Neutron network services) as it already has and continue to explore them, but it should also provide the foundations for network services to be deployed within OpenStack without the platform knowing the service itself. The momentum around the Network Functions Virtualization (NFV) concept, primarily lead by a dedicated ETSI Industry Specification Group (ISG) [6]_, is fostering this latter fact. According to ETSI, OpenStack is well positioned to be the reference platform to play the Virtual Infrastructure Manager (VIM) role in their reference architecture [4]_ [5]_. However, there are still gaps that need to be covered in order to make this possible. We believe that this blueprint identifies and tries to fill part of this gap. Given the limited collection of network services types and providers Neutron provides, it is currently not possible to deploy a network service software of any type or provider in a machine (virtual or bare metal machine) instance that Neutron does not support, and hook it at strategically placed points on the network. An example is the deployment of a DPI instance running on a machine connected to a Neutron network and place it in between an edge router and a private network where tenants machines are connected. Inbound/outbound traffic should be intercepted and steered to the machine running the DPI instance first and then forwarding it to the original destination. The same scenario can be applied to a firewall, IDS and IPS. The term Service Function Chain (SFC) is today widely referred within the NFV context (also referred by Virtual Network Function (VNF) Forwarding Graph within the ETSI NFV ISG). It is considered to be a key functionality in this context, and therefore prone to be considered as available in OpenStack. However, the first drawback lays on the fact that there is no formal definition for it [3]_, only proposals - e.g. [7]_. IETF has created a dedicated Working Group for this purpose [9]_ which is still in an early stage. Nevertheless, the OpenStack Neutron blueprint "Neutron Services Insertion, Chaining, and Steering" [1]_ already provides what we consider to be a good reference definition for SFC. The drawback that we find in this Blueprint lays on the fact that: i) it seems to limit chaining to the embedded OpenStack Neutron services; ii) traffic steering according to traffic classification is not contemplated. We argue that a broader way to define a SFC should be available. Proposed change =============== Every Neutron network services and machines are connected to a Neutron network via Neutron ports. A traffic steering model that covers both network services and machines should be possible. Neutron network services and machines should have no notion of traffic steering. Rather a traffic steering model only knows Neutron ports and so being agnostic to whats connected to the network in the form of ports. This leads to a Traffic Steering Neutron port-oriented approach. Such an approach can: * Allow traffic to be forwarded between Neutron ports (network services and machines) according to traffic classification. In this way a tenant can specify a "personalized" chaining sequence according to the type of traffic. * Leverage what is currently being considered in the SFC Neutron advanced service-oriented approach [1]_. It is up to the user to instantiate the network service by provisioning a machine and configuring the network service software in it, making sure it is attached to a Neutron network. Note that a port can be associated to more than one chain (and steering) instance allowing a service/VM instance to be part of multiple chains. The work in [1]_ will have to address traffic steering at Neutron port level at some extent. The work herein proposed shares such same low-level network logic. For that reason, we see the work in [1]_ as a higher-level abstraction that could be built as an extension on top of this work. It could potentially address specific Neutron network services needs, which should be analysed separately. Another important aspect of SFC lays on the definition of the traffic/packet flow(s) that will transverse a SFC. At this point it is important to highlight the fact that there can be "active" and "passive" functions. We refer to a function as "active" when the function has the ability to change packets (e.g. NAT, VPN, router) and passive when it does not (e.g. FW, DPI, WOC). This raises the question of what might be the notion of traffic/packet flow in a SFC within OpenStack. At this point we see two options: 1. A flow is a set of classifiers that are the same along all hops of a chain - this may imply that in certain cases a chain may need to be forced to end due to an "active" function because this latter function changes the packet and it can no longer be "mapped" to the flow policy initially associated to the chain. Although this might be a limiting factor, it is a "keep it simple" approach. 2. A flow is a set of classifiers defined per hop along the chain - allows to define a chain with "active" and "passive" functions with no restrictions. An eventual implementation of this option could allow an easy way to define the same classifiers to all ports (as in option 1). Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- The herein proposed abstraction introduces two new data models:: +---------+ +------------+ | Port | | Classifier | | Chain +-------+ | +---------+ +------------+ Port Chain: +-----------+-------+---------+---------+------------+--------------+ |Attribute |Type |Access |Default |Validation/ |Description | |Name | | |Value |Conversion | | +===========+=======+=========+=========+============+==============+ |id |string |RO, all |generated|N/A |identity | | |(UUID) | | | | | +-----------+-------+---------+---------+------------+--------------+ |name |string |RW, all |'' |string |human-readable| | | | | | |name | +-----------+-------+---------+---------+------------+--------------+ |description|string |RW, all | '' |string | | | | | | | | | +-----------+-------+---------+---------+------------+--------------+ |tenant_id |string |RO, all |from auth|N/A | | | |(UUID) | |token | | | +-----------+-------+---------+---------+------------+--------------+ |ports |list |RW, all |[] | |list of lists | | |(list) | | | |of ports | +-----------+-------+---------+---------+------------+--------------+ |classifiers|list |RW, all |[] | |list of | | |(UUID) | | | |classifiers | +-----------+-------+---------+---------+------------+--------------+ Classifier: +-----------+-------+---------+---------+------------+--------------+ |Attribute |Type |Access |Default |Validation/ |Description | |Name | | |Value |Conversion | | +===========+=======+=========+=========+============+==============+ |id |string |RO, all |generated|N/A |identity | | |(UUID) | | | | | +-----------+-------+---------+---------+------------+--------------+ |name |string |RW, all |'' |string |human-readable| | | | | | |name | +-----------+-------+---------+---------+------------+--------------+ |description|string |RW, all |'' |string | | | | | | | | | +-----------+-------+---------+---------+------------+--------------+ |tenant_id |string |RO, all |from auth|N/A | | | |(UUID) | |token | | | +-----------+-------+---------+---------+------------+--------------+ |type |string |RW, all |N/A |'broadcast',| | | | | | |'unicast' or| | | | | | |'multicast' | | +-----------+-------+---------+---------+------------+--------------+ |protocol |string |RW, all |N/A |'tcp', 'udp'|empty means | | | | | |or 'icmp' |allow any | +-----------+-------+---------+---------+------------+--------------+ |port_min |integer|RW, all | |1-65535 | | +-----------+-------+---------+---------+------------+--------------+ |port_max |integer|RW, all | |1-65535 | | +-----------+-------+---------+---------+------------+--------------+ |src_ip |string |RW, all |N/A |IP address | | +-----------+-------+---------+---------+------------+--------------+ |dst_ip |string |RW, all |N/A |IP address | | +-----------+-------+---------+---------+------------+--------------+ REST API impact --------------- A new API extension is going to be introduced. Base URL for the Traffic Steering API is /v2.0/traffic_steering/ The following new resources are being introduced: .. code-block:: python RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTE_MAP = { 'port_chains': { 'id': {'allow_post': False, 'allow_put': False, 'validate': {'type:uuid': None}, 'is_visible': True}, 'tenant_id': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': False, 'required_by_policy': True, 'is_visible': True}, 'name': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'validate': {'type:string': None}, 'is_visible': True, 'default': ''}, 'description': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'validate': {'type:string': None}, 'is_visible': True, 'default': ''}, 'ports': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'validate': {'type:uuid_list': None}, 'convert_to': attr.convert_none_to_empty_list, 'is_visible': True}, 'classifiers': { 'id': {'allow_post': False, 'allow_put': False, 'validate': {'type:uuid': None}, 'is_visible': True}, 'tenant_id': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': False, 'required_by_policy': True, 'is_visible': True}, 'name': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'validate': {'type:string': None}, 'is_visible': True, 'default': ''}, 'description': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'validate': {'type:string': None}, 'is_visible': True, 'default': ''}, 'type': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'validate': {'type:string': None}, 'is_visible': True}, 'protocol': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'validate': {'type:string': None}, 'is_visible': True}, 'port_range': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'validate': {'type:port_range': None}, 'convert_to': convert_port_to_string, 'default': None, 'is_visible': True}, 'src_ip': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'validate': {'type:ip_address_or_none': None}, 'is_visible': True}, 'dst_ip': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'validate': {'type:ip_address_or_none': None}, 'is_visible': True}, }, } The following new API methods are being introduced: +-----------+--------------------------------+----------------------+ |Object |URI |Type | +===========+================================+======================+ |Port Chain |/port_chains +GET | +-----------+--------------------------------+----------------------+ |Port Chain |/port_chains +POST | +-----------+--------------------------------+----------------------+ |Port Chain |/port_chain/{id} +GET | +-----------+--------------------------------+----------------------+ |Port Chain |/port_chain/{id} +PUT | +-----------+--------------------------------+----------------------+ |Port Chain |/port_chain/{id} +DELETE | +-----------+--------------------------------+----------------------+ |Classifier |/classifiers +GET | +-----------+--------------------------------+----------------------+ |Classifier |/classifiers +POST | +-----------+--------------------------------+----------------------+ |Classifier |/classifier/{id} +GET | +-----------+--------------------------------+----------------------+ |Classifier |/classifier/{id} +PUT | +-----------+--------------------------------+----------------------+ |Classifier |/classifier/{id} +DELETE | +-----------+--------------------------------+----------------------+ Examples ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Get Classifier: .. code-block:: json GET /classifier/40ace3ed-02b6-421a-b54d-80e3a5dac9c9.json Accept: application/json { "id": "40ace3ed-02b6-421a-b54d-80e3a5dac9c9", "name": "HTTP-classifier", "description": "All HTTP traffic", "tenant_id": "27971046c25a40d2bb2e21467ab62a76", "type": "unicast", "protocols": ["tcp"], "ports": [80, 443, 8080], "dst_ip": "10.0.0.100", } Create Port Chain: .. code-block:: json POST /port_chains.json Content-Type: application/json Accept: application/json { "name": "chain1", "ports": [ [ "681fedb8-342d-4891-93e5-d9f618c0a2da", "18a50d57-37bd-44bf-be47-bf921207f203", "3363f633-7d84-46f5-b497-d6b41464ccfc" ], [ "18a50d57-37bd-44bf-be47-bf921207f203", "299b25fd-968d-466b-ab46-bf4667c8cbd5" ], ] "classifiers": ["40ace3ed-02b6-421a-b54d-80e3a5dac9c9"], } Security impact --------------- * Does this change touch sensitive data such as tokens, keys, or user data? No * Does this change alter the API in a way that may impact security, such as a new way to access sensitive information or a new way to login? No * Does this change involve cryptography or hashing? No * Does this change require the use of sudo or any elevated privileges? No * Does this change involve using or parsing user-provided data? This could be directly at the API level or indirectly such as changes to a cache layer. Yes * Can this change enable a resource exhaustion attack, such as allowing a single API interaction to consume significant server resources? Some examples of this include launching subprocesses for each connection, or entity expansion attacks in XML. Such will depend on a per traffic steering driver implementation basis. Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- Integration with the following projects would be a big plus: * python-neutronclient * Horizon * Heat * Devstack Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- The implementation of this blueprint will leverage other work also being proposed. Please refer to [12]_ for a bigger picture of how this work will stack on the Advanced Services Common Framework. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Carlos Goncalves (cgoncalves) - Launchpad blueprint assignee Joao Soares (joaosoares) Bruno Sendas (bsendas) Sumit Naiksatam (snaiksat) Work Items ---------- * API and database * Traffic steering driver interface * OVS / OpenDaylight driver for PoC * python-neutronclient Dependencies ============ This blueprint is under the umbrella of blueprint neutron-services-insertion-chaining-steering. Testing ======= Driver implementations will have to provide Tempest tests that ensures correct traffic steering rules enforcement. Documentation Impact ==================== Documentation for both administrators and end users will have to be contemplated. Administrators will need to know how to enable/disable and configure the service and end users how to consume it using the Traffic Steering API and python-neutronclient. References ========== .. commit_message:
Add IPv6 RA support in neutron

blueprint neutron-ipv6-ra
Change-Id: I4fbd265b91118fcfdec980b169eedc0684ee9b44
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/64/92164/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Enable IPv6 RA in Neutron ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/neutron-ipv6-radvd-ra With ipv4 addresses being exhausted soon, ipv6 deployments in the data center could become common practice. Currently, neutron doesn't have complete ipv6 support. This specification attempts to address ipv6 RA support in neutron. Problem description =================== In its current state, neutron dhcp and l3 service can support ipv6 (with a few bugs). However, due to lack of ipv6 RA support, ipv6 routing in VMs can not be established without manual configuration in the neutron router. In addition, it doesn't support SLAAC. The blueprint https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/ipv6-two-attributes proposes addition of two new attributes in the neutron subnet command. We'll refer it as two-attribute approach in this specification. Valid combinations of the two attributes can be found in https://www.dropbox.com/s/9bojvv9vywsz8sd/IPv6%20Two%20Modes%20v3.0.pdf. The blueprint https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/dnsmasq-ipv6-slaac and a few other relevant ones are attempting to implement the two-attribute approach in the neutron dhcp module. The two-attribute approach attempts to take advantage of dnsmasq being able to support both RA and DHCP services. A few drawbacks with the two-attribute approach are: - interpretation of the combinations are not intuitive - it requires to run one dnsmasq instance per ipv6 subnet in the router namespace or the dhcp namespace if the subnet doesn't belong to a router. - with dual stack, at least two dnsmasq instances are required, one that is running in the dhcp namespace for all ipv4 subnets, and the other(s) for the ipv6 subnet(s). This specification proposes a different approach that attempts to provide an easy-to-understand API and an easy-to-understand implementation. Proposed change =============== To our intereste, the existing neutron subnet API contains these optional arguments: - ip-version {4, 6} IP version with default 4 - dns-nameserver DNS_NAMESERVER DNS name server for this subnet - disable-dhcp Disable DHCP for this subnet To support both RA and SLAAC, we propose the addition of the following optional arguments: - ipv6-ra {on | off | slaac} Set ipv6 RA mode Note that a neutron port may be created with extra DHCP options. The dns-nameserver in the subnet, combined with the extra DHCP options in the ports that belong to the subnet, determines if there are associated configuration information to be sent to the DHCP client. We use config-items = {true, false} to indicate that in the below description. We also assume ip-version = 6 in the below discussion. The overall behavior concerning the DHCP and RA services depends on the following flags: - diable-dhcp = {true, false} - ipv6-ra {on | off | slaac} - config-items = {true, false} valid combinations are: 1. disable-dhcp = false, ipv6-ra = on, config-items = {true or flase} Both DHCP and RA are enabled. SLAAC is not enabled. config-items can be present or not. 2. disable-dhcp = false, ipv6-ra = slaac, config-items = {true or flase} Both DHCP and RA are enabled. SLAAC is enabled. config-items can be present or not. 3. disable-dhcp = false, ipv6-ra = off, config-items = {true or false} DHCP is enabled and RA is disabled. SLAAC has to be disabled since RA is not enabled. config-items can be present or not. 4. disable-dhcp = true, ipv6-ra = slaac, config-items = {true or false} DHCP is disabled and RA is enabled. SLAAC is enabled or not. DHCP extra options shouldn't be present since DHCP is disabled. 5. disable-dhcp = true, ipv6-ra = on, config-items = {true or false} DHCP is disabled and RA is enabled. SLAAC is not enabled. DHCP extra options shouldn't be present since DHCP is disabled. 6. disable-dhcp = true, ipv6-ra = off, config-items = false Both DHCP and RA are disabled. Note that neutron subnet requires explicit CIDRs/prefixes, and neutron ports always have IP addresses that are allocated from their subnets. In the above cases 5 and 6, however, since IP addresses are not obtained from neutron, the neutron allocated addresses become useless. If an RA with SLAAC is running externally, then it's possible for neutron to come up with the same EUI64 addresses. If DHCPv6 is running externally, or if RA is running externally and the addresses with SLAAC are generated with different methods (other than EUI64), or even worse, the prefix is not even known before creating a subnet, it doesn't make sense for neutron to assign IP addresses to ports. Similar issue exists with ipv4 when DHCP is not enabled on subnets. We'll not try to cover theses cases in this specification. In the following, we'll describe how to enhance neutron DHCP and L3 services in support of the above cases. How to support them in a service VM is out of the scope of this specification. case 1: Enable Both DHCP and RA Without SLAAC ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ Addresses on the subnet will be handed out by the dnsmasq instance running in the subnet's DHCP namespace. If the subnet is associated with a router, RA will be enabled for this subnet in the router namespace. RA will not advertise prefixes for this subnet. The RA message's M and O bits are set. If the subnet is not associated with a router, RA will NOT be enabled for this subnet. case 2: Enable Both DHCP and RA with SLAAC ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ Since SLAAC is enabled for the subnet, dnsmasq will not be responsible for handing out addresses. But it may be used to send configuration information depending on if the config-items are available. If the subnet is associated with a router, RA will be enabled for this subnet in the router namespace. RA will use the CIDR configured for the subnet to advertise a prefix. The RA message's M bit will not be set, but the O bit will be set. If the subnet is not associated with a router, RA will be enabled for this subnet in the subnet's DHCP namespace. The RA message's router lifetime will be set to 0. RA will use the CIDR configured for the subnet to advertise a prefix. The RA message's M bit will not be set, but the O bit will be set. case 3: Enable DHCP only ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ Addresses on the subnet will be handed out by the dnsmasq instance running in the subnet's DHCP namespace. Note that if RA is run somewhere in the network, it is outside the control of neutron. The operator needs to make sure it's configured properly. case 4: Enable RA only with SLAAC ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ Since DHCP is not enabled, the RA message's M and O bits will not be set. Extra DHCP options, if configured in any ports belonging to the subnet, will not be useful. If the subnet is associated with a router, RA will be enabled fro this subnet in the router namespace. RA will use the CIDR configured for the subnet to advertise a prefix. If the subnet is not associated with a router, the RA message's router lifetime will be set to 0. RA will use the CIDR configured for the subnet to advertise a prefix. If the subnet's DNS nameservers are configured, they will be sent in the RA message. case 5: Enable RA only without SLAAC ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ Since DHCP is not enabled, the RA message's M and O bits will not be set. Extra DHCP options, if configured in any ports belonging to the subnet, will not be useful. If the subnet is associated with a router, RA will be enabled fro this subnet in the router namespace. No prefix will be advertised. If the subnet is not associated with a router, no RA will be generated for the subnet. case 5: Disable Both DHCP and RA ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ Nothing needs to be done Alternatives ------------ - https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/ipv6-two-attributes Data model impact ----------------- The subnet model will have one new column: ipv6-ra. The migration script will be incorporated. REST API impact --------------- TBD: neutron subnet API change Security impact --------------- The change requires instantiation of radvd in either the DHCP namespace or the router namespace. And therefore sudo mode is required. Notifications impact -------------------- none Other end user impact --------------------- none Performance Impact ------------------ This change will potentially introduce one radvd instance per namespace that is created by neutron. The radvd instances may load new configuration data when interfaces are added into or removed from the namespaces. Significant system performance degradation is not expected. Other deployer impact --------------------- none Developer impact ---------------- none Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- - baoli@cisco.com - TBD Work Items ---------- - API implementation - l3_agent - dhcp agent Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= TBD Documentation Impact ==================== documentation for the subnet API References ==========
