commit_message:
Add spec for ml2-mechanism-snmp-vlan

An ML2 plugin that dynamically implements VLAN-based tenant network
separation on switches that are configurable using SNMP. This blueprint
would extend Neutron's control of VLAN membership to any physical switch
that implements SNMP write access to the standard Q-BRIDGE-MIB.

Change-Id: Ie826a6164abe765af95d75627bb05b77359f3b6e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/22/90422/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================== SNMP VLAN Mechanism driver for ML2 ================================== Launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/ml2-mechanism-snmp-vlan An ML2 plugin that dynamically implements VLAN-based tenant network separation on entry-level and established physical switch products that are configurable using SNMP. This blueprint would extend Neutron's control of VLAN membership to any physical switch that implements SNMP write access to the standard Q-BRIDGE-MIB. This blueprint also enables the VLAN type driver to be used with baremetal/Ironic deployments. Problem description =================== Many mechanism drivers offer vendor-specific interfaces to physical switch hardware. Our experience has been that OpenStack's switch hardware compatibility is limited by the narrow support of current mechanism drivers. Use of the dynamic capabilities of Neutron may require investment in a new generation of network hardware. In some cases this may be a barrier to OpenStack evaluation for prospective users. Proposed change =============== This blueprint proposes adding a mechanism driver that uses the industry standard SNMP protocol and the widely-implemented Q-BRIDGE-MIB to control VLAN membership and port VLAN configuration. As an example, this project enables OpenStack to be deployed using the ML2 VLAN type driver on basic Netgear gigabit managed switches. The mechanism driver would use PySNMP to perform the SNMP protocol reads and writes. Support for the configuration of untagged VLAN member ports would enable control of VLAN membership for bare metal compute instances. Network interfaces for hypervisor-based compute nodes would be configured as tagged members of all VLANs associated with the hosted virtual instances. In order to apply configuration to physical switches and ports using SNMP, there needs to be a method of associating Neutron virtual ports with physical switch ports. Several possibilities exist for the mechanism for maintaining this association: 1. In the manner of other Neutron drivers (such as the Cisco Nexus driver), the mapping between Neutron virtual ports and physical switch ports could be maintained in configuration files. 2. A data model could be defined for physical network entities, and this model could be populated through exposing a new REST API. 3. A dynamic protocol-based method of associating Neutron virtual ports with physical switch ports could be established, for example through use of LLDP neighbor discovery. (Note that this method would not be appropriate for bare metal compute instances). The implementation of this mechanism remains an open question and review guidance is welcome. This blueprint only proposes manipulation of edge ports on the physical network. Updating VLAN membership on trunk ports between physical switches is beyond the scope of this proposal. Alternatives ------------ There is no clear alternative mechanism with the same level of cross-vendor support. One alternative possibility would be to implement a protocol such as MVRP or GVRP in the hypervisor neutron component. This would enable VLAN memberships to be added or removed dynamically as required by changes in VTN configuration. However, this assumes a layer-2 network, and would not be able to support bare metal systems where there is no secure equivalent to the hypervisor environment. Data model impact ----------------- The SNMP ML2 driver should require no changes to existing Neutron data models. Depending on the method for associating Neutron virtual ports with physical switch ports, new data definitions may be required for switches, switch ports and bindings from Neutron virtual ports to switch ports. Switches and switch ports could be configured in the ML2 configuration file in the manner of the Cisco Nexus driver for a simpler, albeit static solution. Proposed data models: =================== ===================================================== Entity Members =================== ===================================================== Switch varchar(36) id, char hostname, char version, char community, char physical_network, boolean static_vlans Switch port varchar(36) id, varchar(36) switch_id, char name, char hostname, varchar(18) mac_address, boolean baremetal Switch port binding varchar(36) port_id, varchar(36) switch_port_id, varchar(36) switch_id, integer vlan_id =================== ===================================================== No migrations will be required as existing data models be unaffected. REST API impact --------------- Existing REST APIs are not affected. If a data model for physical network entities is included, a new REST API would be created for populating and updating a database of Neutron virtual port connectivity. Security impact --------------- To modify switch configuration through SNMP access, a writeable SNMP community is required. Depending on switch configuration, either physical connectivity to the switch management network is sufficient, or it may require storing of credentials in a manner similar to other OpenStack credentials. Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ SNMP is a stateless protocol, and may be configured to use TCP or UDP transports. Every VTN change leading to VLAN reconfiguration will result in SNMP interaction with one or more physical switches. However, the SNMP operations are lightweight in nature and the overhead incurred should be insignficant. Other deployer impact --------------------- The SNMP driver would need to be listed as an ML2 mechanism driver. A new section would be defined for the ML2 configuration file. The SNMP mechanism driver would need configuration state for the physical switches under its control, the SNMP configuration parameters for each switch, and the physical ports associated with each compute node. Developer impact ---------------- No existing functionality is affected. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Stig Telfer <stigtelfer> Work Items ---------- 1. Implement SNMP interactions for VTN creation, update and deletion. 2. Implement tagged/untagged port membership and PVID to enable support for bare metal deployments. 3. Implement support for multiple physical switches and data model for connecting physical switches and switch ports with compute nodes. 4. Implement unit tests and mocking of the PySNMP interface. 5. If a REST API is decided upon, Tempest test cases may need to be defined and implemented. Dependencies ============ This project has a dependency on PySNMP. Testing ======= The core of the project will be tested through unit tests. For system testing, access to physical switch hardware is required, which prevents adding functional tests as general cases. We will test and qualify several physical switches available to us. If a REST API is decided upon, a Tempest test suite would be added to test the added API through the population and update of physical port association with Neutron virtual ports. Documentation Impact ==================== Configuration details will need to be documented. A list of supported vendors/switches would be helpful. References ========== * Q-BRIDGE-MIB reference: http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2674 * PySNMP home page: http://pysnmp.sourceforge.net/

commit_message:
BP: Detailed status reporting for L3 Services

Blueprint to provide detailed status reporting to
the user to improve troubleshooting of issues with
L3 services.

Change-Id: Ice3a69a39cb31d27570c33c9232b2451c0d6946f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/82/88482/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Detailed Status Reporting for L3 Services ========================================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/l3-svcs-vendor-status-report If an L3 device driver (reference or vendor) encounters a problem, it can update the status (e.g. set resource to *ERROR*), but cannot indicate information on the error. This makes it harder for end-users to troubleshoot issues. Problem description =================== Typically, the only communication from the device driver (in the agent) to the service driver (in the plugin) is for reporting the status. This is one of the Neutron statuses, like ACTIVE, DOWN, PENDING_CREATE, and ERROR. There is no way to indicate details about the status, especially for error conditions. For example, for VPNaaS with a Cisco CSR device driver, if the driver is unable to authenticate with the router, or there is a timeout, all the device driver can do, is set the status to *ERROR*. There is no way for the end user to know why the requested operation, say an IPSec site-to-site connection create request, has failed. Errors can be transient (e.g. network issues/timeouts), or persistent (e.g. authentication failure, resource exhaustion, mis-configuration). Proposed change =============== This proposal involves providing a new API between the device and service driver, so that detailed status information may be passed to the plugin and then displayed to the user. The status information could be maintained in an object in the plugin, or could be stored in the database, if the desire is to persist the information. A decision needs to be made as to which storage method would be preferred. Likewise, the status could be maintained for a specific resource or resources, or for the L3 service as a whole. With the former, it can be displayed along with the resource in show and/or list requests. With the latter, a new GET API would be needed to obtain the status. It is expected that there would be a limited number of resources needing the status information (for VPNaaS, status could be associated with only the ipsec-site-connection) Corresponding client changes will be needed to support the display of the status. Alternatives ------------ The error could be printed in the log (and likely already is), but there is no way for the end user to see this information, and security concerns as well. A more difficult (and partial) solution is to attempt to automatically recover (e.g. retry failures from network connection issues or timeouts), however there are some classes of errors that are not transient, like invalid authentication credentials or exhaustion of resources. Data model impact ----------------- If the status is stored in a database table, a string field would need to be added to resources of significance, or a new data object with a string field would need to be created for the L3 service. Most likely it will be less of an impact to add the field to a resource (e.g. ipsec_site_connection for VPNaaS) and include that field in the show command, than to create a new data object and new show command. However, using a new data object may make faciliate easier reuse of logic by different L3 services. This new field/object would need to be added to migrations, but is a trivial addition. Since the data can be generated through any API operation on the device driver, the string field can be initially blank. Again, the decision must be made as to whether or not the database should be used for this information. REST API impact --------------- If the status information is associated with a resource (or resources) the REST API show and/or list APIs would need to include the additional field. If a "global" status is used for the L3 service, a new GET REST API would be needed. The response code would always be be successful (200). The URI would need to be defined for each L3 service, although code reuse can be applied as well. In both approaches, the REST requirements will be simple: a read-only attribute that is returned in response data for a GET request. TODO: Schema based on approach, and simple example. Security impact --------------- None. Notifications impact -------------------- The detailed status information is returned along with the status reporting by the device driver. Other end user impact --------------------- If the status is associated with a resource, then the corresponding show and/or list command output would be updated in python-neutronclient. If a "global" status is reported, via a new API, then a new python-neutronclient command and output would need to be implemented. Performance Impact ------------------ No performance impact is expected. Other deployer impact --------------------- No deployer impact is expected. Developer impact ---------------- Each L3 service will need to implement changes to support the display (and depending on implementation, requesting) of status information. Code can be reused, if the detailed status is reported for the L3 service as a whole. After beign upstreamed, device drivers can be modified to take advantage of the new status reporting capabilities. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Who is leading the writing of the code? Or is this a blueprint where you're throwing it out there to see who picks it up? If more than one person is working on the implementation, please designate the primary author and contact. Primary assignee: pmichali Other contributors: None Need contributers from the various L3 services. Work Items ---------- For each L3 service: * Identify which resources to associate with status (if not global) * Define changes to REST API for status reporting * Modify device driver status reporting to contain status information * Modify python-neutronclient to display status (optionally add cmd) * Create UTs for testing: * REST APIs * Driver status reporting * python-neutronclient changes Dependencies ============ None. Testing ======= Since this blueprint involves the reporting of detailed status information, unit testing should be suffient for ensuring proper operation. Documentation Impact ==================== Documentation for the REST API will need updates for each L3 service, showing the new detailed status information. The python-neutronclient documention will need to be updated indicating the new information (and command, if a global status command will be used for obtaining the detailed status). References ========== None at this time.

commit_message:
Publish L3 service capabilites to client

For short term, remove validation of enum attributes
and revise help messages to support providers that
may have different limits and defaults.

For the long term, allow provider based L3 services
to publish their capabilities to the the Neutron client
giving more accurate information for attributes,
resulting in a better end-user experience.

Change-Id: Ib61d68275c290f875150f6f54f186e3680c316d5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/66/89366/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Publish L3 service capabilites to client ========================================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/l3-svcs-vendor-client-cap Currently, the configuration capabilities available in python-neutronclient for an L3 service is bound by the reference implementation. Other providers have no way to indicate different attribute values, defaults, or help information, and any simple validation is tied to the reference implementation. Problem description =================== The parser argument definitions for the Neutron client's are tied to the reference implementation, where the default value, allowable choices (for discrete value selections), and help message reflect what the reference implementation supports. This can result in several problems with usability of the L3 service. If a provider doesn't support a value, (for example, the Cisco CSR VPN REST API doesn't yet support IKE v2), then the user will not know until the configuration command is processed by the server, making client side validation impossible. Likewise, if a provider supports a different default than the reference implementation, there is no way to express that difference. This can be misleading, if help message shows the default value. Worst yet, if a provider supports additional values for an attribute, the client will reject the values, preventing the selection from the client side. For example, the Cisco CSR VPN supports additional PFS groups and encyption algorithms. With all of these, the help message may be misleading, if it shows allowable values (as it does in the VPNaaS case for several attributes). Proposed change =============== The proposal here is to allow L3 service providers to *register* their capabilities with the Neutron client. This could be a dictionary with help message, allowable values, and default value. For this to work, there has to be a way to associate the provider currently being used with the configuration command, so that the client can map the corresponding registered capabilities. One issue with this approach is if there is a level of indirection on the validation. Take for example, VPNaaS, where the IPSec and IKE policies are provider agnostic. The user can define a policy and use it for multiple services. However, the VPN service, is associated with a specific provider, and when IPSec site-to-site connections are created an IPSec and IKE policy are chosen. At that point in time, there can be a conflict with the capabilities selected for these policies, and what the provider based connection supports. It's possble, but more complex, to have the client perform "provider based" validation at the time of the entry for the IPSec connection, checking that the policies are suitable for that vendor. The alternative is to allow this validation complexity to be handled by the server side. For attributes with a range of allowable values, the client side does not currently perform any validation (at least for VPNaas). This could be left as-is, and all validation left to the server, or a similar mapping of per-provider ranges could be provided for these types of attributes. Again, there would be the same "nested" validation concerns, for attributes like the IKE policy's lifetime, which could only be validated when applied to an IPSec connection, for example. An added value to the developers, is that configuration capabilities can be specified in one place (the server), instead of two (as is done with the reference implementation). Each time a change is made, it can be done in one place (well maybe two, if you count the UT). Note: This solution requires provider selection information, such as the Service Type Framework, or the possible Flavor based solution being discussed for Juno. Alternatives ------------ One alternative is to remove all validation from the client, and to refrain from displaying defaults and allowed values in the help messages. This has the adverse effect fo providing less information to the end user on how to use the API. Another alternative is to provide L3 service provider information as part of the Neutron client. This would require maintaining attribute information in two places (client and server), for every L3 service (like what is done essentially for the reference implementations). Data model impact ----------------- No expected change to the data model. REST API impact --------------- No change expected to the REST API, however a new internal API from the Neutron server to client would be created to register the capabilities. This would not be observable/usable by the end-user. Security impact --------------- None (do we need to ensure that the real Neutron server is registering capabilities with the client)? Notifications impact -------------------- None? Other end user impact --------------------- There would be a documentation impact, indicating that values for specific attributes may be based on the provider selected, and that the help messages and allowable values would vary based on the context. Performance Impact ------------------ There would be a minimal performance improvement, by catching invalid configuration selections in the client, rather than after a round trip to the server. Other deployer impact --------------------- There should be no change to deployment, other than ensuring that an updated Neutron server and client are deployed to take advantage of the new registration capability. Developer impact ---------------- Each provider for an L3 service can then create registration mappings for their implementation (and the corresponding documentation changes). Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: pmichali Other contributors: Anyone? Need assistance from other L3 service developers to ensure that the registration and mapping mechanism is generic enough to work for different types of services. Work Items ---------- For each L3 service type: * Identify what attributes need to be configurable per provider. * Design and implement the registration mechanism for server and client. * Integrate with STF/Flavor work to be able to map values. * (optionally) Handle nested/indirect validation of attributes in client. * New UTs for the registration mechanism. * Modification to existing UTs for attributes to use the new mechanism. * Documentation updates to indicate provider variable attributes. Dependencies ============ The neutron-flavor-framework, Service Type Framework, or equivalent solution to provide support for provider based attributes for configuration commands needs to be in place for this blueprint to be realized. Testing ======= This change should not change the existing behavior of the L3 services and so it is not expected that tempest tests are needed for this blueprint. There will need to be unit tests for this new feature, and modifications to existing tests to make use of the new feature. Documentation Impact ==================== Currently, for VPNaaS at least, the API documentation indicates the limits for the reference implementation. There isn't any reference to provider based L3 services. There should be an indication that attributes will vary, based on the provider, and there should be documentation as to the specific capabilities of each provider based L3 service. References ========== None currently.

commit_message:
ML2 Type driver for Overlay Networking

Specification for creation of a new type driver in ML2 to manage
and represent a generic overlay network.

Change-Id: Ic40dbdc455b6b3dedf2556119afc83c9eafa1c85
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/41/104341/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ====================================== ML2 Type driver for Overlay Networking ====================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/ml2-overlay-type-driver This patch proposed to instroduce a new type driver to the ML2 architecuture for allocating and managing overlay network segments. Flows .. seqdiag:: seqdiag { API -> Neutron [label = "POST create_network"]; Neutron -> ML2_Plugin [label = "create_network"]; ML2_Plugin -> Type_Manager [label = "create_network"]; Type_Manager -> Overlay_Driver [label = "allocate_segment(static)"]; Type_Manager <-- Overlay_Driver [label = "overlay segment"]; ML2_Plugin <-- Type_Manager [label = "overlay segment"]; Neutron <-- ML2_Plugin [label = "Network dictionary"]; API <-- Neutron [label = "Network dictionary"]; } .. seqdiag:: seqdiag { ML2_Plugin -> Mech_Manager [label = "bind_port"]; Mech_Manager -> Mech_Driver [label = "bind_port"]; Mech_Driver -> Type_Manager [label = "allocate_segment(dynamic)"]; Type_Manager -> Overlay_Driver [label = "allocate_segment(dynamic)"]; Type_Manager <-- Overlay_Driver [label = "local segment"]; Mech_Driver <-- Type_Manager [label = "local segment"]; Mech_Manager <-- Mech_Driver [label = "Bindings(dynamic)"]; ML2_Plugin <-- Mech_Manager [label = "Bindings(dynamic)"]; } Problem description =================== * The current ML2 type drivers (vlan/vxlan/gre) only allow for global state of networks. * This doesn't let providers who want to implement overlays in the network fabric represent the global and local states of an overlay network in Neutron. Proposed change =============== * This patch creates a generic overlay type driver that will allocate local states of a network out of config specified pools and maintain the global overlay state of the network as well. * Global state will be allocated during create_network and local state will be allocated dynamically with bind_port calls from the mechanism driver(s). * The new type driver will implement the allocate_dynamic_segment call implemented by another blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/ml2-type-driver-refactor * The mechanism driver will send pool information to the type driver during it's bind_port process and the type driver will allocate a segment suitable for the network for the specified pool. * Configuration will allow for the operator to specify a single segment range to be reused across all specified pools or segment ranges per pool. * Configuration will also allow specification of overlay range(s) to be statically allocated to a network during create_network calls. * This patch depends on two other blueprints: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/ml2-type-driver-refactor https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/ml2-dynamic-segment Data model impact ----------------- The overlay type driver will maintain two database tables: Global segment: * Id (pkey) * Neutron network ID. * Global state of the network i.e. the overlay segmentation ID. Local segment: * Global segment ID (fkey global segment). * Pool ID. * Local segmentation ID. The patch will be accompanied by an Alembic database migration script. Other deployer impact --------------------- * A few configuration options will be added to support this type driver: [ml2_type_overlay] OVERLAY_RANGES=a:b,c:d,e:f * The configuration will allow the deployer to specify pools and segment ranges per pool: [ml2_type_overlay:pool<x>] SEGMENT_RANGES=a:b,c:d [ml2_type_overlay:pool<y>] SEGMENT_RANGES=e:f,g:h * Alternately the deployer can also specify global segment ranges that will be reused acros all pools: [ml2_type_overlay] OVERLAY_RANGES=a:b,c:d,e:f SEGMENT_RANGES=g:h,i:j * Local segment ranges will take precedence over global segment ranges when dynamically allocating from a pool i.e. global ranges will only be used if the pool in question does not have a local range specified. * Deployers wil have to explicitly enable this type driver in the ML2 configuration using type_drivers=overlay Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: asomya <asomya@cisco.com> Work Items ---------- * Create new overlay type driver in ML2. * Write unit tests. * Test funtionality. Dependencies ============ * https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/ml2-type-driver-refactor * https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/ml2-dynamic-segment Testing ======= Patch will be accompanied by full unit test coverage testing for all scenarios.

commit_message:
Make Neutron DVR job run on the full tempest suite

The job is still non-voting for now. This change is done
as an effort aimed at shaking the last remaining issues
before turning this job into a voting one.

commit_message:
Raise exception if invalid IP is specified

This patch ensures that all values specified for the configuration
option netapp_controller_ips are valid, rather than logging and
continuing with only the valid addresses.

Closes-Bug: 1396718

Change-Id: I180dc74e4535bfde19f1741cff975f5ec675dd21
(cherry picked from commit 3748994b58e4255958365b0939056cca8c323c9a)

deleted_lines: return None if not ips: msg = _('Controller ips not valid after resolution.') raise exception.NoValidHost(reason=msg)

commit_message:
Check for all required variables in keystone start.sh

This allows Kubernetes to reschedule the container in case a required
variable is missing, for example when the Kubernetes pod is started
before the service.

Additionally, define the KEYSTONE_ADMIN_SERVICE_HOST and
KEYSTONE_PUBLIC_SERVICE_HOST variables to their common version if not
already set to allow usage outside of Kubernetes with docker link
feature.

Change-Id: Ie0966c18076a770e4031bbf5f777dd1be0ba20bc
Closes-Bug: 1398632
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/01/138601/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: : ${KEYSTONE_PUBLIC_SERVICE_HOST:=$KEYSTONE_PUBLIC_PORT_5000_TCP_ADDR} : ${KEYSTONE_ADMIN_SERVICE_HOST:=$KEYSTONE_ADMIN_PORT_35357_TCP_ADDR} KEYSTONE_ADMIN_PASSWORD ADMIN_TENANT_NAME \ KEYSTONE_PUBLIC_SERVICE_HOST KEYSTONE_ADMIN_SERVICE_HOST
deleted_lines: KEYSTONE_ADMIN_PASSWORD ADMIN_TENANT_NAME

commit_message:
Make 'admin_pass' updatable for nova server

We can't update the adminPass for nova server now, although
the property is updatable.

Change-Id: I16af5c4350bf9b27cfb05bd8287e5e8d1b7160b0
Closes-Bug: #1397198

added_lines: def test_server_update_server_admin_password(self): """ Server.handle_update supports changing the admin password. """ return_server = self.fc.servers.list()[1] return_server.id = '5678' server = self._create_test_server(return_server, 'change_password') new_password = 'new_password' update_template = copy.deepcopy(server.t) update_template['Properties']['admin_pass'] = new_password self.patchobject(self.fc.servers, 'get', return_value=return_server) self.patchobject(return_server, 'change_password') scheduler.TaskRunner(server.update, update_template)() self.assertEqual((server.UPDATE, server.COMPLETE), server.state)

commit_message:
NetApp fix vol migration unusability

This patch fixes the volume migration related issue
in which the volume became unusable after successfull inbound
migration due to volume id usage instead of name_id.

Closes-bug: #1370098

commit_message:
Fix 3PAR driver attach error when host name missing

In some cases an error was being thrown by the 3PAR driver
when the 'name' property returned from queryHost was
missing.  This change adds a check so that the driver
reacts properly when this occurs.  Also removed an unneeded
warning output that was still in the FC driver.

This patch is related to this merged bug fix:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/138212/

Closes-Bug: 1398206
Change-Id: I6593dc68616f55496c42d625968adfc684f98032

commit_message:
Describes basic info on HA testing scenarios

Since we have collected information about
HA testing scenarios, let's do the following:

* add HA testing scenarios introductory information
into Planning Guide.

* add specific HA testing scenarios into Operations guide.

Change-Id: Iab983a7403a03ab8e8fe18b96c29380b9c8968a0
Closes-Bug: 1389563

commit_message:
Update LVM lockfile name identical to RAW and Qcow

Currently Raw and Qcow2 use filename as lock file identity
while LVM use whole path. This patch change the lockfile
name of LVM to identical to the others.
It will be helpful to allow driver layer code to remove
those files when the life cycle of an instance ends.

Related-Bug: #1256306

Change-Id: I07aa54032026ca479fe8de08308dae51527a6b13

VendorPassthru commands to support different HTTP methods

Extend the vendor_passthru() library methods and clients to support
issuing different HTTP methods on the vendor endpoints.

Implements: blueprint extended-vendor-passthru
Change-Id: I32a4990ed3db0bc73ce845b9b4119d87ab2e1503

commit_message:
Fixed row deletion for deleted stack

Now heat returns stack with "stack_status == 'DELETE_COMPLETE'"
for deleted stack. Added corresponding check to ajax handler.

HTTPNotFound is not used anymore and deprecated. Removed except
block for it.

Added raise to generic "except Exception" block to prevent
internal errors inside horizon.

Change-Id: Ia9cfd975790872918ba25c347319003ddc3468fa
Closes-Bug: #1367758
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/43/137243/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: stack = None not_found = False try: stack = api.heat.stack_get(request, stack_id) if stack.stack_status == 'DELETE_COMPLETE': not_found = True except exc.HTTPNotFound: not_found = True except Exception as e: messages.error(request, e) if not_found: return stack
deleted_lines: try: return api.heat.stack_get(request, stack_id) except exc.HTTPNotFound: except Exception as e: messages.error(request, e)

commit_message:
Blueprint for Swift datasource driver

Decription:

Swift datasource driver obtains list of containers
and list of objects in container information from
object storage service(Swift) of openstack.

Change-Id: I5b28b40ecba1a65fb7c9754497fc9533896d8109
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/congress-specs refs/changes/16/133416/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Swift Data Source Driver ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/congress/+spec/swift-data-source-driver This blueprint is to add a data source driver for swift. Problem description =================== A datasource driver is required to expose list of containers and list of objects in each container to the Congress policy framework so that we can write policies involving object storage entities. Swift is the OpenStack component that provides object storage service. The swift-datasource-driver interacts with swift service to provide object storage specific states to congress for policy monitoring. Proposed change =============== Add data source driver that integrates congress with swift. Alternatives ------------ N/A Policy ------ This will use the congress language. swift:containers(X) etc. Policy Actions -------------- Just monitoring right now. Data Sources ------------ Swift Data model impact ----------------- TBD REST API impact --------------- N/A Security impact --------------- N/A Notifications impact -------------------- N/A Other end user impact --------------------- N/A Performance Impact ------------------ N/A Other Deployer Impacts ---------------------- N/A Developer Impact ---------------- N/A Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Srinivasa Rao Ragolu sragolu@mvista.com Work Items ---------- - Implement swift driver with essential tables - Implement test code to test the driver - Implement tempest code for real-time tests Dependencies ============ python-swiftclient Testing ======= - Will need to add unit test code - Will add tempest tests. Documentation Impact ==================== N/A References ========== N/A

commit_message:
Add ability to zfssa driver to create multiple initiator groups

Currently the zfssa driver only support one initiator group. This
is causing broken scsi devices when detaching volumes from instances.
This fix adds support for configuring multiple initiator groups.

Closes-Bug: #1378390
DocImpact

Change-Id: Ib3262ebd40e9c2ff2f36d0a7b1b5b3506ed3acc1

commit_message:
Added spec for adding Extract-fn to all translators

Change-Id: Ic5db303b7dee6fadc2a9426f29ec971e6ab3b19a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/congress-specs refs/changes/61/138561/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Add Extract-fn To All Translators ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/congress/+spec/add-extract-fn-to-all-translators This proposal would expand the general functionality of the translate_obj() method by adding a general extract-fn method to translators for HDICT, VDICT, and LIST. This gives datasource developers versatile tool to use when translating data into congress congress drivers. Problem description =================== Today, if a datasource returns an object that contains a json string instead of pure python objects, lists, and dicts, then the translator has no way to read data out of the json object. Proposed change =============== By including the extract-fn method as a translator, the translate_obj() method could then preprocess the data object with extract-fn before running the existing translation code. This way,the programmer can set the extract-fn to a json extractor to convert the json into a python object. Alternatives ------------ Currently if a datasource returns data in a non-standard format a driver developer can create unique methods inside their drivers to handle this data. This proposed change potentially eliminates the need for developers to individually generate code to use in their solutions by providing a tool to assist with translations in base driver class. Policy ------ None Policy Actions -------------- None Data Sources ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other Deployer Impacts ---------------------- None Developer Impact ---------------- This change provides developers more versatility when creating datasource drivers. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Alex Yip Other contributors: Conner Ferguson Work Items ---------- Add extract-fn as a parameter to HDICT, VDICT, and LIST translators. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= To test the results of this change, data will need to be passed through the extract-fn translator then this data will be checked to ensure that it is being displayed in the expected manor. Documentation Impact ==================== Minor additions to the datasource driver based class documentation to inform new developers about what the extract-fn method does as a translator. References ========== None

commit_message:
Workflow documentation is now in infra-manual

OpenStack Project Infrastructure Manual.

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-07-07 16:29:35.000000000', 'files': ['tests/test_titles.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs/commit/4c2c9dddae3c79c01900b3b90c686e26cf985110', 'message': "tests: ignore editor backups when testing spec sections

The tests.test_titles.TestTitles.test_template test has a
check for the spec filename ending in '.rst', which will
raise errors any time an editor creates a backup file
eg 'foo~' or 'foo.bak'.  Ignore these obvious editor temp

Change-Id: I692670cbb10bcdbb8569a59dd3ad90cf3f43ae4b
"}]
commit_message:
tests: ignore editor backups when testing spec sections

The tests.test_titles.TestTitles.test_template test has a
check for the spec filename ending in '.rst', which will
raise errors any time an editor creates a backup file
eg 'foo~' or 'foo.bak'.  Ignore these obvious editor temp
files.

Change-Id: I692670cbb10bcdbb8569a59dd3ad90cf3f43ae4b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/29/105229/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @staticmethod def _is_editor_backup(filename): endings = ["~", ".bak"] for ending in endings: if filename.endswith(ending): return True return False if self._is_editor_backup(filename): continue

commit_message:
virt: switch get_available_resource to use VirtHostResources

Update the get_available_resource() method so that the dict
it returns is entirely replaced by a VirtHostResources instance.
The resource tracker is update to convert this back into the
traditional dict format. It is expected that when the resource
tracker is refactored it will be able to use the new object
more directly and avoid the intermediate dict.

Blueprint: virt-driver-get-available-resources-object
Change-Id: I2e9c3ec326029f2a8c87ee31164f67e47d49f5f3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/86/127586/11 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: res = hardware.VirtHostResources( "hyperv", self._get_hypervisor_version(), platform.node()) res.cpus_total = vcpus # TODO(berrange) something sensible needs to be # reported here res.vcpus_used = 0 res.disk_gb_total = total_hdd_gb res.disk_gb_used = used_hdd_gb res.disk_gb_least = None res.memory_mb_total = total_mem_mb res.memory_mb_used = used_mem_mb res.cpu_model = cpu_info res.supported_instances = [ hardware.VirtInstanceInfo(arch.I686, hvtype.HYPERV, vm_mode.HVM), hardware.VirtInstanceInfo(arch.X86_64, hvtype.HYPERV, vm_mode.HVM) ] return res
deleted_lines: dic = {'vcpus': vcpus, 'memory_mb': total_mem_mb, 'memory_mb_used': used_mem_mb, 'local_gb': total_hdd_gb, 'local_gb_used': used_hdd_gb, 'hypervisor_type': "hyperv", 'hypervisor_version': self._get_hypervisor_version(), 'hypervisor_hostname': platform.node(), 'vcpus_used': 0, 'cpu_info': cpu_info, 'supported_instances': [ hardware.VirtInstanceInfo(arch.I686, hvtype.HYPERV, vm_mode.HVM), hardware.VirtInstanceInfo(arch.X86_64, hvtype.HYPERV, vm_mode.HVM) ], 'numa_topology': None, } return dic

commit_message:
virt: switch get_available_resource to use VirtCPUModel

Update the get_available_resource() method so that the dict
it returns uses a VirtCPUModel instance for the 'cpu_info'
field, instead of a JSON string. The resource tracker then
converts this to the format it most desires when it needs
to.

Blueprint: virt-driver-get-available-resources-object
Change-Id: Iee01f68bf02bd4f57fdc6cad4b5145151a2cd0ae
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/85/127585/13 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: arch = w32_arch_dict.get(processors[0]['Architecture'], None) model = processors[0]['Name'] vendor = processors[0]['Manufacturer'] topology = hardware.VirtCPUTopology( sockets=len(processors), cores=int(processors[0]['NumberOfCores']), threads=(int(processors[0]['NumberOfLogicalProcessors']) / int(processors[0]['NumberOfCores']))) features.append(hardware.VirtCPUFeature(name=fname)) return hardware.VirtCPUModel( mode=hardware.VirtCPUModel.MODE_CUSTOM, name=model, vendor=vendor, arch=arch, features=features, topology=topology) cpu_topology = cpu_info.topology vcpus = (cpu_topology.sockets * cpu_topology.cores * cpu_topology.threads) 'cpu_info': cpu_info,
deleted_lines: from nova.openstack.common import jsonutils cpu_info = dict() cpu_info['arch'] = w32_arch_dict.get(processors[0]['Architecture'], 'Unknown') cpu_info['model'] = processors[0]['Name'] cpu_info['vendor'] = processors[0]['Manufacturer'] topology = dict() topology['sockets'] = len(processors) topology['cores'] = processors[0]['NumberOfCores'] topology['threads'] = (processors[0]['NumberOfLogicalProcessors'] / processors[0]['NumberOfCores']) cpu_info['topology'] = topology features.append(fname) cpu_info['features'] = features return cpu_info cpu_topology = cpu_info['topology'] vcpus = (cpu_topology['sockets'] * cpu_topology['cores'] * cpu_topology['threads']) 'cpu_info': jsonutils.dumps(cpu_info),

As is the barbican command fails with a traceback because this package

commit_message:
Correctly set pbr version name

As is the barbican command fails with a traceback because this package
name is incorrect.

Change-Id: I307fae3819a679199bab0570010985fdb7401112
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-barbicanclient refs/changes/92/139292/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: version_info = pbr.version.VersionInfo("python-barbicanclient")
deleted_lines: version_info = pbr.version.VersionInfo("barbicanclient")

commit_message:
virt: switch get_available_resource to use VirtNUMATopology

Update the get_available_resource() method so that the dict
it returns uses a VirtNUMATopology instance for the
"numa_topology" field, instead of a JSON string. The resource
tracker then converts this to the format it most desires when
it needs to.

Blueprint: virt-driver-get-available-resources-object
Change-Id: Iee01f68bf02bd4f57fdc6cad4b5145151a2cd0ab

deleted_lines: self.assertThat(hardware.VirtNUMAHostTopology.from_json( stats['numa_topology'])._to_dict(), matchers.DictMatches( HostStateTestCase.numa_topology._to_dict()))

commit_message:
virt: switch get_available_resource to use VirtPCIDeviceInfo

Update the get_available_resource() method so that the dict
it returns uses a list of VirtPCIDeviceInfo for the (renamed)
"pci_devices" field, instead of a JSON string. The resource
tracker then converts this to the format it most desires when
it needs to.

commit_message:
virt: switch get_available_resource to use VirtHVSpec

Update the get_available_resource() method so that the dict
it returns uses a list of VirtHVSpec for the
"supported_instances" field, instead of a JSON string. The
resource tracker then converts this to the format it most
desires when it needs to.

Blueprint: virt-driver-get-available-resources-object
Change-Id: Ia738cf378d0c2e8420d2cd0ec0ddf82d5f1ae79c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/82/127582/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from nova.virt import hardware 'supported_instances': [ hardware.VirtInstanceInfo(arch.I686, hvtype.HYPERV, vm_mode.HVM), hardware.VirtInstanceInfo(arch.X86_64, hvtype.HYPERV, vm_mode.HVM) ],
deleted_lines: 'supported_instances': jsonutils.dumps( [(arch.I686, hvtype.HYPERV, vm_mode.HVM), (arch.X86_64, hvtype.HYPERV, vm_mode.HVM)]),

commit_message:
virt: introduce VirtHostResources object

Extend nova.virt.hardware to provide a VirtHostResources
class. An instance of this class will be capable of
representing the set of resources available & allocated
on a hypervisor host. It is intended that an instance
of this class be returned by the get_available_resource
method instead of an undocumented dict()

Blueprint: virt-driver-get-available-resources-object
Change-Id: I27ed23c6a7671b9bf3257f2af4437974daa0b11a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/81/127581/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class VirtHostResources(object): def __init__(self, hv_driver, hv_version, hv_hostname): """Create new host resources information record :param hv_driver: name of the hypervisor driver :param hv_version: version of the hypervisor :param hv_hostname: hostname of the control plane OS """ self.hypervisor_type = hv_driver self.hypervisor_version = hv_version self.hypervisor_hostname = hv_hostname # Number of logical CPUs present on the host self.cpus_total = None # Number of virtual CPUs used by guests, which # may be larger than cpus_total due to use of # overcommit self.vcpus_used = None # Amount of memory present on the host self.memory_mb_total = None # Amount of memory currently used by guests, # which may be less than the guests' # allocation with some hypervisors self.memory_mb_used = None # Total disk space available on the host # for image storage self.disk_gb_total = None # Disk space used by guests images, which # may be less tha nthe guests's disk # allocation due to grow-on-demand disk # image formats self.disk_gb_used = None # Smallest amount of free space if all # guest disk images were fully allocated self.disk_gb_least = None # Arbitrary dict of extra statistics self.stats = None # VirtCPUModel object self.cpu_model = None # List of VirtPCIDeviceInfo objects self.pci_devices = [] # List of VirtInstanceInfo objects self.supported_instances = [] # VirtNUMAHostTopology object self.numa_topology = None

commit_message:
virt: introduce VirtCPUModel object

Extend nova.virt.hardware to provide a VirtCPUModel class.
An instance of this class will be capable of representing
both the physical CPU in the host and the virtual CPU
exposed to the guest instance.

Blueprint: virt-driver-get-available-resources-object
Change-Id: I27ed23c6a7671b9bf3257f2af4437974daa0b14a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/80/127580/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _to_dict(self): return { 'sockets': self.sockets, 'cores': self.cores, 'threads': self.threads } @classmethod def _from_dict(cls, data): return cls(**data) class VirtCPUFeature(object): """Class for representing guest CPU feature flag. There are currently five policies for how a feature flag is exposed to the guest - POLICY_FORCE - the feature will be enabled even if not present in the host CPU - POLICY_REQUIRE - the guest will fail to start if the feature is not present in the host CPU - POLICY_OPTIONAL - the feature will be enabled if it is present in the host CPU, disabled otherwise. - POLICY_DISABLE - the feature will be disabled if it is present in the host CPU, even if implied by the CPU model name. - POLICY_FORBID - the guest will fail to start if the feature is present in the host CPU """ POLICY_FORCE = "force" POLICY_REQUIRE = "require" POLICY_OPTIONAL = "optional" POLICY_DISABLE = "disable" POLICY_FORBID = "forbid" def __init__(self, name, policy=POLICY_REQUIRE): self.name = name self.policy = policy def _to_dict(self): return {'name': self.name, 'policy': self.policy} @classmethod def _from_dict(cls, data): return cls(**data) class VirtCPUModel(object): """Class for representing guest CPU model. There are currently three ways to represent the guest CPU model, chosen using the mode attribute. - MODE_CUSTOM - a named CPU model & feature set. The set of valid names is hypervisor dependant. - MODE_HOST_MODEL - a named CPU model & feature set automatically chosen based on the host CPU. - MODE_HOST_PASSTHROUGH - direct passthrough of the host CPU without changes. It is not possible to migrate guests with this model. When determining if a host CPU is compatible with the requested guest CPU, there are a number of match options - MATCH_NONE - no match policy. Used if the CPU model instance represents a host CPU only. - MATCH_MINIMUM - the guest CPU will be given at least the requested features. Other features from the host may be exposed to the guest depending on hypervisor choice. - MATCH_EXACT - only the exact listed features will be exposed to the guest, even if the hypervisor supports more features. - MATCH_STRICT - only the exact listed features will be exposed to the guest, and if the hypervisor supports more features it will refuse to start the guest. """ # TODO(berrange): VMWare/Hyper-V might require us to # define more MODE types in future. This is at least # sufficient for libvirt right now and could cope with # some other hypervisor configs too. MODE_CUSTOM = "custom" MODE_HOST_MODEL = "host-model" MODE_HOST_PASSTHROUGH = "host-passthrough" MATCH_NONE = "none" MATCH_MINIMUM = "minimum" MATCH_EXACT = "exact" MATCH_STRICT = "strict" def __init__(self, mode, name=None, arch=None, features=None, vendor=None, topology=None, match=MATCH_NONE): if features is None: features = [] self.mode = mode self.arch = compute_arch.canonicalize(arch) self.name = name self.features = features self.vendor = vendor self.topology = topology self.match = match def _to_dict(self): data = {'mode': self.mode, 'features': [feat._to_dict() for feat in self.features]} if self.arch is not None: data['arch'] = self.arch if self.name is not None: data['name'] = self.name if self.vendor is not None: data['vendor'] = self.vendor if self.topology is not None: data['topology'] = self.topology._to_dict() if self.match is not None: data['match'] = self.match return data @classmethod def _from_dict(cls, data): features = [VirtCPUFeature._from_dict(f) for f in data['features']] if data.get('topology', None) is not None: topo = VirtCPUTopology._from_dict(data['topology']) else: topo = None return cls(mode=data['mode'], arch=data.get('arch', None), name=data.get('name', None), vendor=data.get('vendor', None), features=features, topology=topo, match=data.get('match', None)) def to_json(self): return jsonutils.dumps(self._to_dict()) @classmethod def from_json(cls, json_string): return cls._from_dict(jsonutils.loads(json_string))

commit_message:
virt: introduce VirtPCIDeviceInfo & VirtPCIAddressInfo classes

Extend nova.virt.hardware to provide the VirtPCIDeviceInfo and
VirtPCIAddressInfo classes. The VirtPCIDeviceInfo class provides
information about a single PCI device present on the host. It
references a VirtPCIAddressInfo class instance to provide the
address of the device. If the device is a virtual function,
it will also reference a second VirtPCIAddressInfo instance to
provide the address of the physical function.

Blueprint: virt-driver-get-available-resources-object
Change-Id: I27ed23c6a7671b9bf3257f2af4437974daa0b13a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/79/127579/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class VirtPCIAddressInfo(object): def __init__(self, domain, bus, slot, function): """Create new PCI device address information record :param domain: the PCI domain component :param bus: the PCI bus component :param slot: the PCI slot component :param function: the PCI function component """ self.domain = domain self.bus = bus self.slot = slot self.function = function def _to_str(self): return "%04x:%02x:%02x.%1x" % ( self.domain, self.bus, self.slot, self.function) @classmethod def _from_str(cls, data): bits1 = data.split(":") bits2 = bits1[2].split(".") return cls( bits1[0], bits1[1], bits2[0], bits2[1]) class VirtPCIDeviceInfo(object): DEV_TYPE_REGULAR = "type-PCI" DEV_TYPE_PHYS_FUNC = "type-PF" DEV_TYPE_VIRT_FUNC = "type-VF" def __init__(self, dev_type, dev_id, label, vendor_id, product_id, address, phys_function=None): """Create new PCI device information record :param dev_type: type of device - DEV_TYPE constants :param dev_id: unique string identifier for device :param label: descriptive label of the device :param vendor_id: integer ID of the vendor :param product_id: integer ID of the product :param address: instance of VirtPCIAddressInfo :param phys_function: instance of VirtPCIAddressInfo """ self.dev_type = dev_type self.dev_id = dev_id self.label = label self.vendor_id = vendor_id self.product_id = product_id self.address = address self.phys_function = phys_function if address is None: raise exception.PCIDeviceAddressMissing() # TODO(berrange) the xenapi driver doesn't provide the # parent address for virtual functions yet. When we # can address that in xenapi we should enable this # validation rule # if (dev_type == VirtPCIDeviceInfo.DEV_TYPE_VIRT_FUNC and # phys_function is None): # raise exception.PCIDeviceParentAddressMissing() def _to_dict(self): data = { "dev_type": self.dev_type, "dev_id": self.dev_id, "label": self.label, "vendor_id": "%04x" % self.vendor_id, "product_id": "%04x" % self.product_id, "address": self.address._to_str(), } if self.phys_function is not None: data["phys_function"] = self.phys_function._to_str() return data @classmethod def _from_dict(cls, data): return cls( data["dev_type"], data["dev_id"], data["label"], int(data["vendor_id"], 16), int(data["product_id"], 16), VirtPCIAddressInfo._from_str(data["address"]), VirtPCIAddressInfo._from_str(data.get("phys_function")))

commit_message:
virt: introduce VirtHVSpec object

Extend nova.virt.hardware to provide a VirtHVSpec class.
An instance of this class will represent the ABI of a guest
instance that is able to be hosted on the hypervisor.

Blueprint: virt-driver-get-available-resources-object
Change-Id: I27ed23c6a7671b9bf3257f2af4437974daa0b12a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/78/127578/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from nova.compute import arch as compute_arch from nova.compute import hvtype as compute_hvtype from nova.compute import vm_mode as compute_vmmodeclass VirtInstanceInfo(object): """Records information about the guest instances hardware types that can be executed by the hypervisor. """ def __init__(self, arch, hvtype, vmmode): """Create new instance information record :param arch: one of nova.compute.arch constants :param hvtype: one of nova.compute.hvtype constants :param vmmode: one of nova.compute.vmmode constants """ self.arch = compute_arch.canonicalize(arch) self.hvtype = compute_hvtype.canonicalize(hvtype) self.vmmode = compute_vmmode.canonicalize(vmmode) def _to_dict(self): return { "arch": self.arch, "hvtype": self.hvtype, "vmmode": self.vmmode } @classmethod def _from_dict(cls, data): return cls(data["arch"], data["hvtype"], data["vmmode"])

commit_message:
[Data_processing] auto security group

Set auto_security_group field checked by default.
This change also sets the value for copy workflow.

Closes-Bug: #1383600

commit_message:
Show up to 1 decimal place for instance detail RAM

The current instance details page rounds the amount of RAM to the
nearest integer, which at GB and TB levels does not provide enough
fidelity to be useful, this patch allows the page to display up to one
decimal place if it is required, by changing the filter applied in the
template from mbformat to mb_float_format.

Change-Id: Ida97e83285b64ac6b08260f78f31c69dc37009b0
Closes-Bug: 1384446

commit_message:
Remove Python 2.6 classifier

Horizon does not support Python 2.6 anymore starting with Kilo and might
not work correctly with it, so remove the classifier.

Change-Id: Idb2a044968bf35c1fbe4ab42188c6f7df096d442

commit_message:
Use auto create DB item feature for instances

Change-Id: I6bd8be64d506aae81558c7850ed7b8fa2e0dc780
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ec2-api refs/changes/19/138419/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: instance = ec2utils.get_db_item_by_os_id( context, 'i', os_instance.id, novadb_instance=novadb_instance)def _auto_create_instance_extension(context, instance, novadb_instance=None): if not novadb_instance: novadb_instance = novadb.instance_get_by_uuid(context, instance['os_id']) instance['reservation_id'] = novadb_instance['reservation_id'] instance['launch_index'] = novadb_instance['launch_index'] ec2utils.register_auto_create_db_item_extension( 'i', _auto_create_instance_extension)
deleted_lines: instance = db_api.add_item( context, 'i', {'os_id': os_instance.id, 'vpc_id': None, 'reservation_id': novadb_instance['reservation_id'], 'launch_index': novadb_instance['launch_index']})

subject: Blueprint for the implementation of Nested Quota Driver API
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-07-30 13:18:58.000000000', 'files': ['specs/juno/nested-quota-driver-api.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs/commit/8968daf3a106123c362293f2c55fda5008676d12', 'message': 'Blueprint for the implementation of Nested Quota Driver API

Nested Quota Driver API helps in the the enforcement of
quota in Hierarchical Projects

Depends On: blueprint hierarchical-multitenancy

Change-Id: I219e335a9818ee6b39a4f21692128bc8497a11ae
'}]
commit_message:
Blueprint for the implementation of Nested Quota Driver API

Nested Quota Driver API helps in the the enforcement of
quota in Hierarchical Projects

Depends On: blueprint hierarchical-multitenancy

Change-Id: I219e335a9818ee6b39a4f21692128bc8497a11ae
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/39/110639/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ======================= nested-quota-driver-api ======================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/nested-quota-driver-api Nested quota driver will enable OpenStack projects to enforce quota in nested projects. The nested projects are having a hierarchical structure, where each project may contain users and projects (can be called sub-projects), except for projects at the last level in the hierarchy called leaf nodes, which contain only users. Users can have different roles inside each project: A normal user can make use of resources of a project. A project admin is a user who in addition is allowed to create sub-projects, assign quota on resources to these sub-projects and assign the project admin role to individual users of the sub-projects. Resources quotas of the root project can only be set by the cloud admin.The users roles can be set as inherited, and if set, then an admin of a project is automatically an admin of all projects in the tree below. Problem description =================== OpenStack is moving towards to support for hierarchical ownership of objects. In this regard, the Keystone will change the organizational structure of Openstack, creating nested projects in Keystone. The existing Quota Driver in Nova called "DbQuotaDriver" is useful to enforce quotas at both the project and the project-user level provided that all the projects are at the same level (i.e hierarchy level canot be greater than 1). The proposal is to develop a new Quota Driver called "NestedQuotaDriver", which will allow enforcing quotas in hierarchical multitenancy of Openstack. Use Case: **Actors** * Martha - Admin (i.e role:cloud-admin) of ProductionIT * Joe - Manager (i.e role: project-admin) of Project CMS * Sam - Manager (i.e role: project-admin) of Project ATLAS * Bill : is one important CMS user and needs access to the bulk of computing resources of CMS for a physics analysis Martha is an infrastructure provider and offers cloud services to Joe for Project CMS, and Sam for Project ATLAS. Martha needs to be able to set the quotas for both CMS and ATLAS, and manage quotas across the entire system. Joe has multiple sub-projects with many users under CMS. Joe needs the ability to create quotas, as well as the ability to list and delete resources across CMS. Sam and Joe cannot see or manipulate the resources owned by each other, only Martha has the ability to manage the whole cloud. Joe can approve the request of Bill for an increase of quota for his activity, and changes the quota of the Bills projects without having to involve the cloud admin. Proposed change =============== 1. The default quota (hard limit) for any newly created project is set to 0. The neutral value of zero ensures consistency of data in the case of race conditions when several project are created by admins at the same time. 2. A project is allowed to create a server(VM) only after setting the quota is set to a non-zero value (as default value is 0). After the creation of a new project Quota values must be set explicitly by a Nova API call to a value which ensures availability of free quota before resources can be claimed in the project. 3. A user with role "cloud-admin" is permitted to do quota operations across the entire hierarchy, including the top level project. Cloud-Admins are the only users who are allowed to set the quota of the root project in a tree, and assign the Project-admin role to users in the root project. 4. A person with role "project-admin" in a project is permitted to do quota operations on its siblings (sub-projects and users) in the hierarchy. If the role "projet-admin" on a project is set as inheritable in Keystone, then the user with this role is permitted to do quota operations starting from that project to the last level project/user under the project hierarchy. 5. The total resources consumed by a project is dividied into a.Used Quota - Resources used by the project users (excluding child-projects) b.Reserved Quota - Resources reserved for future use by the project c.Allocated Quota - Sum of the quota "hard_limit" value of immediate child projects 6. The "free" quota availabile with a project is calculated as free quota = hard_limit - (used + reserved + allocated) Free quota is not stored in database; it is calculated for each project on the fly. 7. An increase in the quota value of a project is allowed only if its parent has sufficient free quota available. If there is free quota available at the parent, then the quota update operation will result in update of the "hard_limit" value of the project and "allocated" value update of parent project. That's why, it should be noted that updating the quota of a project requires the token to be scoped at the parent level. * Hierarchy of Projects is as A->B->C Project A (hard_limit = 100, used = 0, reserved = 0, allocated = 50) Project B (hard_limit = 50, used = 20, reserved = 0, allocated = 10) Project C (hard_limit = 10, used = 10, reserved = 0, allocated = 0) Free quota for projects would be: A:Free Quota = 100 {A:hard_limit} - ( 0 {A:used} + 0 {A:reserved} + 50 {A:Allocated to B}) A:Free Quota = 50 B:Free Quota = 50 {B:hard_limit} - ( 20 {B:used} + 0 {B:reserved} + 10 {B:Allocated to C}) B:Free Quota = 20 C:Free Quota = 10 {C:hard_limit} - ( 10 {C:used} + 0 {C:reserved} + 0 {C:Allocated}) C:Free Quota = 0 If Project C hard_limit is increased by 10, then this change results in: Project A (hard_limit = 100, used = 0, reserved = 0, allocated = 50) Project B (hard_limit = 50, used = 20, reserved = 0, allocated = 20) Project C (hard_limit = 20, used = 10, reserved = 0, allocated = 0) If Project C hard_limit needs to be increased further by 20, then this operation will be aborted, because the free quota available with its parent i.e Project B is only 10. So, first project-admin of A should increase the "hard_limit" of Project B (using scoped token to Project A, because of action at level A) and then increase the "hard_limit" of Project C (again scoped token to Project B) 8.A decrease in the quota value of a project is allowed only if it has free quota available free quota > 0 (zero) And hence the maximum decrese in quota value is limited to free quota value. * Hierarchy of Projects is A->B->C,where A is the root project Project A (hard_limit = 100, used = 0, reserved = 0, allocated = 50) Project B (hard_limit = 50, used = 20, reserved = 0, allocated = 10) Project C (hard_limit = 10, used = 10, reserved = 0, allocated = 0) If Project B hard_limit is reduced by 10, then this change results in Project A (hard_limit = 100, used = 0, reserved = 0, allocated = 40) Project B (hard_limit = 40, used = 20, reserved = 0, allocated = 10) Project C (hard_limit = 10, used = 10, reserved = 0, allocated = 0) If Project B's hard_limit needs to be reduced further by 20, then this operation will be aborted, because the free quota of Project B should be greater than or equal to (20+0+10) Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- Create a new column "allocated" in table "quota_usages" with default value 0. REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: * sajeesh Other contributors: * vishy * schwicke * raildo * vinod * nirbhay * morganfainberg * tellesnobrega * rodrigodsousa * afaranha Work Items ---------- 1. Two new roles will be used "cloud-admin" and "project-admin". Users with role "cloud-admin" will be able to do quota operations on any project/user in the hierarchy. The user with "project-admin" role on a project will be able to do quota operations on the child projects which he created. 2. A new Quota Driver called "NestedQuotaDriver" will be implemented to enforce quotas in hierarchical multitenancy of OpenStack. Dependencies ============ Depends on bp Hierarchical Multitenancy * https://blueprints.launchpad.net/keystone/+spec/hierarchical-multitenancy Testing ======= * Add unit tests for the REST APIs calls. * Add unit tests for integration with other services. Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== * Wiki <https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/HierarchicalMultitenancy>

Get DB item by os id with auto creation possibility

added_lines: _auto_create_db_item_extensions = {} def register_auto_create_db_item_extension(kind, extension): _auto_create_db_item_extensions[kind] = extension def get_db_item_by_os_id(context, kind, os_id, items_by_os_id=None, **extension_kwargs): if os_id is None: return None if items_by_os_id is not None: item = items_by_os_id.get(os_id) if item: return item item = next((i for i in db_api.get_items(context, kind) if i['os_id'] == os_id), None) if not item: item = {'os_id': os_id} extension = _auto_create_db_item_extensions.get(kind) if extension: extension(context, item, **extension_kwargs) item = db_api.add_item(context, kind, item) if items_by_os_id is not None: items_by_os_id[os_id] = item return item

subject: Nova config should use NOVA_SERVICE_HOST

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-10-28 16:32:10.000000000', 'files': ['lib/nova'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack/commit/2ae39ad446a22dfa235ced94b93dc15fa652e9be', 'message': 'Nova config should use NOVA_SERVICE_HOST

Much of the Nova config was using SERVICE_HOST (and in one case HOST_IP)
for Nova config options that should be overrideable to
NOVA_SERVICE_HOST. Update lib/nova:create_nova_conf to use
NOVA_SERVICE_HOST in these cases.

This makes the nova config consistent with other services and allows for
more flexibility (like running nova control plane behind NATed floating

Change-Id: I823d9b79c04526b053715cda32926e1cf343368d
'}]
commit_message:
Nova config should use NOVA_SERVICE_HOST

Much of the Nova config was using SERVICE_HOST (and in one case HOST_IP)
for Nova config options that should be overrideable to
NOVA_SERVICE_HOST. Update lib/nova:create_nova_conf to use
NOVA_SERVICE_HOST in these cases.

This makes the nova config consistent with other services and allows for
more flexibility (like running nova control plane behind NATed floating
IPs).

Change-Id: I823d9b79c04526b053715cda32926e1cf343368d

commit_message:
Allow keypair to be specified in environment

Added a hook to allow for the 'key-name' field to be specified by
an environment variable, NOVACLIENT_DEFAULT_KEY_NAME,  rather
than a command line argument.

Change-Id: I35341d5f6872eebb75140fa6469f53974969d041
Closes-Bug: 1327418

commit_message:
Fix For Bug #1233492 : "nova list doesn't work with tenant name, only tenant id"

After this bug fix, the nova list will work with tenant name and tenant id. Change done in python-novaclient.

nova --os-tenant-name admin list --tenant demo --all-tenants 1 - Will return servers list (similar to, when tenant-id is passed in place of tenant-name)

Closes Bug : 1233492

Change-Id: Ie5f6aae7be5d844a42506232214fedcd4b8427ca

commit_message:
Adding Read-Only volume attaching support to Nova client

Adding mode argument to volume-attach sub-command.
Allow end user using read-write or read-only mode to attach a volume to
an instance.

blueprint read-only-volumes

Change-Id: I12ad13b4c8ff773269d39a7ffe0d357ade8a80d5
Signed-off-by: Zhi Yan Liu <zhiyanl@cn.ibm.com>

commit_message:
Make write_to_completion_cache thread safe

This method was not thread safe resulting in exception
when multiple threads were in use

Change-Id: If07946429ed03fe17ce479192ccb1a6954f5e909
Closes-Bug: #1263581

commit_message:
Add username of the owner in nova list response

Currently nova list command does not show which user the particular
VM belong too. In enterprise deployments, knowing which user booted
the VM could be very useful for the cluster administrator.
This will save admin a lot of manual steps before knowing the owner
of the VM. In this blueprint, we plan to add an additional column
'username' to 'nova list' output which will facilitate cluster
maintenance for the administrator
command to use: nova list --show-owner

Implements blueprint username-in-nova-list-response

Change-Id: I63c19cb92f09d61e1e1e5da994b777fb44781a81

added_lines: from six.moves.urllib import parse from keystoneclient.apiclient import exceptions as kexceptions from keystoneclient.v2_0 import client as keystoneclient_v2@utils.arg('--show-owner', dest='show_owner', action="store_true", default=False, help=_('Show owner of each server (Admin only).')) if args.show_owner: _get_owner(cs, search_opts, servers) if servers: # only add the username column if it exists in server if getattr(servers[0], 'username', ''): columns.append('Username')def _get_userlist(cs, keystoneclient, all=False): # get userlist for the requester's tenant userdict = {} try: tenant_id = cs.client.tenant_id if all: tenant_id = None users = keystoneclient.users.list(tenant_id=tenant_id) # make a dict user_id: username for user in users: userdict[user.id] = user.name except kexceptions.Forbidden: # No need to do anything. Empty dictionary will be returned. pass return userdict def _show_owner(cs, search_opts, servers): magic_tuple = parse.urlsplit(cs.client.auth_url) scheme, netloc, path, query, frag = magic_tuple port = magic_tuple.port if port is None: port = 80 # TODO(sandy): Assume admin endpoint is 35357 for now. # Ideally this is going to have to be provided by the service catalog. new_netloc = netloc.replace(':%d' % port, ':%d' % (35357,)) admin_url = parse.urlunsplit( (scheme, new_netloc, path, query, frag)) keystoneclient = keystoneclient_v2.Client(token=cs.client.auth_token, endpoint=admin_url) # only pull userlist if not limited to requester user if 'user_id' not in search_opts: all = True if 'all_tenants' in search_opts else False userdict = _get_userlist(cs, keystoneclient, all=all) #return userdict for server in servers: if userdict: # add username if we have it username = userdict.get(getattr(server, 'user_id', '')) setattr(server, 'username', username)

commit_message:
Added support for periodic checks and results lists

- Added periodic_checks and check_results to both v1_1 and v3
- Added commands periodic-check-list and check-result-list to shell

Change-Id: Ic229b1616a99a1f632d184678dec12cccac0e986
Implements: blueprint periodic-security-checks

added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from novaclient import base from novaclient.v1_1 import periodic_checks class PeriodicCheck(base.Resource): """ A check is a periodic task to update trusted pool. """ HUMAN_ID = True def __repr__(self): return "<Check: %s>" % self.name def delete(self): """ Delete this check. """ self.manager.delete(self) class PeriodicCheckManager(periodic_checks.PeriodicCheckManager): """ Manage :class:`PeriodicCheck` resources. """ resource_class = PeriodicCheck def _build_body(self, name, desc, timeout, id): return { "periodic_check": { "name": name, "desc": desc, "timeout": timeout, "id": id } }

commit_message:
limit novaclient commands to those available

Currently, "nova help"  mixes end user and cloud operator commands.
This fix adds a string "Administrative command" in the description of
commands, which are admin specific, to make it more informative to the
user. By doing this, non-admin users will get to know that the admin
specific commands will not work for him/her.

Closes bug: #892067

Change-Id: I839108ab59446235f7c0323bd5d2407725038cbf

commit_message:
Nova scrub will delete everything under a tenant

When passed a tenant id, nova scrub is suppose to delete
all instances, networks, and secgroups related to that tenant.
Right now, it doesn't clear any instances and it often gets
hung up on deleting secgroups.

Nova scrub will now delete all networks, secgroups, and instances
underneath the specified tenant.

Change-Id: I0ad6aa46df0e7a6de85871876c0ba20efc53046e
Closes-Bug: #1280389
Related-Bug: #1351315

deleted_lines: search_opts = {'all_tenants': 1}

commit_message:
Add profiling support to novaclient

To be able to create profiling traces for Nova, client should be
able to send special HTTP header that contains trace info.
This patch is as well important to be able to make cross project
traces. (Typical case heat calls nova via python client, if
profiler is initialized in heat, nova client will add extra
header, that will be parsed by special osprofiler middleware in nova
api)
Don't worry no security issue here, trace information is signed by HMAC
key that is setted in api-paste.ini. So only person that knows HMAC key
is able to send proper header.

oslo-spec:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/103825/

main-patch:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/105096/

Change-Id: If687c6006e3162a25089c01ca4af066e0d2e00f2

commit_message:
handle --endpoint_type without weird hackery

there was some special-case code in novaclient/shell.py to handle both
--endpoint-type and --endpoint_type.  By adding --endpoint_type as an
additional argument to add_argument, it Just Works.

Change-Id: Ic91836d09ed4982cd413e32cfe21f36d0fafe35e

commit_message:
Pass instance name as parameter in nova cli

After the proposed bug fix, the admin can also start/stop
instances of other tenants by passing instance name as the
parameter. Initially it could be done only through ids. One
additional argument --all-tenants is added so that the
instance name is searched across all tenants.

Previous command was:
nova start/stop <instance_name>

New command is:
nova stop <instance_name> --all-tenants

Change-Id: Ie5f8c5c15dee6060b979a34ed0aa01262e05e122
Closes-Bug: #1297963

commit_message:
Make sure test code isn't used outside of the test suite

Code outside of the test suite should not be importing anything from
nova.tests.

Adds [N328] Do not import nova test suite outside the test suite

Change-Id: I39758f09e1be4c46a5505dcc049a6d22ba53fb6e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/15/125215/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def import_no_test_suite(logical_line, filename): """Check for nova/tests imports outside of the test suite N328 """ if "nova/tests/" not in filename and "nova/test.py" not in filename: if (logical_line.startswith("from nova.tests") or logical_line.startswith("import nova.test")): yield (0, "N328: Don't import nova test suite outside of " "the test suite") register(import_no_test_suite)

commit_message:
Vmware attach the iscsi volume in the right way

Attach the iscsi volume to the right Adapter, if the 'Vitual Disk'
make 'adapter_type' decision to 'ide', then change it to the default one

Change-Id: I7a9d2e495f7a47f8f8866adc40b046e2e019d611
Closes-bug: #1383100
